11.content:
Two years.

Two years since she'd left, two years since she'd ran. Since she'd left Simon naked under the sheets in his bed and heard his groggy, "Bye, Vic," as she was pulling her shirt on over her head. She'd hadn't turned around. She hadn't looked to see if he was watching. But she'd called back to him. She'd said it like it like it was forever - and in her mind, it was supposed to be.

"Goodbye, Simon."

She'd walked out the door. She'd left him naked under the sheets and she'd been saying goodbye forever.

But that was two years ago.


***



"You're gonna kick ass, I know it."

Victoria Wolfe ran a hand over her face, pausing to adjust the eye patch covering her left eye. She'd lost it a year ago in an arena match in Dublin. The bastard hadn't been playing by the rules. He'd taken a swipe at her face with his claws, which was against the rules of the sanctioned arena matches. You fight with your animal counterparts, you stay away from the face and the vital organs. You go for the limbs. Fists were free reign to hit where you please. Claws had limited ability. There weren't meant to be deaths in arena fights. It happened though, sometimes. Luckily, Vic had only lost her eye. Unluckily, she'd been so pissed she'd torn out the fighter's throat. They'd kicked her out of the Sanction after that. She'd never be allowed to fight in the arena cage matches again.

Which was what brought her to Beijing. A different kind of fight. A different kind of cage. The kind where two walked in, but one walked out. Death Matches. She never thought she'd be one to take part in them, because years ago when she'd agreed to take on these animal genes, she thought that it was brutal and immoral and wrong in every sense of the word. But after the genes, after the arenas, and after seeing what Shifters did and were capable of doing if they weren't reigned in, she'd given in to the temptation. And what was worse than giving in, she found she enjoyed it. She found she was good at it - taking lives that is. She knew it should have scared her, this strange bloodlust, but it didn't. She didn't know the people she killed in the matches and they had signed up to die, basically. She felt little remorse.

Turning her attention to the young man sitting across from her, she forced a smile at his expense. Death matches had an odd following. It was an underground organization that attracted criminals and adrenaline junkies alike. The matches also brought in the high roller gamblers. What better sport to bet on than death? As such, fighters who signed up to be in these matches were assigned a "keeper" for the few days before the match, to ensure no one got cold feet and backed out. It only happened a handful of times, where people wanted to call it quits before the match. But when it did, the Keepers were there to ensure they either died fighting or died running. Either way, Vic wasn't going to run. The match tomorrow would be easy, she was sure. And her Keeper was apparently giving her a pep talk because of it.

"Kick ass?" She asked, grinning at him. "I intend to make it quick," she said, serious. She hated drawing out death matches. Although it made the crowd go wild when there was showmanship involved, Vic did not play along. She didn't draw out someones death longer than it had to be. Maybe that's why the small underground following seemed to like seeing her. They knew she didn't do it for show. She did it for blood. Plus, it paid well.

The Keeper, his name was Sung, grinned wider. He was a mild-mannered kid, but he was also a Tiger Shifter and she had no doubt he'd put up a damn good fight. Otherwise he'd never of been picked to be a Keeper. "I know, but you'll still kick ass. That other guy is going down. Have you seen him yet?"

Vic shook her head. "No, I don't like making friends with my opponents before I kill them," she said dryly.

Sung shook his head. "You're in for a shock then. The guy is huge. Like a freaking bull!"

"Is that his Shifter?"

"No, I don't know what it is," Sung answered. He looked around and then leaned in closer. "But the bigger they are, the harder they fall." He winked at her and Vic resisted the urge to roll her eye at him. She looked around the small diner, studying the patrons. It was the night before a fight and even though she was confident in her own abilities, she knew there was a chance that tonight would be the last night she was alive. It happened before every fight. She called it her own special jitters, because it wasn't nerves or anxiety, it was just - peace. Being at peace with the possibility of death. If she lived, great. If she died, that was okay too. She'd said her goodbyes. She'd cleaned up her messes. She'd left her life and her organization behind. She'd left him.

Vic looked up as a waitress brought their food over. She'd always liked the local food. Something about being less processed, more raw, always attracted her wolf-senses. She'd ordered fish. It was placed in front of her with head and scales still attached. If she looked hard enough, she thought she could even see the damn tail squirm. it made her want to dig in.

Sung snorted as he grabbed his dumplings and looked over at her. "That could be your last supper, you know," he joked humorlessly.

She glared at him through her one good eye, then dug in.

111.content:
“Are you sure about this?” he asked.

The man pushed his glasses up his nose with one finger, gazing at her from across the desk. He had an expression of sympathy on his face and she almost wanted to believe it if she didn’t know he probably did this every day. It was his job to process the final paperwork. He was the one who would take her life and file it away in his computer and the metal cabinets behind him and she would become a number in their system. She was going to be just another cog in the machine.

She hated this feeling. She hated feeling trapped. She wanted to spit at him, to tell him to go to Hell, to tell them all to go to hell. She hated that she was more afraid than she’d been in her whole damn life because she was looking at death either way. She either gave her life to them, or she gave it back to the system.

Life in prison, that’s what she was looking at.

She’d thought she was doing the right thing. She still did.

She looked down at her hands in her lap and they were handcuffed together, metal edges just touching the sleeves of her orange jumpsuit. They could erase all of this with the click of a button and all she had to do was sign that little scrap of paper in front of her. Words jumped out at her, words like “liability” and “experimental procedures” and other bullshit that basically meant once she signed it she was theirs until the end of the contract.

“Yes,” she said. “I’m sure.”

***


The crowds were the worst thing about Death Matches.

Victoria fucking hated the crowds. All those people gathered together in one place to watch two people try and kill each other and they called that entertainment. She couldn’t complain too loudly because they put money in her pocket every time she walked out alive, but at the end of the day they were the worst thing about her job. They got off on watching the world’s most popular and legal snuff film because they were fucking cowards who would never step in the ring themselves.

She hated them because they were weak, and Victoria had based her entire life on being strong. She had to be strong at all times because it kept her heart beating and her lungs breathing. It was what kept her surviving from one day to the next when she should have been dead years ago.

Had she always been this way? She couldn’t remember anymore.

There was a girl once, a girl named Victoria Boston, but they had buried her name deep in the records and forgotten she had existed because that girl was supposed to be in prison right now. Victoria Wolfe had been born from the ashes of that girl’s life and the gene therapy that had turned her into an animal. She didn’t have to worry about what her parents would think because they’d been nothing but dust blowing in the wind before she’d turned ten.

Victoria didn’t have anyone to worry about, not anymore.

“And in this corner,” the announcer was saying, “weighing in at one hundred and thirty-seven pounds, we have the Wolf!” A second announcer was rattling off the information in rapid Chinese. When they were done a cheer broke out over the audience and she knew she was supposed to wave or bow, but she just didn’t have it in her. She stretched her hands over her head and then bent to touch her toes. Her back snapped and settled into place and she felt a little more loosened up.

She still felt numb and peaceful, even with the crowd cheering around her. They were a sea of faces and at the end of the day they wouldn’t matter, just like she wouldn’t to them. Maybe they would win some money on her winning, or maybe they would lose it when the clean up crew came and rolled her body onto a gurney. It didn’t matter.

All that mattered was life and death, strength and weakness.

All that mattered was the fight.

It was the only thing that made her feel alive anymore. When she’d signed that contract and signed her life over to the Big Bosses, she had never expected that she would actually enjoy the work she was doing. She hadn’t expected that she would enjoy being the wolf, or that she would find a family in their ranks. She hadn’t gotten close to anyone in her life because that was the way she was, constantly pushing people away from her with words or fists. People were attachments and love and friendship or hatred and loathing and all those emotions jut ended up tying her to them.

She didn’t want to care about anyone but herself. Luckily in the arena she didn’t have to.

She heard the drums and glanced up as they let her opponent into the ring. A hiss escaped her throat and couldn’t stop the word that tumbled out unbidden from her lips.

“Bullshit.”

112.content:
She always had the same dream the night before a match.

She didn’t know why it was this dream, and not something encouraging like the first time she’d killed someone or the night she’d lost her eye. If she had to pick she would have done a rerun of last year’s fight where she gutted a spider shifter on the concrete because she really didn’t like spiders and it made her more inclined to want to taste blood in the morning. It didn’t matter what she wanted, the dream was always the same.

She was sitting on the floor and her head was buried in her hands. In the dream she’s crying and she can’t remember why anymore but it had something to do with her last fight. She hadn’t killed anyone, it was years before that started, but she’d wanted to and she hadn’t gotten used to that feeling yet.

She didn’t hear him come in the room. She didn’t know he was there until she felt his hand brush hers.

Victoria jerked in surprise, trying to wipe away the tears as quickly as she could.

Simon stopped her, catching her hands in his. He used the edge of his shirt to wipe them off her face and she stared at the floor so she didn’t have to look at his face. She felt so stupid and she pulled her knees up to her chin so that she could hide behind them. He laughed a little at her and she let him get away with it because if she opened her mouth she’d probably just say something nasty that she didn’t mean.

That and there was the lump in her throat from crying and she felt weak and tired and honestly she liked that he was there. Not that she’d tell him that.

“You okay, Vic?”

“Fuck you,” she told him.

He laughed. “I’ll take that as a no.” He puffed air out of his lips to try and get the hair out of his eyes, and she realized he was still holding her hands. His thumbs were rubbing in small, smoothing circles on her skin and she glanced at his expression. He had his concentration face on, staring at her hands, studying the scars. He was probably one of the few people on the planet that knew where every one of them came from.

Then he looked up at her and she thought how unfair it was that he had such beautiful green eyes. “You gonna tell me what’s wrong?” he asked.

Her teeth worried at her bottom lip and the words came out in a quiet whisper.

“Do you think I’m a monster, Simon?”

He started to laugh and then he realized she wasn’t joking. His face turned thoughtful and then the lines of concern formed between his eyes and then he broke her by brushing her cheek with one hand. He cupped her face in his palm and it was rough against her skin. “No,” he told her. “Never.”

Her eyes slid open at 2am to the sound of her phone ringing. She stretched across the mattress and grabbed weakly at it, both disappointed and relieved that she’d missed the rest of her dream. She didn’t need to be reminded of what she’d left behind because she had left him for a reason. She didn’t want to be thinking about Simon fucking Welsh because she wasn’t that girl anymore and hadn’t been for a long time.

“Oh fuck you phone,” she growled as her fingers knocked it clumsily to the ground and now she was half crawling on the floor and wondering who the fuck was calling her this early anyway.

“Hello,” she snarled into the receiver.

“Victoria?” a familiar voice asked.

She blinked in surprise and fell the rest of the way out of her bed. “Jezibel? What’s wrong?”

She heard a quiet, demure laugh on the other end. “You always did cut right to the chase.” Then the laugh faded and there was a quiet, pregnant pause coming over the line. Victoria was just about to reach through the line and throttle the girl when she finally asked “Are you sitting down?”

“Yeah, Jesus Jez, just spit it out. It’s 2 o’clock in the fucking morning over here.”

“Simon’s in the hospital.”

It was like someone had dumped a bucket of ice water over her head. Her skin when cold and numb and she suddenly couldn’t breathe. She felt like someone was sitting on her chest and she was going dizzy picturing a million possibilities over and over and she didn’t want to ask if it was serious because Jezibel of all people, a girl she hadn’t talked to in years, wouldn’t have called her if it wasn’t. She wanted to ask if he was okay but her lips wouldn’t move.

“Victoria? You still there?”

She closed her eyes and bit her lip so hard it bled but the metallic taste in her mouth helped snap her out of it. “Yeah,” she finally managed. “How bad?”

The silence was really all the answer she needed and her imagination filled in all the blanks.

“He, ah, he hasn’t woken up yet.”

“I see,” she said. Her fingers were cold and she couldn’t feel the phone in her hand anymore. She knew what she should’ve asked. She should’ve asked how his vitals were and if Alexey had been called yet and whether they thought he would wake up. She wanted to ask who the fuck was responsible for it and whether they were still living and breathing because if they were she had to fix that immediately. Instead she took a breath and tried to tell herself it wasn’t her problem anymore.

“I have a fight tomorrow. I can’t come back to the states right now.”

“Vic,” Jezibel said quietly. “It’s Simon.”

“I know,” she breathed. She pressed her forehead into her knees and tried to tell herself she didn’t care. “I just can’t,” she said, more harshly than she meant to. Then she flipped the phone shut and let it slip from her nerveless fingers to the ground. “I can’t,” she told herself, and no matter how many times she said it, she still didn’t believe it.

1121.content:
She was pinned and bleeding.

The merc had gotten the drop on her and to this day she didn't know how the fuck he'd been able to. Maybe she'd been distracted. Maybe he was just that good. She wouldn't know and wouldn't find out. Either way, he had her pinned with a gun to the back of her head and he was getting ready to pull the trigger.

"Die, bitch," he'd said to her.

Maybe she cried out then, because she couldn't stop the bullet in time and she knew it.

Then Simon was there. And she didn't have to.

There was a flash of black fur and white teeth and bloody jowls as he ripped into the merc on top of her. He hadn't held back. He slashed and clawed and chewed and tasted and bathed in the blood. He'd made sure the merc was dead, and then he doubly checked by ripping limbs apart and throats out and heads open.

And all Vic could do was sit up, holding her bleeding side and watch. Because it was his first kill and it was the bloodiest fucking thing she'd ever seen.

Simon turned and shifted back to the man she knew - but covered in blood and flesh. He rushed to her side, maybe he wasn't aware of what he'd just done. Or maybe he didn't care. A hand came to cup her cheek gently as he inspected her for other wounds.

"Vic? You alright?" he asked softly.

She stared at him. "Gee, Simon," she said, cursing mentally when her voice shook. "Why don't you hold back next time?"

He grinned. And it was so Simon that she grinned too.

"Only I get to call you a bitch."


***



She sat crying on the floor in her underwear and tanktop. The phone lay a few inches from her, mocking and driving her depressive thoughts. She should call back. She should call Jez and ask all of the million questions that were racing through her mind and keeping her from going back to sleep and preparing for tomorrow's fight. Was he okay? How bad was it? What happened? Who did she have to kill? The last part seemed to run through her mind more than the others. Whose fault was this? They were going to pay. She'd make sure they paid.

He'd always been there for her. Always. There to pull her back from despair and hurt and death and everything else that had ever threatened to consumer her. He'd given up a lot for her. The more she looked back on it, the more she realized just how much he sacrificed to keep her happy, to keep her alive, to just fucking be with her. And what had she done? She'd up and left and hadn't looked back. And now he needed her.

And she needed him. More than ever.

Determined, she picked up the phone. The operator connected her to the last number called and Jez picked it up on the second ring.

"Vic." Her voice was small and meager.

"Where are you?" Vic asked, surprised that she managed to keep the tears from her voice. She reached up and wiped the remaining evidence from her face, listening for Jez's answer.

The owl shifter on the other end was quiet a moment, but Vic could hear background noises and Jez's heavy heels clicking on tiled floor. She was walking, to get privacy most likely. "Mercy Hospital," Jez said quietly, and then seemed to find her privacy as her voice rose. "In New York. There's a flight that leaves from Beijing in two hours. I already booked you a ticket."

Vic let out a small chuckle at that. She couldn't help herself. The girl was on top of things and she somehow knew her team, even after years of separation, better than anyone. Vic reached a hand up to pinch the bridge of her nose. "What happened?"

"We'll talk when you get her, Vic," Jez said, her voice small again.

Nodding, though the other girl couldn't see her, she looked around the room. "It's going to be complicated."

"Complicated how?"

"I have a match tomorrow. When I don't show, they'll send people to kill me."

Jez scoffed. "Kill them back!" she said.

The smile that reached Vic's face was genuine and whole hearted and it had been so long since she'd had one like that. They'd been a team once, all of them. And she was remembering just what she left behind. Jez's happy and naive attitude. Alexey's cockiness. Lyle's worm tongue. Simon. Her mind picture him in a hospital bed and it was all she could do to keep from crying again. She wouldn't cry. Not anymore over this. She had work to do.

"I'll call when I land," she said into the phone and then hung up before the girl could get a chance to reply.

Standing, her eyes went around the room. She quickly packed a light duffle bag. She pulled on a pair of jeans and shirt. Heading to the closet, she threw it open and rifled through the clothes hanging there, stopping when she found what she was looking for in the back. One of Simon's shirts. She'd accidentally taken it with her when she left. Running a hand over the fabric for a moment, she leaned into it and took a deep breath. It still smelled like him.

Quickly pulling the shirt off the rack, she stuffed it carefully into the duffle bag and then slung it over her shoulder. She walked quietly to her bedroom door and peeked out. Sung was on the couch in her living room. His feet propped up on her coffee table. The apartment was small and she'd decorated it to fit American culture more than Chinese culture. In the apartments around her, families of ten to twenty people lived in the same space she herself occupied. She tried to not to feel guilty when she still found it to be small for her taste.

Sung was asleep. He was Shifted and orange and black striped fur ran the length of his body. His sense were more alert when he had cat ears listening to everything. She was somewhat surprised that he hadn't woken up as she'd packed up her things. But she counted it as a blessing.

Walking as lightly as she could across the hardwood floor, she made her way to the front door, her eyes never leaving the sleeping Shifter. He stirred once, and she froze, holding her breath. When he settled, she smiled somewhat and opened the front door. It was louder than she hoped and she thought for sure he'd wake. By some grace of god, he didn't and she slipped out, half jogging the rest of the way to the staircase. She took them four at a time and reached the bottom of the building faster than she ever had.

"Be seeing you soon, Sung," she whispered to the building as she ran up the sidewalk to where her car was parked at a garage. She knew that when he woke up to find her gone, he'd report it to the Death Match organizers. They'd send people after her. Probably Sung himself. And the high rollers would send people. She'd be running for a good long time, if not the rest of her life.

But that didn't matter.

Because all she could think about now was Simon. And he'd better wake the fuck up before she got there.

11212.content:
The flight was long and ridiculous. Vic thought more than a couple times about pulling open the emergency door and flying there herself. Nevermind the fact that wolves weren't airborne animals, she'd will herself to sprout fucking wings and flap her damn way to Simon's side way faster than this hunk of junk airplane was going, she was sure. Lucky for her, and the 300 other passengers who shared her flight, she managed to restrain herself.

Her mind wandered for the thirteen hours it took to get to the States. She dozed on and off, but could never truly fall asleep. Each time she did, she'd wake with a jolt and Simon's name on her lips. She tried listening to music or reading a book or watching the in-flight movies, but she couldn't focus. She couldn't pay attention. The names, the words, the actors - they all looked the same and they all reminded her of him in some way or another.

The sad thing was, she hadn't realized how much she missed him.

Two years ago when she'd walked out, yeah it hurt. But she'd gotten over it. Any time something reminded her of him, it didn't hurt as badly as she was hurt right now, because in her mind, she'd been done with him. She'd never see him again. He was a person from her past, a memory in her mind, a name in her history. She tried to convince herself that she wanted it that way. In reality, she had always wanted to run back to him and there wasn't a day she'd felt otherwise.

When the plane landed, she'd shoved her way out of the cluster fuck of unloading the plane and had gone straight out to try and find a taxi. She shouldn't have been surprised to find Jez waiting for her in the lobby, but she was. And a little pissed. If Jez was here, who was with Simon? What if he woke up? Dread flashed through her as she thought of reasons why the girl had abandoned his side.

"Jez?" Vic asked as she came up to the blonde. Jezibel had gotten a hair cut since last she'd seen her. And it looked like a boob job too. She was still beautiful and sexy without taking on the skanky slutty look like most girls with her beauty did. Her icy blonde hair was pulled back into a bun and she wore her typical white outfit. Her leather heels were six inches high, but you'd never notice as the girl stood only about 5'1. It made her look normal height.

Jezibel smiled at her. "Vic," she enveloped her in a hug and Vic tried to remain calm, waiting for the girl to explain why she was here, why she didn't just let her catch a cab. When Jez pulled back, she frowned a little. "Oh, honey, we're gonna have to get you a better eyepatch. Maybe one with a diamond in it. You'd look fabulous with that!"

"Simon?" Vic choked out, appreciating the attempt at familiarity, but not wanting it. She wanted to know how he was doing.

The smile faded from Jez's crimson lips and she wrapped an arm around Vic's as the smaller girl led her towards the parking lot where her flashy car was waiting. Vic would have to remember later to ask how Jezibel had come to have so much money for all the flashy things she had. It made her envy the girl a little, to know she was doing so well for herself.

Jez sighed. "Let's just get to the hospital."

11213.content:
An electronic voice was coming over the PA system and Vic sat back on her hard plastic chair, arms crossed over her chest. Her body portrayed boredom and irritation, but her eyes were constantly moving, scanning the airport. The flight was delayed and she had somehow convinced herself that Sung would be awake and looking for her now. There would be Keepers swarming the airport soon. She was convinced.

They'd come for her and they'd kill her. They wouldn't stop until she was dead. The Keepers would think it an honor tracking her down because she was a regular in the Death Matches. They all watched her fight, watched her win, and watched her kill. She only hoped that she'd survive long enough to help Simon. And that thought alone was what kept her from racing back to fight in her match. She couldn't guarantee she'd live through the match. She couldn't take the chance that she would be killed before seeing him again. It also meant that when she got to Simon, she couldn't get close again. Because now, she couldn't stay with him even if she wanted to. They'd come for her. She would die. And she'd be damned if she got Simon hurt, physically or emotionally, in the process.

Her phone going off in her pocket made her nearly jump out of her seat. She pulled it from her pocket and looked at the caller ID. She frowned a little at the unusual phone number. She didn't recognize it. Against her better judgement, she flipped the phone open. She didn't say anything, however, because she didnt' know if it was a Keeper or an Organizer on the other end of the line. She didn't expect the voice that came through.

"What, are you pulling the heavy breather on me, Vic?" It was Alexey, pure and sweet. She felt tears sting at her eyes in relief at hearing his voice after all this time. He was joking, which was so much more welcoming than the greeting she thought she'd get out of the Fox Shifter. She reached up to wipe the tears from her eyes.

"Alexey," she choked out.

He must have caught on to her saddened tone. "So I guess you heard."

"Jez called me," she said quietly, standing up and grabbing her backpack. She hefted it over a shoulder and decided to take a walk through the airport while she spoke to him. She didn't want to sit still anymore. She kept seeing Keepers in all the different faces passing her by. "She said he was in the hospital. What happened, Lex?"

He sighed and she could hear the exhaustion in his voice. "He got cut during a match." Vic frowned, but let Alexey continue. "Nothing big, nothing he hasn't had before, you know? He won the match and then afterwards they were trying to stitch him up, but he just kept fucking bleeding and he was bruised everywhere." She heard Alexey give an angry growl.

"It's the fucking cancer, Vic. It's back."

That stopped her dead in her tracks. A tourist walking behind her nearly collided with her. He cussed at her in a foreign language and wheeled his giant suitcase around her. She glared at him with her one eye and headed towards the wall. She lowered her voice, like they were talking about something taboo. Simon had never liked talking about being sick. The cancer had nearly killed him. Then the geneticists had given him panther DNA and he'd been cured. He'd owed the government his life, after that.

"What?" she asked, clutching her phone tightly in her hand.

"He has fucking cancer and he nearly bled to death because his blood wasn't clotting. I don't know the medical reason behind it all, I'm not a fucking cancer expert." Alexey was yelling and she had to resist the urge to tell him that she never said he was a cancer expert, or even asked about the blood clotting. When Alexey yelled, he usually did it because he was scared, not angry. When he was angry, he got quiet.

Vic ran a hand through her hair, looking around the airport before responding. "Can't they do something? Can't they just replace more genes or..." she trailed off. She'd never really been an expert on the science behind their process either.

"That's just it, Vic," Alexey's voice got soft and she could almost picture the Fox Shifter sagging his shoulders in defeat. "They can, but Simon won't let them."

"Why the fuck not?" she demanded.

"Because his fucking contract was up last week."

She took a deep breath, her mind reeling over that piece of information. When Simon first had his genes spliced, he'd signed away years of his life to serve whatever purpose the company wanted. When the contract was up, he was a free man. He'd served a few years as a mercenary, then had movie on to be a prize fighter. Now his contract was up, and in the first week, he had life threatening cancer again.

"How convenient," she voiced her thoughts without realizing it. Alexey must have been thinking the same thing.

"That's what I said. Vic, god dammit. Those fuckers did this on purpose." Vic closed her eyes. Yeah, her and Alexey were definitely on the same wave length. "Look, those scientists pick out specific gene codes and sequences. They know what they're putting into you top to fucking bottom. There's no way they wouldn't have seen this coming. They just wanted him to fucking sign up again, those god damn bastards." Alexey was raging now and Vic let him. She felt like punching her fist through the wall too.

"And he's not going to sign up again." She didn't have to ask.

"No, he's a dumbass. He thinks he'd rather die than work for the company again. Asshole."

Vic chuckled and she heard Alexey give a tired chuckle on the other end of the line. If there was one thing the both of them could agree on, it was how stubborn Simon was. She sighed into the phone.

"I'm at the airport," she said and she heard Alexey stay quiet, like he was afraid to ask where she was going or coming because he didn't want to scare her off. "My flight's delayed, but I'll be there late tonight. Come pick me up."

"From Beijing?"

"Yeah," she said. "We'll convince that stupid brother of yours that he'll sign the contract and then we'll come up wtih a way to pay those fuckers back."

Alexey laughed and Vic grinned herself.

"I missed you, Bitchzilla."
11213.title: Vic gets another phone call...

1122.content:
Victoria leaned over the sink and pulled the eye patch from her face.

A nasty lump of scar stared back at her and she didn’t even have the dead eye left in her face. She still remembered the pain of it, the pain of claws searing through her skin and the burning agony of having one of her eyes practically torn out of her head. She’d gone insane with it, the wolf taking over completely in rage and anguish. She remembered the rest of the fight through a haze of red and she remembered what happened after it even less.

She’d been taken to the hospital at some point and she remembered Jezibel calling her there too. How the girl managed to keep tabs on all of them she didn’t ask, but she was probably still in touch with the Big Bosses and they knew where every one of their investments had run off to, no matter how far they ran.

She remembered Simon calling, and he’d barely gotten her name out before she’d hung up on him.

Her arms were shaking she was gripping the sink so hard.

She didn’t like to admit to herself how tempting it would have been to ditch the fight and fly back to the States six hours ago. The quickest flight she booked would still take over thirteen hours and she didn’t know what kind of condition Simon was in because she hadn’t asked. She could have called Jezibel back and gotten all the details from her, but that would have been admitting something to herself that she wasn’t ready to.

She couldn’t say she was just asking as a friend because he hadn’t been just that to her for a long time.

She jumped when Sung knocked on the door. “Victoria? You ready?”

Her one good eye focused on the face looking back at her and it looked cold and hollow to her. The peace she normally felt was gone and shattered in one phone call. How could she go into this fight while constantly wondering in the back of her mind if Simon was flat-lining? How could she die without knowing if he was okay?

“Fuck,” she snarled, and punched her reflection. She kicked the shattered pieces of glass and yanked the bathroom door open. “I’m ready,” she snapped, and Sung took an involuntary step backwards.

She knew how she looked. She looked like a monster.

She didn’t care.

***


“You know what I wanted to be when I was a kid?”

Simon laughed at her. “I don’t know. A serial killer?”

“Ha ha, very funny asshole,” she said. She mock-glared at him and shoved him away from her. He barely stumbled and caught himself by slinging an arm around her shoulder. She shrugged it off out of habit and turned so that she was walking backwards and could keep an eye on him. “Maybe I won’t tell you after all.”

He was still smiling and he reached out to catch her hand in his. “Aw baby, don’t be like that.”

She couldn’t help the laugh that followed. “Oh fuck you! Don’t think that sweet talk is going to work on me.”

“No?” he asked, and then he stopped, pulling her back towards him. She thought about fighting it and then his other hand caught her around the waist and pulled her against him. “Will this?” he asked. She could feel the smile still on his lips when he kissed her and she couldn’t decide whether to push him away or pull him closer.

“A lion tamer,” she said, her lips still brushing his.

“Hmm?”

She turned her head so he couldn’t kiss her again and she was laughing. “That’s what I wanted to be. When I was a kid I wanted to run away and join the circus. I wanted to tame lions.”

He grinned. “Luck you. You get to live the childhood dream.”

“Shut the fuck up Welsh,” she told him.

Then she made him.

***


Sung was right.

The guy was huge.

He waved his arms at the crowd and they howled for him. She couldn’t remember his name or how many kills he had to it, but it really didn’t matter in the end. In the beginning she’d studied her opponents and she’d sweat when she walked into the ring. Her first Death Match had been a close thing and she had been terrified that she was going to die here on the mats in China, thousands of miles from home.

After a while, she’d stopped being afraid.

At the end of the day, it wasn’t about winning or losing. It was about life and death, about walking that edge between human and animal and seeing who had the stronger will to survive. She’d gotten used to toeing that line and it shouldn’t have been any different this time, except it was and she knew it.

The official stepped into the arena and blew his whistle.

“You know the rules,” he said. “Two enter, one leaves. No holds barred.”

Then he headed back to the sidelines where he could watch. She wondered in the back of her mind who he’d bet on to win and then he blew the whistle and the match began. The man let loose a roar and barreled across the arena at her. She didn’t know if he was trying to scare her or just encourage himself but she side stepped the charge easy and landed a roundhouse kick to his back.

She didn’t want to fuck around today but he when he came up with fists swinging and no sign of claws or fangs she knew he was trying to make a match of it. The crowd cheered when his fist clipped her jaw and it cheered when she landed a knee in his gut. The crowd was a living, breathing thing and they were the heart of it. They didn’t care who was winning as long as blood was flowing and they had something to make the day go faster.

She landed two more kicks to the guy, one in the stomach and the other on the kneecap, before he started getting mad.

A growl escaped his lips as his fangs came out and then he was charging her again. She tried to dodge but they were too close and his arm caught her across the chest and brought them both to the ground. She tried to roll but now claws were digging into her side and trying to hold her in place. She slashed at his face with fresh claws and it forced him to move his arms, but now he was holding both of hers down.

She felt a growl rumble in her own chest and her teeth snapped at the guy’s throat that was just out of reach.

He grinned at her and she snarled back at him.

She tried to heave the guy off her but he weighed too much and she barely moved them off the ground. Another growl escaped his throat and even if he was using all his energy holding her down he could still tire her out that way and then she would be an easy kill. She hated even the thought of it.

Her wolf form ripped through her, enough to rip one arm free and roll out from under the guy. He turned and he was still midway through his change when she hit his chest and sunk her teeth into his throat.

She got a mix of thick hair and flesh when she leapt away.

He was a lion shifter. She would have laughed if she could.

Something that was a mix of a paw and a hand came up to clasp a hand over his throat and while maybe that wouldn’t have been enough to kill him the opening he left her was. She darted in quick under his chest and her teeth sunk into the soft skin of his belly. She ripped at anything she should reach and it was probably too little too late when a heavy paw smacked her to the side. A bestial roar echoed around the arena and then it fell quiet.

He was still alive when she dragged herself over to him. He was going to bleed to death, eventually.

She tried to remind herself she was doing him a favor when she ripped his throat out.

Sung was the first one to clap her on the back when she limped out of the ring. “I said you would kick ass today, didn’t I?” he grinned. “A little quick, but that’s your style, right?”

She didn’t have the energy to smile back at him. She didn’t have the energy for anything except to grab her coat and her bag. She didn’t want to see the medic or her “fans” or the judges and she didn’t care about setting up another fight. Her side was throbbing and her chin felt bruised and this was the part where she was supposed to feel like a survivor, like she was one with the beast and everything was right with the world.

She just wanted to see Simon.

11221.content:
She couldn’t sleep.

The lights were off and the blinds closed and she even had the little pillow tucked under her head but she couldn’t fall asleep. Her flight had been delayed twice and it was turning into a twenty hour trip. It made her wish that she’d left at two o’clock when Jezibel had first called because then she might already be there and wouldn’t be reading the in-case-of-emergency instructions over and over again.

She’d made the mistake of calling Jezibel while she waited for her plane to take off.

“Victoria,” she said, and didn’t even have the decency to pretend to be surprised that she was calling. “How are you?”

“Alright,” Vic sighed. “I’m at the goddamn airport. Now tell me what happened.”

She knew Jezibel was smiling because she could be a smug little bitch sometimes. Most people never saw that side of her, but they’d been closer than family once and they knew how far they could push each other. She was also an idealist who thought there was a happy ending at the end of the rainbow or some shit and she didn’t understand that sometimes things couldn’t be fixed.

“Someone assaulted him on his way home from the bar last night.”

“Who?”

“We don’t know yet, Vic.”

“What do you mean you don’t know?” She was snarling into the phone now and she had started to pace in front of the bench. “How the fuck do you not know? Aren’t you still in with the Big Bosses and all? Don’t they know who attacked one of their own? Jesus, what fucking good are they?”

“Stop yelling at me Vic,” she said. “I’ll tell you what I can, but there’s not a lot to go on yet. We won’t know more until he wakes up and even then it might not be any help.”

She didn’t calm down, but she did manage to sit back down because her legs felt wobbly. “He still hasn’t woken up?” she asked. She was proud of how steady her voice came out because her hands were shaking. How long had he been out and how hard did someone have to hit him to knock Simon out?

“Not yet,” she said. “But I’m sure he will.”

Vic hated false optimism. “I gotta go, my flight’s here,” she said, and then hung up without saying goodbye. She hated goodbyes too.

The plane rumbled as they flew through a cloud. She sighed and tried to listen to some of the music they had on these things but none of it slowed her thoughts. She picked at her nails and there was still blood caked under them and she wondered what Simon would say if he knew she was fighting in Death Matches. She wondered what he would say when he saw the mess that was left of her eye, and if he would still think she was pretty.

She tipped her head back against the seat and took a deep breath. It was almost funny. Two years ago she’d though she couldn’t get far enough away. She’d gone to Ireland and she still felt too close after that call to her hospital bed, so she’d moved to Russia and that was too close to Alexey, so she’d finally settled on China and she’d though she was far enough away from him.

Turns out she was, and now she was damning herself for it.

112211.content:
Before a fight she always felt this weird sort of calm like whatever happened next was going to be okay, whether it was good or bad. If she died and ended up being scraped into a black bag after the match, it didn’t matter because she’d come to terms with the important bits. If she lived, then she would go on to fight another day and send someone else back to their families in a body bag. It was nature and she had peace with it.

That feeling started during the last two hours of her flight. It stayed with her through customs and calling the taxi cab. She was fine on the ride to the hospital and even standing outside it, watching the spectacle going on there, she still felt strangely calm about the whole thing.

A crowd of teenagers, mostly girls, were gathered outside the hospital.

They were carrying homemade signs reading “Get well soon Simon!” and “You can do it Big Cat!” She didn’t know whether to laugh or gag and she wondered what had happened in the two years she’d been gone. It still didn’t shake her, even the goddamn newscaster that stood outside and did a report on his condition only managed to piss her off a little bit. She was fine all the way up the elevator and to the end of the hallway.

The second she set foot in his room it came crashing down around her head.

He lay in the center of a white bed; an IV drip hooked up to one arm and wires running all over the place to keep track of his heart rate and blood pressure. He looked like he’d been put through a meat grinder, dark bruises all over his face and arms. He had stitches holding his eyebrow together and his lip was split and bleeding. His left arm was bound, but not in a cast, so at least it looked like nothing was broken.

She took a deep breath and looked away because she wasn’t ready to cry.

There were two giant vases of flowers set up by the window and a little parade of teddy bears keeping him company. Someone had started setting up all the cards and get well posters he’d received on a table in the corner, and none of them said anything she hadn’t seen on the signs outside. She flipped through them, not really reading any, but she did pause on one from his mother and she couldn’t stop the sneer that pulled at her lips. “To my dear boy, wishing you a speedy recovery.”

“My dear boy” her ass. His mother had always been a bitch.

She sighed and turned back around to face the bed.

She hated seeing him like this, all weak and fragile and breakable. She hated that they didn’t know if he’d wake up or who she had to fucking kill for doing this or how they’d managed it in the first place. She held back the tears and walked over to the bed, fingers brushing the hair out of his eyes. She kept waiting for him to open them and tell her that she looked like someone had run over her dog or something equally as stupid.

She realized she was terrified.

She was terrified that he wouldn’t wake up.

She crawled into the bed next to him and laid her head on his chest. She could hear his heart beating slowly against her cheek and she closed her eyes, holding on to the sound. “Please be okay,” she whispered. Her fingers tangled in the hospital gown and she pulled herself closer to him, twining around his form. There were tears slipping down her face and if he were awake she would never hear the end of it because Vic hadn’t cried since that first night he’d kissed her.

She let her eyes closed and her tears dry up and she just focused on the steady sound of his heartbeat and the low breaths that still passed through his lungs. She tried not to look at the split lip or the stitched up gouge running from his forehead over his temple. Those things would heal. Simon would heal.

He had to.

She wasn’t sure when she fell asleep, but she woke up when she felt him shift under her cheek. She went to move but his arm came up around her waist and held her there. She watched as his other hand came up to cover hers and his fingers played over her skin in a way that was all too familiar. “Hey Simon,” she said after a while.

“Vic,” he whispered back, and his voice was harsh and ragged and didn't sound like him. A cough shook his body and his hand clenched around hers. She squeezed reflexively back and crushed her eyes shut until the fit passed.

She was crying again, and she didn’t want to be. “You’re an asshole,” she said quietly and she couldn’t put any force behind it.

A chuckle rumbled through his chest. “I missed you too.”

1122111.content:
A strange sort of silence fell over the room. There was so much to say and neither of them knew where to start, so it hung over both of them in a way that was familiar and awkward at the same time. Victoria wondered if she should apologize for leaving but she didn’t know if she was sorry yet, and saying it implied that she wished she’d never left. Whether it was true or not didn’t matter, saying it would change things in a way she didn’t know if she could face.

Another cough shook him and it forced her to look up at his face. His eyes were shut as it wracked his body and his lip split open and started bleeding again. She used the edge of her sleeve to wipe it off his chin. When it stopped he looked at her and for a second his e yes went wide.

His hand brushed her hair out of her face and she realized he was staring at the eye patch.

She glanced down at the bed so she didn’t have to see his expression but she didn’t stop him when he slid it off her head and then his fingers brushed over the scars. “This is from Dublin?” he asked, even though he already knew the answer. She almost told him that but instead bit her lip and nodded. He smirked, but it wasn’t a cruel thing. “Looks like it hurt.”

She shrugged. “I’ve been hurt worse.”

Okay, so maybe that was a lie. But he laughed anyway. “That’s my fearless girl.”

She wanted to tell him she wasn’t his girl anymore, but that would have been a lie too. She wondered if she’d ever stopped and she let her hand come up to trace the lines on his face. He winced when her fingers brushed over the black stitches, but he didn’t stop her. “What happened?” She demanded, changing the subject. “Who the fuck did this to you?”

He laughed and coughed, hand reaching up to catch hers again. “Why, so you can hunt them down?”

“Yes,” she said without hesitation.

He just shrugged. “Some assholes caught me unprepared. I was drunk if that counts for anything.”

She growled, her eyes narrowing. “Somebody puts you in the hospital for two days and all you can do is shrug? What aren’t you telling me, Welsh?”

“Why did you leave?” he asked abruptly, ignoring her question. The laughter was gone from his voice and he just sounded sad now. She tried to sit up and tried to pull her hand back but he laced his fingers with hers so that she couldn’t run away. “I thought you’d come back, but you were just… gone.”

Her breath caught in her throat and she swallowed it down. “If you don’t tell me,” she said coldly. “Then I can’t kill them.”

“Victoria…” he began, and she pulled her hand roughly from his because she didn’t want to talk about it and if she stayed there she might even tell him the truth. She stumbled climbing out of the bed, but he let her go. He struggled to sit up and she could feel his green eyes staring at her as she turned her back on him. A heavy sigh escaped his lips and she wondered if she was pissing him off. “I’m not going to tell you until you talk to me,” he said quietly.

“Are you serious? You’re lying in a hospital bed and you want to talk about our relationship?” she asked and now she was digging through the cards just so her hands had something to do. “We’re thinking of you!” and “Get well soon” flashed before her and she realized there were tears stinging at her eyes again so she tossed them into a pile on the table. “It was time to go, so I left. I told you at the beginning not to read anything into it,” and the words came out cruel and harsh.

“Jesus Vic, I’m trying not to but I can’t for the life of me figure out what it was to you to begin with,” and he just sounded tired.

“What the hell is that supposed to mean?”

Why couldn’t she stop being a bitch?

He shook his head at her, running one hand through his hair and he winced when his fingers brushed the gash on his face. His face just looked so goddamn sad. Her mouth wouldn’t open to apologize even though her brain was saying the words over and over again. She was sorry for leaving, sorry for being a bitch about everything, sorry she couldn’t say sorry. There wasn’t enough time in the day to tell him all the things she was sorry for.

He glanced up at her and he looked exhausted. “What was I to you? Was I your boyfriend, your friend with benefits, was I just a fuck buddy? I’m trying not to read into this but I don’t know where the line is with you. You just up and leave for two years and then you come back and it’s like nothing changed and I don’t even know why you left in the first place.”

She shook her head. “I can’t believe we’re having this fucking conversation right now.”

He smiled a little. “Well, we could have it later but there’s no guarantee you’d stick around for it.”

She threw a teddy bear at him and she didn’t want to smile but she couldn’t help herself when he was giving her that look. It was everything she loved about him. “You’re an asshole.”

He grinned back and caught it before it hit him in the face. “So you’ve said already. You gonna answer me today sometime? Because I can wait, but I figure eventually the nurses are gonna kick you out and then it’ll be another two years before I can ask you again.”

She smiled but she didn’t know what to say to him. “You’re not just a fuck buddy,” she managed.

“Well that’s good to know, at least.” He laughed at her and struggled to sit up. She didn’t miss the wince on his face or the blood that still trickled from his lip and she just wanted to be done with this so that she could fucking kill whoever had hurt him and then leave again. It was too hard to be here and see him like this and not tell him all the things she wanted to say and couldn’t because it was too hard and when it came to Simon she was nothing but a damn coward.

“Let me make this easy for you Victoria,” he said. She didn’t expect the words that came next, at least not coming out of his mouth while she was still awake. “I didn’t want you to leave. I still don’t and if I didn’t hurt so goddamn much then I would think this was a dream I was having. Fuck, come here,” he told her and held a hand out.

She wanted to tell him no. Her feet carried her over to him anyway and she sat on the edge of the bed with his hand in hers.

He was staring at the bed, his thumb rubbing small circles on her skin and it was so familiar it made her chest ache. “I love you,” he whispered to the ground. Then his head rose and he was looking right at her and she couldn’t pretend she hadn’t heard him because it was hard to breathe. Tears pricked her eyes and she dashed them away with the back of her hand. “Hey,” he said. “Come here.” He pulled her back onto the bed with him, hand settling in her hair. “Don’t cry Vic. It kills me when you cry.”

“Don’t,” she told him. She was shaking and she didn’t know what to say because the words were everything she wanted to hear and the one thing she’d been terrified of. How did she justify leaving him now, knowing how he felt?

He laughed. The asshole laughed at her. “Don’t what? Love you? It’s a little late for that, babe.”

“Don’t be nice to me,” she said, and buried her face in his chest.

He laughed, rubbing a comforting hand up and down her back. “Some days I don’t get you at all,” he said, but his voice was calm and almost cheerful. “I tell you I love you and it makes you cry. Not that you’re the only girl who’s ever had that reaction, but I gotta tell you, it’s still a blow to the ego.”

She laughed and sat up, swallowing the last of her pride as she looked into his face. He was staring back at her with those green eyes and they were crinkled at the edges because she’d made him sad and he was trying to pretend she hadn’t. He was still handsome, even with that mask of bruises on his face, and she brought a trembling hand up to his lips. She was tired of lying to herself, tired of running away from him.

“I love you too,” she whispered.

He smiled and then his lips were brushing hers and the kiss was small and soft because she didn’t want to hurt him. It had been two years since they’d seen each other last, but he was right. It was like nothing had changed at all, and she felt her heart pounding in her chest. He pulled away all too soon and they were left staring at each other with the same expression. “What happens now?” he asked after a moment.

This time she was the one that grinned, and it was a wicked, feral thing. “Now you tell me who the fuck put you in a hospital bed so that I can return the favor.”

11221111.content:
Simon's face fell slightly, but he did a good job of trying to hide it. She saw it, though. And he knew that she saw it, so she pretended like she didn't. She reached up to run her fingers lightly down his face, careful of the stitches, careful of the bruising. She lingered a bit on a small cut on his chin, before looking back up into his eyes. He looked tired.

"I don't want you involved, Vic."

His words caught her off guard, because whether he realized it or not, he'd just admitted that this had been more than just a random happenstance. It was more than "some assholes catching him unprepared." Because as much as he loved her and tried to protect her, he wouldn't keep her out of just anything. He wouldn't ask her to stay out of a random hate crime just for the sake of keeping her safe, because he knew what type of fighter she was. He knew that she could kick his ass, even on his good days.

"Too late," she said, leaning to kiss him again to silence whatever words were on his lips. "You can't say you love me, then trick me into saying it too and expect me to not get involved." She grinned at him, but watched his eyes. He let out a low chuckle, but there was worry and anxiety behind it. She brought his hand to her lips and kissed his fingers. "Tell me, Simon. Who did this?"

He stayed quiet, his eyes studying her for a moment. She tried not to let the hurt shine in her eyes because his silence meant he was hiding something, that the trust wasn't there. She didn't blame him. She'd been gone, she'd left. It would take a while to mend what she'd done to him. Even if today they were okay and together again, she knew it would take a while before he didn't panic every time she left his side.

"Fuck, Vic..." he struggled for words. "These guys don't play around."

"Obviously," she said, running her hands to his arm, to his side. She could feel the bandages beneath his hospital gown. She imagined the bruises on his chest. She needed to go kill someone, soon.

Simon looked away and she could see him swallow thickly. His hand gripped hers and he coughed. It was raspy and violent and she laid a hand on his chest to tell him she was still there. When he opened his eyes, he didn't look at her. He spoke quietly and he spoke brokenly. She'd only heard him talk like this a few times before. When he talked about the cancer that had nearly killed him before he had the panther inserted into his genes. When he talked about his father leaving when he was a kid. When he'd said her name on that phone call while she was in Dublin. She hated this weak voice. This was his defeated voice. And Simon Welsh should never be fucking defeated.

"I was suppose to go down in the third round," he whispered. "I said I'd do it but, fuck, I only said it so they'd leave me the hell alone."

Vic sat up a little, keeping her eyes on his face. She squeeze his hand for encouragement and because he looked lost, he looked like he needed a hug, he looked like he needed her to go make it all go away. "Someone asked you to throw a fight." She didn't ask it, because she was starting to put the pieces together even before he explained it entirely.

He nodded and it looked painful. "I don't throw fights, Vic, you know I don't."

She leaned forward and ran a hand over his head again because he was getting upset and she hated when he got upset. "I know," she told him and she did know. Simon wasn't a fighter for the money or the fame or the violence, even though he received plenty of all of them. He was a fighter because he didn't have a choice. He followed contracts because the contracts had saved his life when he'd been dying. He did what he was told and along the way, he'd become honest. He'd become loyal. He'd become a fucking model citizen in a world of crime and hate. She loved that about him. She always had. "I know," she repeated when it looked like he didn't want to tell her anything else.

"They were so fucking persistent. They were every where, damn," he growled and she ran her thumb over his hand, trying to keep him calm but knowing he'd just woken up to a world much different than the one he'd gone to sleep in. He needed to vent, if only just a little. "Every match, in the locker rooms, they even showed up at my apartment, Vic. They just wouldn't go the fuck away so I said I'd do it. I said I'd take a dive."

"And you didn't." Again, not a question.

"I didn't."

"Who are they?"

He laughed but it turned into a cough. She waited for it to pass. She thought she had an idea who they were, but she needed Simon to tell her. She needed to confirm it. There were reasons people asked fighters to throw matches. Most of them involved gambling. In Beijing, the chinese crime lords would convince death match fighters to make martyrs of themselves and die in battle and glory so they could bet on the opponents and win big. They'd make the underdogs win and the one predicted to win the fight would always die. In America, it was the same gist, but no death - most of the time.

"Don Corleone and the entire cast of the fucking Godfather," Simon hissed out, looking pissed off and rightfully so. She chuckled, because he was cute when he was pissed, and she leaned forward to kiss his lips again. It seemed to calm him down.

"So let me get this straight," she said, moving her kisses to his chin, to his cheek, to his neck. She couldn't seem to stop because she was just so fucking happy she could touch and smell and taste him again. His hand came up to run through her hair and she was fairly certain if Simon wasn't in a hospital bed, they would have found their way to another bed soon enough. "You tell the mafia that you're going to throw a fight. You don't. Then you decide to get drunk and walk home alone from a bar?" She pulled back to look at him.

He was grinning and she shook her head. "Good thing you only like me for my charm and good looks."

He reached a hand up to cup the side of her face and she placed her hand over his, keeping it there because, damn, it felt so good to feel him again. "Stay with me."

She kissed him and it was passionate and she felt and tasted his lip bleeding. He winced beneath the kiss but she didn't pull back or hold back. She wanted to prove it to him that she loved him and she'd made a mistake and she wouldn't make it again. When she pulled back, she wiped the blood from his lips and hers and he was looking at her still, looking tired and pleading and hurt.

112211111.content:
The doctors had come in to check up on Simon, now that he was awake. They'd given him two more days in the hospital, to watch for hemorrhaging on the brain, and then he could go home. He'd be sore, dizzy and need lots of rest, but he'd heal completely. Shortly after the doctors left, the police showed up to take a statement. Simon had bullshitted his way through that, and Vic let him get away with it. Because the further away from the truth the cops were, the closer she could get to the actual fuckers who'd put Simon here. A reporter tried to sneak in to see Simon, but security escorted her out rather quickly.

Once everyone was gone, a nurse came in to give Simon morphine. He complained his eyeballs itched, then fell to sleep immediately. Vic watched the nurse blush and grin and eye fuck Simon in his sleep and she couldn't help the jealous rage that almost had her leaping out of her chair next to his bed to throttle the bitch. But then she left and the room was quiet except for the heart monitor they wanted to keep up. They weren't kidding about the brain hemorrhaging thing, and Vic let them take all the extra precautions they needed.

Watching him sleep, she had to remind herself that he was only resting. He wasn't unconscious or in a coma, just resting and if she wanted to, she could reach out and shake him awake. She was tempted to do it several times, but held back. Simon looked so tired, even while he was sleeping, he looked exhausted. She stood up and gently placed a kiss on his forehead, because she couldn't help herself.

"I'll be back," she whispered to him. He actually mumbled something in his sleep that she couldn't quite understand and she gave his hand a squeeze before letting go. He didn't stir again and she laid her coat over the chair so if he woke up while she was gone, he'd at least know she was coming back.

Heading out into the hallway, she walked down the hospital wing and towards the waiting room, where she knew a coffee machine was calling her name. She'd had a long day and she was going to have a longer night because she'd already told the nursing staff that she wasn't leaving. Surprisingly, they agreed to let her stay and even offered for a cot to be brought to Simon's room. She hadn't understood their compliance or hospitality at first, but when the doctor had been in examining Simon, she didn't miss the way the man had referred to him as "Big Cat" on several occasions. It must be nice to have fans. She guessed Simon had already informed the doctors that she would be staying.

The waiting room was remarkably empty. She got a coffee and grabbed a few packets of sugar, dumping them in without hesitation. As she sipped at the sugary, bitter drink, her phone went off. She grabbed it and flipped it open. "Yeah?" she barked into and winced slightly. God she was a bitch when she was tired and cranky.

"Are you with Simon?" It was Jez and Vic sighed, taking a seat in one of the chairs.

"Yeah, I'm at the hospital."

Jez gave a relieved sigh on the other end as Vic took another sip. "Good, stay with him. I think I know who did this to him. I think it was-"

"Let me guess, the mafia."

The Owl Shifter was quiet on the other end of the line and Vic had to supress a chuckle as she tried to picture the smaller girl's face. Jezibel had always prided herself at being the one with information, being the one in the know. She scoffed. "How did you know that?"

"Simon told me."

"He's awake?"

Vic nodded, then realized the girl couldn't see her. "Yeah."

"Jesus, Victoria, have you ever heard of picking up the phone once in a while?

Vic shrugged. "We were busy."

"Wow, that was quick. Was he as good as you remembered?" Vic could almost hear the naughty grin spreading onto the girl's face. She took another sip of her coffee to keep the colorful retort to herself. Jez laughed when she didn't answer right away. "Okay, well tell him I said hello and that he needs to stop lying around. Oh, and keep an eye on him. If it really was the mafia and he cost them money, I doubt they're done yet."

Vic bristled at the words and her eyes involuntarily went to the exterior doors, like she was daring some mobsters to roll up with machine guns and try to start something. She'd rip all their fucking throats out. "They won't touch him again," she said quietly into the phone.

"Just be careful, Vic," Jez said, her voice growing serious. "He can't lose you again."

Pain and guilt struck through her heart and she sat forward in her chair, letting her styrofoam cup dangle from her fingers, the coffee almost gone. "He won't," she said, her voice catching on the lump in her throat.

"Good. I'll stop by in the morning." And with that, the girl hung up.

Vic sat quietly in the waiting room for a moment, her phone in one hand and the coffee cup in another. She closed her eyes, processing it all. She'd thought there might still be a danger to Simon out there, when he'd first said who did it, she'd thought it. It only fueled her anger and hatred towards these people.

Standing, she realized she'd been gone from Simon's side for longer than she wanted to. She finished off her coffee and threw the cup in the trash, then headed back down the hallway to his room. As she entered, she stopped in the doorway, the unexpected visitor in the room stopping her in her tracks.

"Victoria."

1122111111.content:
Vic tensed in the doorway, her eyes on the dark haired man standing over Simon's bed. The man's hand was running over Simon's head, barely touching the same black hair they both shared. Simon remained asleep, either oblivious of the touch or so tired he didn't care. Either way, she was happy he was asleep. She knew this wouldn't be pleasant.

"Alexey," she said in response. The man smiled softly and looked up at her, withdrawing his hand from his brother's head.

"Surprise, surprise," he drawled to her. His voice was different. He'd gotten a slight accent in the two years he'd been apart from them. His face was colder, not the same she remembered on him. "The bitch shows up after Simon's already in the hospital." She bristled at his words. She was right, this wouldn't be pleasant. "Not like if you stuck around, none of this would of happened, or anything."

"Fuck you."

"No, Vic, fuck you," he all but shouted. Simon shifted on the bed, his face turning towards Alexey as he responded to his brother's distress. The Fox Shifter reached out to put a hand on Simon's arm to settle him, but lowered his voice. "You hurt him worse than these pricks ever could," he growls at her. "So if you're back, you're back for good. Otherwise, I want you to leave right fucking now."

Vic sighed, watched the younger man go off. She crossed her arms over her chest, raising an eyebrow. She knew Alexey was pissed at her. He had every right to be. Luckily, she also knew he was much easier to appease than his older brother. "Are you done?" she asked, a small smile quirking the side of her lips.

Alexey was quiet for a moment before his own lips quirked into a smile. "Yeah, I think so. How was it?"

She laughed at that. "Did you practice that speech?"

"A little. I had it much better in my head this morning when Jez called me."

She shook her head. "No, no, you did good. Sounded like you were really mad."

"I was mad," he let the smile fall from his face. "I am mad."

"I know you are." She moved forward into the room, coming to stand on the other side of Simon's bed. She reached out with a hand to brush his hair from his eyes, looking down at him. "I'm not leaving him again, Alexey. I shouldn't have in the first place."

Alexey nodded. "You're damn right, you shouldn't have." He too looked down at his brother. "He was crushed, Vic. I didn't think..." he trailed off a little. "I was scared to let him out of my sight." He looked back up at her, his face a mixture of emotions. She cringed inwardly, trying to hide it from the younger man. How many times would she have to say she was sorry for the whole thing? Sorry she ever left in the first place? She didn't think there would ever be a time when she would say it enough. Even if she said it every fucking day of every fucking week from here on out - it wouldn't be enough. She could only make up for it now. Stay with them, protect them, make sure he was never hurt like that, or this, again.

"I know I hurt him," she whispered quietly, reaching out to touch the bandage wrapped around the length of Simon's right forearm. "I'll make it up to him."

Alexey smiled at her. "If you're here, and you're here to stay, you already have."

"You are so cheesy, Romanova."

He snorted. "And you're full of shit, but I still like ya."

Vic laughed, looking away, her chest becoming tight as she realized it was just like old times again. She looked down at Simon's sleeping face, actually kind of surprised he was still asleep after the argument being had across his bed. It made her more determined. She reached out to touch his face again, her hands drawn to him. She needed to make sure he was still there.

"I'm going to kill them, Lex."

"I know you are," he replied simply. "And I'm going to help you."

"It'll be dangerous."

Alexey snorted. "Vic, did you forget how awesome I am? I live for danger. No, no, I am danger. Danger is my middle name."

"More like dumbass."

"Fuck you."

A low rumbling chuckle from Simon brought both of their attentions to him. He peeked open his eyes and looked between them both. "Would you guys keep it down?" he asked quietly, though there was a smile on his face. "I'm working on my beauty sleep."

Alexey chuckled. "Like that would help, Mr. Potato Head. You look awful."

"Well...whatever," Simon said, groggy from the drugs.

"I'll let that lame insult slip by, since you're concussed and drugged. But tomorrow you'd better come up with a really good one, or I'll laugh at you for getting your ass kicked by goons with the IQ of a ping pong ball." Alexey glanced back to Vic and she smiled between the two of them.

"Whatever," Simon repeated, closing his eyes again. "Just shut up."
