Vic held the apartment door open for Simon as he walked gingerly into the room. She watched him closely, because even the walk from the parking complex to the elevator had worn him out. It would take a while for him to get his full stamina back, but she was certain she could help him with that. He'd only been released from the hospital that afternoon. Alexey had gone of with Jez to try and put a name to the "mobster" behind Simon's attack. Simon swore he didn't know who it was, they'd never told him their names.

As soon as he crossed the threshold into his apartment, Vic closed the door and looked around, first and foremost scanning the place for anyone who wasn't supposed to be there. Simon had told her that the guys who were behind this knew where he leaved and had even showed up here once. She'd been leary about even allowing him to come back here, but he'd insisted they would leave him alone. That they'd gotten their point across. Vic somehow doubted it.

As Simon made a beeline for the fridge, Vic moved into the living room, eyes scanning for danger. She continued down the hallway to Simon's study, the bathroom, then finally to his bedroom. She found the apartment to be empty of anyone meaning to do Simon harm. She relaxed a little and headed back to the kitchen area, stopping in the doorway to eye Simon as he pulled a sports drink from the fridge. He'd always been a health nut. It had drove her crazy sometimes because the stuff he ate and drank, she'd never be able to do it. She smiled as he took a swig of the drink and sighed contently.

"I like what you did with the place," she said from the doorway.

Simon turned to look at her, smiling a bit as he reached out for a bowl he'd left out days ago on the counter. He tipped it towards him and made a face at the eco-system growing inside. Sighing, he turned to dump the dish into the sink and ran the water over it. "Everything reminded me of you after you left," he said, his tone light and not accusing at all, but it still made her wince.

"I'm going to take a shower," she said, to keep herself from apologizing again. Simon would get sick of hearing it. After a while, it would stop meaning anything. She's said it enough. She'd had to start showing her regret to him now, instead of using words.

With a grin spreading across his still bruised face, he turned to look at her. "You want me to join you?"

"Go to bed, Welsh."

"Bed? I just got home!" he called after her as she headed down the hallway towards the bathroom.

"I didn't say you had to go to sleep!" she answered and grinned as she heard him laugh in response.


***



Simons' shower always took a while to heat up, but Vic didn't mind. She kept the water cold and let it run over her. She placed her palms flat on the shower wall and leaned over, closing her eyes as the water ran over her head over her face, dripping off her nose. She breathed through her mouth and simply let her thoughts run. About Simon, about the people who'd put him in the hospital, about Alexey and Jez, about everything. She'd always found wisdom in Simon's shower, always. Being here felt like she was coming home.

The guys who hurt Simon were dead men, of that much she was certain. There was no way she would let them go on living. Not when there was the possibility of them coming back and hurting him again. She would have to take the whole operation out. And if she was going to do that, she'd need firepower. Being a Shifter only went so far when you were up against guns and ammunition. She knew Alexey and Jez would help. She knew Simon would want to. She wasn't sure if she'd let him or not. Not yet. He was still injured and frail and in danger, to her.

She was back at Simon's place and she'd told him she was here to stay, but she wasn't sure if she'd been lying or not. She liked to think she wasn't. She'd even been convinced she wasn't when she'd said it. But now, she wasn't sure. Love was the one thing in the world that terrified her. She wasn't sure she could do it right. She wasn't sure that she wouldn't hurt him again. The longer she stayed, the more damage she'd do if she left, which terrified her and made her want to kill the pricks who hurt him and then get out of dodge. She just wasn't sure if she had it in her to stay. But she could figure that out afterwards. She'd have to.

Vic thought about all the things she'd done while she was gone and all the things she knew Simon had done in her absence. They'd lived two separate lives and that confused her. Because as long as she'd known Simon, even before they'd really known each other, she'd always thought of them as sharing a life. Sharing their memories. But now there was a two year gap. She didn't like it.

Turning the water off, she stood and wiped her hands over her face to clear it of the water. She toweled off and pulled on her underwear and a t-shirt. She'd left clean clothes out in the apartment. As she exited the bathroom, she passed near the bedroom and peeked in. Simon was on the bed. He'd striped down to a t-shirt and a pair of boxers. He hadn't even managed to crawl under the covers before he'd passed out, face down, on the bed. She smiled to herself, watching him for a moment. He really should cover up, at least.

Sighing, she entered the bedroom and walked over to the bed. She crawled up onto it and kneeled next to him, leaning over him as she ran her hands through his hair. She could still feel the swollen bumps that were hidden beneath his black hair. "Simon," she cooed, trying to wake him up enough to get him under the blankets. "Come on, hun," she whispered, seeing him crush his eyes shut before they opened and he was blinking, trying to remember where he was. The doctors said this would be common for a while. He'd sleep heavier and become disoriented upon waking. It would pass within a week. "Under the covers," she said, trying to tug on the comforter to pull it down.

She was surprised when Simon reached out to gently hold her wrist. He rolled over and pulled her with him. She caught herself, still aware of his bruised ribs, and leaned over him, her face near his. He smiled up at her. "Did you use all the hot water?" he asked, moving his head up to kiss her. She kissed him back.

"No," she said around his lips. "Cold shower."

"Oh, babe," he chuckled. "Why'd you go and do that?"

"Needed time to think," she said, moving her kisses across his cheek and to his neck. She moved her legs so she was straddling his waist. He grunted slightly as she jarred his ribs and she smiled apologetically at him.

"About what?" he asked.

She grinned down at him and reached for the hem of his shirt. She pulled it up and off of him, throwing it to the ground. She stopped, however, as she looked back down at him. His chest was a mess. Dark purple and red and blue bruises still littered his sides and chest. It had started to fade to a sickly yellow at the edges, but they were still vivid and horrifying on him. She let her hands come down and trace the outlines. A couple even had the nerve to take on the shape of a fist. She tried to remain calm, finding solace in the face that whoever did this wouldn't live to see the end of the week.

"About you," she said, her fingers coming up to trace a new scar that was long since healed, but she'd never seen before, just below his right breast. "Where is this from?" she asked.

Simon lifted his head, grunting at the pain it caused his abdoment. He smiled and looked up at her. "Unsanctioned blow in a fight. Won me the match. Was a spider shifter, disgusting bastard." Vic smiled back at him and then grabbed the hem of her own shirt and lifted it off of her head. She found him frowning afterwards. 'Vic..." he trailed off, looking a little apprehensive.

She smiled and leaned over him, so her breasts were pressed against his chest. He gave a small sound of discomfort at the jarring out his wounds and she went back to kissing his neck. "I'll be gentle," she whispered into his ear. She felt Simon's hands come up and trace multiple scars along her back and near her hips. She had too many new ones, she knew. Death matches didn't spare her injuries like sanctioned fights did.

"I don't want you to be," he said back to her, pressing his cheek against hers. She laughed. "Are you just doing this because you missed me?" he asked quietly as she reached to pull his boxers away. He let her lead and take charge. She crawled back up the bed, feeling his thumbs hook into the waist of her underwear.

"No," she said sternly, kissing him fiercely. "I told you. I love you. I want to show you how much I love you."

Simon let out a small groan as her found it's way down to him. He tugged at her underwear. "I love you too, Vic," he whispered back.

"Then show me, Welsh," she growled and snapped her jaws at his neck. He laughed, wrapping his arms around her.


***



Vic didn't know what woke her, but for a moment she forgot where she was. His apartment was so different from the last time she'd been there. She lay on her side in the bed, facing the wall. She panicked a moment, not knowing why, and turned to look over her shoulder. Simon lay on the bed next to her. His chest slowly and steadily rising and falling. It had been rough, it had been long, and it had been the best fuck she'd had in a long time. She hadn't gone easy on him, but in all fairness, he hadn't gone easy on her either.

Turning back around, she looked around the room, trying to figure out what woke her up. She glanced to the clock. It was four in the morning and still dark out. She lay still and listened. That's when she heard it again. A small crash out in the kitchen. A dish clinking or a glass breaking.

She growled deep in her throat, her mind reeling with who the fuck could be in Simon's apartment.

Climbing out of bed, she headed for the dresser near the window, hoping Simon hadn't changed too much in the two years she'd been away. Judging by his prowess in bed, he hadn't. He'd always been and always would be the best she ever had. Pulling clothes to the side and scrounging through one drawer and then the other, she was ready to turn around and cuss Simon out, but stopped when she found what she was looking for. The gun was tucked into his sock drawer. She pulled it out, checked the clip, and found it was loaded.

Looking over her shoulder, she frowned when she saw Simon hadn't stirred from all the commotion. That in itself told her everything she needed to know about how Simon was healing. It was slow going. Because he had feline DNA in him and even before he'd gotten the panther in him, he'd been a light sleeper. She'd never been able to sneak out on him without him knowing. That's how she'd actually gotten to say goodbye last time.

The doctors told her that sleeping and waking would be ten times harder than normal. They'd used the word brain trauma and Vic had shut them up at that and told them to fuck themselves and just tell her when he'd be okay again. They said "probably a week" and she'd flipped them off and went to get Simon ready to come home. It wasn't the doctors she was mad at, but she had no one else to carry out her anger on at the time.

Taking the safety off the gun, she gave one last glance to Simon, still asleep on the bed, and moved to the door. Silently, she checked the hallway and the bathroom for intruders and found none there. She crept down the hallway, keeping herself low to the ground and against the wall as she did so. She could hear someone moving around in the kitchen. The fridge door opened and closed, then some cupboards. She heard the sink being turned on and off. What the fuck were they doing?

Leaning against the wall, she moved ever so slightly so she could get a look into the kitchen. The lights weren't turned on and in the dark she could see a figure standing with his back towards her. He was leaning over the counter next to the sink. She aimed her gun out, slowly rose to a standing position, and moved forward with silent footfalls.

"Don't fucking move," she said in a low voice and took pleasure in seeing the figure stiffen. She thought about just shooting, just firing the gun and being done with it, but the thought that this person could lead her to Simon's attackers kept her from doing so. "Turn around," she commanded. "Slowly."

"I love it when you get bossy," the figure said and Vic frowned. She knew that voice. Quickly moving to the lightswitch, she flipped it on and watched as the figure relented to her request. Her eyes widened as she saw who it was.

"Sung?" she asked in disbelief.

The Tiger Shifter grinned, holding a bowl of cereal in his hands. He took a spoonful and brought it to his mouth, speaking with his mouth full. "You're boyfriends got a nice pad," he said, looking around the room, his eyes coming back to the gun and he tilted his head at her, giving her a come on sort of look. She lowered the gun, but kept her finger on the trigger, just in case.

"What the fuck are you doing here?" she demanded.

Sung took another bite of cereal before he answered. Vic thought he did it just to piss her off because she hated when he spoke with his mouth full. It reminded her too much of Alexey. "Well I was looking for a beer, but your boyfriend's a bit of a health nut, eh? I mean, come on, Grape Nuts? That's old man food."

"He's not my boyfriend," she said automatically and tried to keep the wince from her face.

Sung raised a brow at her. "Oh really? Then what is he?" Now that was a good question. She chose to ignore it.

"Sung, what the fuck are you doing here?" she asked again, tightening her grip slightly on the gun. There were a million possibilities running through her head and not a one of them were pleasant. She'd fought her match before coming, she hadn't been signed up to fight anymore, so what the hell was he after? He wouldn't just chase her around the world to congratulate her on fight well won. No, he wanted some. Or rather, his bosses wanted something. Sung was just a Keeper. He wasn't the one calling the shots.

With a sigh, Sung set the cereal bowl down into the sink and actually had the deceny to rinse it out. He dried off his hands on the kitchen towel and turned to lean agains the counter, crossing his arms over his chest. He looked nonchalant and mellow. But she could see the tense muscles in his arms.

"I missed you," he said sarcastically.

"Sung," she spat out at him, not in the mood for his jokes.

He held up a hand before she could chew him out. "Okay, okay. Can you just...put the gun down? I'm a messenger and we all know what happens to the messengers."

"No," she said coldly.

"God, fine, straight to the point, I like that in a girl." He jumped up onto the counter and swung his legs.

"I will put a fucking bullet in each of your knees if you don't tell me, right now, why the fuck you're here."

Vic rolled over and ran her head down the side of Simon's cheek, trying to rouse him. "Simon," she whispered, aware of the urgency in her voice. Apparently, Simon caught on to it too, because he frowned and rolled his head towards her, moaning slightly. "Shh, Simon, wake up," she said, keeping her hands by his lips.

"Vic, what-" he said groggily, but she moved his hand to cover his mouth. That seemed to clear the cobwebs in his head real quick and he looked up at her with wide eyes. She tried to offer him a reassuring smile, but she'd already slipped into guarded mode. Whoever was out there, she would not let them get to Simon. Whatever the cost.

"Simon, shh," she said, keeping her hand over his mouth. "There's someone in the apartment."

She growled low in her throat, they were looking for something. Rolling away from Simon, she found her underwear and t-shirt and quickly threw them on. She stood at the side of the bed, trying to peek out of the doorway and into the hallway. There was no one there. She turned to look at Simon and paused. He had managed to get into a seated position on the edge of the bed and was finishing pulling on his boxer briefs. She held her breath when she saw that the dark and vivid bruising that had lined his chest and stomach also circled and covered his back. There were several new scratches that led sideways by his shoulders. She'd given him those just hours ago.

"Simon-" she whispered.

He already knew what she wanted. "There's a baseball bat under the bed," he said and she nodded, but watched him try to stand. He failed his first attempt, waivering on his feet and falling back to the bed. But the second attempt fared better and he stood, hand coming to his head as he turned and headed towards the closet. She didn't wait to see what he was fetching as she bent down and pulled the baseball bat from beneath the bed.

The voice that called out from the hallway was something completely unexpected. "Welsh, we know you're in here." It was sing-song and deep and it made Vic shudder. She leapt to the corner of the room, just behind the door and looked over at Simon, who emerged from the closet with a golf club in one hand. His eyes were wide and that was all she needed to tell her that he recognized the voice. She swallowed thickly and looked at her. She put a finger to her lips and motioned for him to get back into the closet.

He hesitated at first and she nearly growled at him, but then he slipped back behind the doors and she steadied herself, gray and white fur already appearing over top of her skin as she shifted into her wolf form, tighetning her grip on the bat. She waited and her wolf hearing could pick up the footfalls of someone coming down the hallway, heading towards the bedroom. She grit her canine teeth and tensed her muscles, ready to jump.

The door to the bedroom creaked open and she saw the gun enter the room first. It was all she needed. They weren't here to talk. They weren't here to kick someone around. They were here to kill. And she'd be damned if she let that happen.

Striking quickly, she brought the bat down onto the arm holding the gun. The scream resonated through the bedroom and she didn't give the attacker time to finish it as she threw the bat to the side and grabbed the arm, flinging him into the room and onto the bed. She leapt onto him and was actually mildly surprised when he started shifting. Horns sprouted on his head and his muscles seemed to triple in size. A freaking Bull shifter.

He lifted her off of him and easily flung her across the room. She managed to rake her claws up his arm and gave a gratified growl as she felt them snag on the exposed bone in the arm she'd broken with the bat. He gave a raging and painful yell as she landed near the window to the bedroom somewhat gracefully. She crouched low and brought her head up, ready to get back into the action, but she froze as she saw a second attacker in the doorway, and who he had his gun aimed at.

Simon had come out of the closet as the sounds of the struggle. He didn't see the second attacker in the doorway. And as the gun fired, Vic screamed out of fear and rage and terrifying, dehabilitating anguish as she could almost picture the bullet ripping through his head and spraying the wall and the room with blood and brain matter and bone. But that didn't happen. Instead, a dart exited the gun and Simon only gave a sudden gasp as it entered his neck. His hand weakly came up to grasp it and pull it out of his skin. He already started to stagger on his feet, the golf club dropping from his hand.

"Simon!" Vic screamed, her voice deep and animalistic in her wolf form. She watched as he turned his eyes to her. The motion and the drugs now coursing through his system sent him off balance and he teetered a bit before collapsing to the ground, blinking owlishly as he still watched her. There was an apology in his eyes and she fucking hated that.

Howling in anger, she tore her eyes from his prone form on the ground and leapt at the man in the doorway. She barely felt the dart enter her back, having dismissed the Shifter on the bed as not being a threat. She managed to slice open the man in the doorway before she felt the darkness and the stars and the the world spin around her. She fellt to the floor, covered in a strange man's blood. Her head lolled to the side and her eyes sought out Simon, who hadn't moved.

"Simon..." she pleaded. Not for him to help her, but for him to forgive her. She'd failed him.

1122111111122.content:
Waking was slow. It came gradually. The first thing she realized was that there was a gag in her mouth. She tried to reach up and withdraw the cloth, but then found out her hand were tied to the arms of a chair. That notion alone was enough to clear the cobwebs in her head and force her to open her eyes. Her head was pounding but she couldn't remember hitting it. It felt like a bad hangover, many of which she'd had throughout her days. But never before had she woken up gagged and tied to a chair.

She groaned and closed her eyes. But when a groan responded to her own, she quickly opened them and whipped her head up to look at the source of the sound. Her eyes widened and it all came back to her. Simon. She'd been with Simon in his apartment. Someone had come in. They'd been tranquilized. And now, she was bound and gagged and sitting across from her, so was Simon. Anger spiked through her as she found new wounds on him.

Simon was tied more than she was. Whereas her arms were tied to the arms of her chair, his were bound behind his back, with a rope tied to the supports on the bottom of his chair. His ankles were bound to the legs of the chair and he had duct tape over his mouth instead of a soft gag. He was still in his boxer briefs. His knees were both skinned and she imagined whoever had done this hadn't been as gentle getting Simon in here as they were with her. Not to mention the new cuts on his chest, which had bled and dripped down his abdomen. His face, if possible, looked more bruised than it had before and the old cut on his eyebrow had been reopened. Dammit, it looked like he'd woken up and put up a fight.

Through the gag, she tried to say his name. His eyes rose to meet hers and she could see the utter exhaustion and pain there. She growled deep in her throat. She began working her hands back and forth up the length of the arm chairs, feeling the ropes rub into her wrists but not caring. They needed to get out of here - wherever here was.

A door to the dark room opened and Vic had to blink against the sudden light, but she focued quickly on the three figures who'd entered. One was the Bull Shifter from the apartment, his arm in a cast. The other two she didn't recognize. There was a smaller one trailing behind, holding an uzi, which really dampened her spirits. The third man was wearing a suit and was incredibly clean cut. He was older, mid fifties probably. He looked like he was in charge.

"Ms. Wolfe," the man in the suit said and his voice was smooth and calm and she didn't like it one fucking bit. Nor the fact that he knew her name. She watched as he came over to her and the Bull Shifter walked over to Simon while the little dude stood guard in the doorway. "I'm sorry we had to meet under these circumstances."

Vic had a colorful retort for the fancy pants man, but the gag stopped it from coming out. She just glared at him. But they weren't allowed to continue their conversation as the Bull Shifter suddenly and without provocation, backhanded Simon, hard. Simon's head whipped to the side, blood splattering the ground from the heavily bleeding cut on his eyebrow. Vic growled and tried to rise to go to him. Simon hadn't made a sound and he bowed his head, swallowing.

"Now," the suited man said. "Is that necessary?" The Bull Shifter turned to look at him, then submissively took a step away from Simon. Vic breathed a small sigh of relief. The man turned back to her and smiled warmly. She wanted to wipe that smile off his fugly face. He squated down in front of her just watched her a moment. "Do you know who I am?" he asked after a moment. Vic gave him a look and all he had to do was nod his head before the Bull Shifter came over and pulled the gag from Vic's mouth. "Let's try again," he said, chuckling.

Vic didn't answer, just spit on him. "Fuck yourself," she said afterwards. The Bull behind her grabbed a fist full of her hair and pulled her head back violently. She couldn't help but cry out.

"Stop," the suited man said and she was let go. She turned around to glare at the Shifter behind her. The touch of a hand on her thigh had her whirling her head back around, though. She forgot that she was only in her panties and a t-shirt. Fucker.

"Don't touch me," she growled at him.

The man chuckled. "I can't help myself," he drawled. "You are very beautiful." His eyes went to the patch over her eye. "Despite your flaws. "

"What do you want?" she demanded, deciding to change tactics.

He continued to rub her thigh for a moment, moving his hand higher and higher until it came to her hip and around to her back. She suppressed a shiver at the unwanted touching. He looked up at her, grinning, and ignored her question. "Mr. Welsh is a lucky man to have found a woman like you," he said and stood up. He brought his hand to her chin and tilted her head up, running his thumb along her jaw. She jerked her head away, but he caught her chin in a violent hold. "Does he fuck you like you want to be fucked?" he asked quietly.

Vic heard Simon say something muffled. It didn't sound pleasant. She ignored the man's question, not giving in to his stupid mind games, although she knew there was a distinct possibility this man would be capable of getting, or doing, whatever he wanted to her. Like hell she'd let him do it without a fight, though.

"What do you want?" she repeated.

He laughed. "Strong willed, I like that." He let go of her and walked away, heading towards Simon. Shit, that wasn't the way she wanted him to go. "Well, I did want something out of Mr. Welsh here for a while. But he didn't follow through on our little bargain." The man's hand came to Simon's shoulder and she saw him tense. His eyes darted to her for a moment and she read fear in them, which is something she didn't often see coming from him. "So I think I'm done with him." He nodded to the little guy at the door and the guy pointed his gun, straight at Simon.

"No!" Vic screamed, trying again to come out of her seat. "Please!" she begged, her heart pounding so heavily in her chest she thought she'd pass out right there and then. She couldn't fucking lose Simon, not now, not after she just got him back.

The man held up his hand, stalling the execution. Simon had gone white, but a look of anger had settled itself onto his face. He was getting pissed. "No? What, do you think there is something you could offer me that will save Mr. Welsh's life? I have no use for him. I have no qualms with killing him where he sits."

"I'll do anything," Vic grit out. "Just, please, don't hurt him."

The man grinned.

"That's what I wanted to hear."

11221112.content:
Simon faltered for a moment and it was enough to tell her that he was hiding something. It hurt to think that he'd hide something from her, but she had to remind herself that she'd walked out on him without so much as a look back. It would probably take a long, long while before the trust was back. She'd hurt him and she knew it.

His hand came up to weakly brush through the hair hanging over her shoulder. He looked her in the eyes. "Vic, I-" Whatever he was about to confess or tell her was cut off when a familiar and distinct voice sounded from the doorway of the room.

"You're not welcome here!"

Vic saw Simon flinch and it confused her at first. The voice was enough to make anyone flinch, sure. But Simon's eyes had held fear for a moment as they darted towards the door. And Vic had only ever seen him express anger, frustration, betrayal and love towards his mother. Never fear. What was worse, she couldn't tell if it was just because he'd been beaten within an inch of his life or because something else entirely. It sent every protective instinct of her on edge and she gave his hand a squeeze before she leaned back and hopped off the bed. She turned to eye the woman standing in the doorway.

Sophie Welsh was the epitome of a rich bitch. She kept her hair died an unnatural blonde color. She'd had work done on her face to keep her looking young, but Vic thought it just kept her looking dehydrated. She wore a fancy blue dress suit with skirt and a hat that was too big to be from this century. She held sunglasses in her gloved hands and there was a fur scarf around her neck. Vic hated the woman to the core of her very being. Back in the day, she'd thought about putting a hit out on her more than once. But being Simon's mother, Vic had restrained herself. As much as Simon may get frustrated and want to cut her out of his life, she was still his mom.

"Funny," Vic forced a smile onto her face. "I could say the same to you."

The woman huffed and waved her sunglasses at Vic. "You get out of this room or I will call security."

Vic made an overexaggerated roll of her eyes at the threat. "Go ahead. I'm sure they wouldn't mind escorting you off the property."

Sophie bristled and yelled, "You little bitch!"

There was a comeback on the tip of Vic's tongue, waiting to come out, but Simon's quiet, "Mom," from his bed was enough to bring both their attention to him. Vic frowned. He looked ten times more tired than he had been only moment ago. She cursed herself for not calling the doctor in to take a look at him. She thought about going now to do it, but there was no fucking way she was leaving Simon alone with his mother. He was practically defenseless. Not that she ever thought Sophie would hurt her son, on purpose that is. There were ways family could hurt each other without drawing blood. Sophie was damn good at that kind of pain.

"My boy," She cooed and purposely shoved Vic out of the way to come to Simon's side. Vic let her get away with it, because she wasn't going to drop an old lady in the middle of the god damn hospital. She took a few steps back, standing at the end of Simon's bed as Sophie took her spot by him. Simon's eyes met Vic's for a moment and an apology passed between them before Sophie was reaching out to touch Simon's face. He winced as she didn't go easy in her examination over him. Vic gripped the end of the bed until she was white knuckled, managing to keep a growl deep in her throat. She really fucking hated Sophie Welsh.

"I'm fine, Mom," Simon said. Vic wanted to reach out and slap them both. She hated this. She hated how Simon turned submissive around his mother, because he wasn't submissive. Not the way his mother made him be. And as Vic watched, she realized it must have gotten worse while she was away, because Sophie stood back and put her hands on her hips and Simon looked like he'd just gotten kicked while he was down.

"What good did all those years of practice do if you're just going to let a bunch of hooligans jump you on the way home from a bar?" she demanded, her voice scolding and piercing and entirely unneeded at the moment. She didn't give him time to answer. "And what good is having animal genes if you don't use them. I'm disappointed. I thought you were better than, this." She waved a hand near over his face, gesturing to the bruises.

"Do you know who did this, Sophie?" Vic asked, trying to draw attention away from Simon.

Sophie turned and let out a snarl. It was very feral for someone with no animal genes. "Why are you still here?"

"Mom, she-"

"Shut up, you," Sophie snapped at Simon, who sighed and seemed to settle into the bed, defeated. Vic could see his eyes droop a little and he brought a hand to his face, feeling the bruises and wounds there.

"I think I'll get the doctor," Vic growled, bringing both of their attentions to her. She smiled at Simon, who returned it gratefully. Then she glared at Sophie, who did the same, before she left to get the doctor.

112212.content:
By the time the plane landed, it was dark in New York. She'd called Jezibel as soon as the pilot had announced their arrival and the use of cell phones. Jez had told her the hospital wasn't allowing visitors. Simon had gotten worse. He was in ICU and he was limited to only a few hours a day of visitation for as long as he stayed in the intensive care. She thought about going to the hospital anyway. She could scale the walls, climb in through a window, kill a few doctors, no big deal. But Jez talked her out of it. Told her to find a motel somewhere and get some rest. Simon would still be here in the morning. They both knew that could be a lie as soon as she'd said it.

"His heart stopped. They had to put him on life support."

She played the words over in her mind. He'd died. He'd fucking died on her. She'd have to kill him later for doing that.

The fact that he was getting worse, instead of better, didn't slip pass Vic unnoticed, either. A part of her had hoped he'd be awake when she landed in the States. She hoped he'd be up and at 'em when she got to the hospital. She hoped he'd smile and say something funny and witty and make her angry and happy all at the same time. But it didn't look like it was going to work out that way. Nothing ever worked out the way she planned these days.

There wasn't a motel in New York that seemed to suit her. She didn't have a lot of cash on her and she didn't keep credit cards, they were too easy to track. There was one place she could go and she hoped that he hadn't changed the locks on her while she was gone.

Simon's apartment building was looking a lot better and less "hell-hole"-ish than the last time she'd seen it. Someone had put a lot of money into the building to fix it up and it actually looked decent. The smile that crept across her face was barely contained as she entered through the familiar doorway. She paused a moment to look at the names on the mailboxes, just to make sure that he still live here. Sure enough, apartment 305, Welsh was scribbled onto a torn up sticky note and stuffed beneath the plastic cover. Her hand written had been better back then, even if she'd put it in there out of anger. He'd always been lazy and bad about taking care of small household chores like that.

Climbing the stairs, because she still didn't trust the elevator in the building, no matter how nice it looked now, she reached the third floor and made her way down the hallway. Last apartment on the right. A corner apartment. Two hundred bucks more a month than other apartments, but not as much as the penthouse. They'd always talked about moving into the penthouse together. She closed her eyes as she reached his door. For a moment, she wanted to turn around and run straight to the hospital and demand to see him, demand to make sure that he was still fucking breathing even if it was with the aide of a tube and a machine. She wanted to touch him, to smell him. She just wanted him, god dammit.

Vic's thoughts were stilled as she heard noise come from within the apartment. She was part way shifted even before she threw the door open with a crash and lunged inside. Her eyes caught a man standing in the kitchen, with the refrigerator door open. He whirled on her and she froze, recognizing him instantly.

Alexey had a beer in one hand and a half eaten sub in the other. His mouth was full and his hair was pulled back in a tight pony-tail and he looked years older yet more immature than the last time she'd seen him. Surprise etched into his face and it would have been comical if the situation hadn't been so dire.

Swallowing the food in his mouth, Alexey set his food down and narrowed his eyes at her. "About time you showed up," he said, leaning against the counter in his typical swagger type of way. "Simon's only been unconscious a day and a half. No need to rush or anything. Not like he means anything to you."

Something snapped insider her at the words. Something that had been bending and bursting and festering within her and at those words, it exploded. She leapt across the counter in one fluid motion, shifting completely as she brought her fists to meet him. His surprise turning to utter shock at the motion and he cried out as she slammed into him, shoving him up against the counter, one hand wrapped around his throat, her claws digging slightly into his skin. She lifted him off the ground. "Fuck you!" she screamed at him.

Red and white fur sprouted on him instantly in a defense mechanism. He shifted easily within her grasp and with the agility she'd always known him to have, he twisted his body up so his legs wrapped around her. He reached out and slapped her across the face. She fell backwards, letting go of his neck. He flipped, gracefully, over the counter and ducked down low, gauging to see if she'd come after him again. She whirled on him, unable to keep the tears from coming as she shifted back, her wolf form disappearing.

"I got here as fast as I could," she cried softly, feeling a tear slip out of her eye and down her cheek, still smarting from his slap.

Alexey's eyes widened a little and he stood, shifting himself back as well. He looked a little confused at her reaction. He reached a hand up to rub at his neck. "Well fuck, Vic," he said, looking at her. "Don't pull out the damn tears. You know I fucking hate it when you cry."

"You've never seen me cry," she growled at him.

He paused a moment to think about it, then shrugged. "Guess your right, still doesn't change anything." He hesitated a moment before he moved forward, still agile even in his fully human form, to wrap an arm around her. "Good to see you, Bitchzilla."

Vic let out a small laugh at the nickname. She hadn't heard it in forever. He'd always called her that. Then Simon was supposed to punch him in the arm, brotherly and lovingly. She threw the punch, weakly, for their missing family member. "You too, you little shit." She pulled back and looked up at him. "What do you know?"

Alexey sighed and let his arm drop from her. "We're gonna need something harder than beer."

Turns out the only hard liquor Simon had in his apartment was blackberry brandy. Vic decided she'd rib him about it if he woke up. Correction, when he woke up. She hadn't really expected anything less from him, though. Simon Welsh had never been much of a drinker. He stuck mostly to beer and, on occasion, wine when he was trying to be sophisticated and classy. It didn't happen often, but his mother seemed to like it when he drank chardonay instead of Pabst.

Alexey poured them both a tall glass of the putrid drink and then pulled a stool to the other side of the counter island in Simon's apartment. He sat down and raised his glass to toast her. There was a goofy, giddy look on his face and she couldn't help but smile as she raised her glass, clinked it with his, and they both gagged on the girly liquor. Vic wondered if Simon kept the alcohol around only to please his mother. Probably.

"What happened?" She repeated as she placed her glass down, looking up at Alexey. He was staring at his glass, licking his lips as if he was trying to rid himself of the taste in his mouth. But she caught the far away look in his eyes and the small sigh that escaped his lips. It did nothing to calm her down. Because as long as she'd known Alexey, she'd never known him to look so...lost. Or worried. Or whatever hell other emotions were on his face that she couldn't read. Seeing him without a grin or no jokes escaping that dumb mouth of his - it wasn't natural.

"Simon's a dick, that's what happened," he growled suddenly and brought his glass up to take another long swig. He finished it off and then shoved the glass aside, leaning heavily onto the counter as he finally rose his eyes to meet hers. They lingered a bit on the eyepatch over her eye and she gave him time to take it in, almost daring him to ask her how she got it. But he didn't bring it up, instead looking at her good eye.

She snorted and took another sip, her nose turning up, before she pushed it away and stood back. She didn't want to sit. She'd been sitting for so long on the airplane. "I know he's a dick," she said. "But that doesn't explain why he's in the hospital." She paused long enough for Alexey to smirk. "What happened?" she asked again.

Running a hand over his face, Alexey looked tired suddenly. She imagined him getting the call, probably the same way she'd gotten one. How long did it take to get from Russia to the States? She wondered if he'd even still been in Russia. He was the last time she'd been there, that's why she'd left. She hadn't kept in touch with him.

"It was fucking Lyle," Alexey spat, the venom and hatred in his voice slipping out when he said the other Shifter's name.

Surprise registered on her face and she felt her heart skip a beat for a moment. "Tex?" she asked.

"Fucking Liddle."

The last time Victoria had seen Lyle Fucking Liddle, he'd been lazing at work and throwing spitballs into the garbage can while Jezibel was going off on some rant about their last job. It had been the day before she'd left and she'd paid just enough attention to the Viper Shifter to observe he looked bored before she'd walked over to Simon and told him she wanted to come over that night. She'd wanted to say goodbye. She hadn't bothered with a goodbye to Lyle. She'd never really liked the slimey bastard, and sure as hell didn't trust him.

Turns out she had been right not to.

"Tex," she said the name again and Alexey nodded, quirking a small smile despite himself. He must have known where she was going with this. "Fucking Lyle Liddle put Simon in the hospital?" she was having trouble picturing it.

Alexey straightened a little, a snort escaping his mouth. "He's not the same," he said. "Lyle, not Simon. Simon's...pretty much the same bastard you left two years ago." She tried not to be hurt by the statement. "But Lyle, he went rogue. And he must have some serious fucking backing because he broke his contract and the Big Bosses just let him walk."

Vic worried her bottom lip at that. Contracts were serious business in Shifter world. You didn't break them and keep breathing free air. Everything came with a price. You either wound up in some lab somewhere or in jail or six feet under. Those were the options. You didn't just break a contract and do whatever the hell you wanted. Unless someone bought you out. She frowned and Alexey must have seen it.

"Don't think too hard, you might hurt yourself. "

"Fuck you," she said half heartedly as her mind continued to work. She raised an eyebrow at him though. "How'd he get the drop on Simon? And why? They always got along."

Alexey shrugged. "Don't know why he did it. And I don't know how either. Simon's good, Vic." He didn't have to tell her that. She knew how good Simon was. He was one of the best fighters she'd ever seen. He'd beat her once, in a caged match. He used to like to rub it in, until she'd beat him back. Not in a cage match. "I can't picture Lyle ever winning against him. But it was him. There were witnesses. And the way they talk.." He trailed off shaking his head.

"What, Lexey?" she asked. She leaned forward to try to catch his eye. "Tell me."

He hesitated a second. "I don't know. It's like he was suped up on something. Made him faster and bigger and...I don't know. I want to kill him, Vic." He'd slipped the last part out, like it wasn't something he had meant to admit, but he looked at her with such earnest eyes that she knew he meant it. Hell, she felt the same way. If Lyle really did put Simon in the hospital, there was no way she'd let him get away with it. She wanted an explanation. And after she got one, she'd gut the bastard.

She smiled at Alexey. "Me too."

They'd shared another drink, had gone into Simon's living room and watched the Kung-Fu movie he had in his VCR - god he was so old fashioned - and then Vic couldn't deny how tired she was. After telling Alexey to fuck off after he offered to keep her warm in the bed, she'd closed the door to Simon's bedroom and had stared at the room as Alexey found a spot on the couch. It was like a foreign country to her, one she somewhat remembered, but couldn't quite recall how to navigate. He'd gotten a new comforter. She'd told him for a long time he needed a new one. She'd tell him again when she saw him, because this one was ugly. He'd rearranged the room, the dresser was on the opposite side. Clothes were strewn about the bedroom and she was reminded what a slob he could be.

As she climbed onto the bed, she lowered herself face down into the familair feel of it. Her face buried into one of the pillows and she inhaled deeply. It smelled of him. She kicked off her jeans and pulled off her shirt and cozied herself beneath the covers, hugging one of the pillows to her chest, trying not to pretend it was him.

She must have been tired. Sleep came quickly.


***



The street corner was foreign to her. She couldn't remember how she got here and it took just a moment to realize she must be dreaming.

"Fuck."

She turned at the voice and there, walking up the street, pausing beneath a streetlight to peel gum off his shoe, was Simon. And damn he looked good. He was dressed up for something. Nothing fancy. Just a nice shirt and a pair of jeans that made him look more cowboy than street fighter. His signature work boots were his pride and joy and it was no wonder he hated it when he stepped in something that had no right being on the ground. Fucking teenagers.

The attack came out of nowhere and Vic was frozen in place, unable to stop it, forced to be a bystander to the crime. She wanted to scream. She wanted to run in there and pull Simon away. But she was dreaming. And there was no stopping what was about to happen.

Lyle jumped from the roof of a building like some god damn super hero monkey man. Only scales covered his body and a wild snaked tongue trailed to the side as he hissed his assault. He looked bigger than she remembered. He looked more monster than she knew him to be. Alexey's voice came to her mind. It's like he was suped up on something. Suped up, more like he was juiced up on steroids - a shit ton of them.

Simon looked up in time to let out a startled gasp as the Viper Shifter landed on top of him, sending him to the ground. He was shifting even as he whirled, trying to gain his feet back. Maybe he didn't think Lyle was really going to hurt him, because he didn't move as quickly as she knew he could. Maybe he thought this was a prank or a joke. But the cry he emitted when Lyle's snake fangs entered his shoulder was not a joke. It shook Vic to the core.

The Viper Shifter had Simon pinned beneath him. He aimed punch after punch to Simon's face. The Panther Shifter's struggles were growing weaker and weaker, not all from the punches. The venom coursing through his veins slowed and numbed him. She heard bones crunch. She saw blood spill. The beating Simon was taking was horrific. And Lyle carried on, eyes narrowed and focused on the feline. Simon shifted back somewhere around the ninth punch to the face. His arms fell limp to his side. He jerked with each additional punch, but he'd stopped struggling a while ago.

Lyle screamed into the night air suddenly and stood, giving Simon several kicks to the side for good measure. Then, the Viper Shifter was scaling the wall and he was gone.

And Simon was bleeding and broken on the street.

Vic wanted to scream.

And then she did.


***



Sitting up quickly in bed, she wasn't sure at first if she'd actually screamed outloud. But as Alexey came barging into the bedroom with a spatula in one hand, she knew that she had. His eyes darted around the room, scanning for an enemy or an attacker. When he didn't find any, he looked back to her, lowering his cooking utensil weapon.

"Vic?" he asked, looking frazzled.

She stared at him for a moment, frowning as she tried to catch her breath and stop herself from shaking. She glanced to the clock. It was morning. They could go and visit Simon soon. The smell of bacon and eggs filtered in through the open door and she reached a hand up to run it over her face. "Shit," she growled.

Alexey snorted and Vic wanted to punch him. She would have, if he wasn't across the room. Bastard probably knew that too. "Bad dream?"

"Fuck yourself."

"No thanks, I got a girlfriend to do that."

Vic looked at him curiously after that, raising an eyebrow. "You do?" she asked, somewhat surprised.

Alexey grinned and it looked so much like Simon when he did that Vic felt pain strike at her heart, the blood and violence of her dream flashing through her mind again. "Sure do."

"Left hands don't count as girlfriends."

The laugh that emitted from his voice sounded good and calmed her. He shook his spatula at her. "Get dressed. I made your favorite. Jez called and we're leaving in fifteen minutes."

Vic frowned. She hadn't heard the phone ring. She must have really been tired. "And?"

"And what?"

She sighed. "What did she say? Is he awake?"

Alexey grinned.

The drive to the hospital was too slow for Vic's liking. She'd threatened to rip Alexey's throat out if he didn't pick up the pace. He'd complied, not wanting to test the validity of her threats. She was out of the car before he had it fully in park. He had to run to keep up with her as she entered the elevator, smashing the button fifteen times to get the doors to close faster. Vic ignored the dumbass grin on Alexey's face, her thoughts completely on Simon.

He was awake.

They were the sweetest words she'd ever heard in her life.

As the elevator doors opened, she bolted out. Completely bypassing the reception desk, she ran down the corridor and nearly collided with Jez as she was exiting Simon's room. Vic took a deep breath, looking at the petite blonde woman a moment. Jez looked somewhat startled to see her, but then gave little warning before she leapt forward and wrapped Vic in a rough hug.

"Oh, Vic, it's so good to see you!" she said, giving her a tight squeeze. Vic returned the favor lightly before pulling back.

"How is he?" she demanded.

Jez didn't look offended. She seemed to understand. It made Vic cringe a little. Because that kind of understanding was not something you just packed your shit up and ran away from for two years without a word. That kind of understanding was reserved for the deepest of family ties. It made Vic want to hug her again.

"He's resting," she said, smiling as Alexey finally caught up, having fended off the angry nurses Vic's wild dash through the hospital had created. Vic didn't miss the way his hand entwined Jez's. She looked at the both of them, sure that that hadn't been there before. She'd have to ask later through, because Jez's words decided her actions before she did. "You can go see him though."

She glanced at Alexey, who waved her into the room, bringing an arm up to wrap around Jez's shoulder. Yeah, she'd have to ask them later. "Go ahead. I'll take sloppy seconds," he winked.

With a thankful nod, she entered Simon's hospital room and immediately froze. All of her hurry and rush to see him seemed to melt away. She almost wanted to turn around and leave again, because looking at him, lying there asleep, with all those tubes and all those bruises and his arm in a sling - she wanted to run away all over again. But she knew it wouldn't erase the hurts. She knew it wouldn't take his bandages away. Alexey had informed her of his injuries, but she still wasn't ready for this.

Simon's head was wrapped in gauze. His messy dark hair poked through the white bandages in spots. He'd had a severe concussion and bleeding in his brain, which was what had induced the coma. The gauze came down and around his chin. His face was bruised and swollen. One eye was swollen completely shut, a blow to the head had broken his left cheekbone. A single laceration across his nose told her it had been broken, but not shattered. It would heal. Purple bruises spread out along his chin and down his neck. He was slightly propped up on the bed. His right arm was in a sling and she could see bandages poking out from beneath his hospital gown. His arm wasn't broken, but there had been large puncture wounds in his shoulder and he needed to not move his arm. Three broken ribs were hidden by the gown. There were wires and IVs connected to his free arm, which was just as bruised and lacerated as his face.

He was a mess.

Swallowing thickly, she realized her dream probably hadn't been that far off. She'd seen Simon beat up before. It came with being a cage fighter. She'd visited him in the hospital before too. But none of them, absolutely none of them, had been this bad. The one that came closest was four years ago when he'd taken a fall off of a scaffolding. They'd thought he'd broken his back. Turns out cats really do have nine lives.

A fact for which she was so grateful for as she stood in his hospital room now.

He had to be running out of lives.

Moving slowly to the end of his bed, she stared down at him. The closer she got, the heavier the air in the room was. Her eye darted to the flowers and cards littering the room. Fans, family - they'd all sent him things. There were probably more out there that the nurses couldn't fit in. Simon had a big fanbase. She'd heard of his fame even in China. At one of the matches she'd fought, she had nearly died of shock when her opponent had come out wearing a t-shirt with Simon's scripted catch phrase on it. It read, "Big Cat's gonna bring tha pain!" She hated that catch phrase. And she'd never actually heard him say it.

Sliding around the side of his bed, she stood at his side. She felt a lump form in her throat, because how was she going to handle this? How was she supposed to handle this? She didn't know and she needed help. She thought about going out and getting Alexey, because he always broke the tension in a room. But she didn't have the chance. Simon didn't give her the chance.

One eye slowly fluttered open. It was bloodshot and glassy. It scanned the room quickly, coming to rest on Vic for a moment before he closed it again. Her heart beat heavily in her chest as she thought he didn't recognize her or didn't care enough to stay awake. She shouldn't have fucking come.

Then, almost comedicly, he frowned, and it looked like it hurt, and the eye opened again, staring up at her. He licked his lips, when he finally spoke his voice was raw and rough and painful. "Vic." he couldn't quite form it into a question.

Her fingers slid out to grasp his gently. She felt him squeeze, too lightly, back.

"We have to work on your bob and weave," she whispered to him as he stared up at her, his glassy green eye begging for answers, for something.

The smile that broke onto his face was enough to make the trip worth it.

1122122111.content:
Simon couldn't seem to keep his eyes open, but bless his heart if he wasn't trying so hard to do so. Vic wasn't moving from his side, just watching the losing battle he was waging with consciousness. She imagined the drugs and the concussion were really fogging up his mind right now. He'd open his unswollen eye and search her out. Looking frantic for a moment that maybe she'd left him again while he wasn't paying attention. He'd spot her, she'd squeeze his hand, and he'd be so content that she was there his eyes would slip close again. She would have thought it was cute, if he wasn't so good damn worried that she'd leave. It made her feel guilty. She wouldn't be leaving again. Not until whoever did this was dead and gone and she was certain he would be sticking around for a while longer.

A soft knock came from the doorway and Vic pulled her eyes from Simon to find Alexey standing there. He grinned at her, but it faded a bit as his gaze wandered to his prone brother lying on the bed. "He's back asleep?" he asked, stepping into the room and walking over to the other side of the bed. He frowned down at Simon, hand reaching out to ghost over the swollen eye. God someone had really done a number on him.

"Trying not to be," she said and as if on cue his eye opened again, searching her out. He found her and she nodded in Alexey's direction. Simon actually turned his head a bit when he realized his brother was standing there too now. The motion seemed to take it out of him and his eyes slipped closed a moment, a small wince escaping before he opened them again.

Alexey grinned down at him. "Hey, bro," he said, louder than he had to. He reached out and gave the bandage around Simon's head an extremely gentle tug. "I like the new do."

Simon actually smiled again, looking increasingly more alert. Vic still held his hand in hers. His thumb moved ever so slightly over her fingers. It was a motion she was painstakingly familiar with. He'd always been gentle. But never because he didn't have the strength to be rough.

"It's all the new rave in France," Simon rasped out, his voice no more than a whisper and it looked like talking took a lot of effort. Alexey and Vic exchanged a look, neither one of them really used to seeing him so weak and banged up. Vic couldn't stop herself from lifting his hand and bringing his fingers to her lips. Alexey stuck his tongue into his cheek and turned his attention back to Simon.

"You've never been to France, dickweed." A laugh escaped Simon's lips but it turned into coughing. He drew his hand away from Vic's and held his own side. Alexey's face fell a little and he reached out to gently put a comforting hand on Simon's leg. "Hey, easy," he said softly. Vic watched, trying not to feel like a stranger among the two. She wasn't sure, but she had to guess that Alexey and Simon had had more contact with each other in the past two years than she'd had with either. She still knew them, still loved them, but this situation was all so foreign to her that she couldn't seem to jump in and break whatever passed between the brothers.

As the coughing subsided, Simon brought his hand away from his ribs and it blindly seeked out the comforting touch of Vic's fingers. She gave him what he sought and squeezed his hand gently. His eyes were closed again, but he was moving his jaw. Finally, he opened his eye again and looked between the both of them. "How bad?" he asked quietly.

"Bro, you got your ass handed to you," Alexey said, laughing as Simon's face fell into an annoyed glare, regardless if it lost most of it's effect through the bruising.

Vic reached a hand out to run her fingers down the side of Simon's face. He turned to look at her, knowing she'd have answers. "You're going to be fine, now that you're awake," she assured him. He nodded slightly, eyes slipping closed as the motion made him dizzy. She gave him a second to reopen them before she added. "It'll take a while, but you'll fully recover."

Simon tilted his head at her, as if he suddenly noticed something. His eyes lit up as he spoke. "Are you a pirate now?" There was mirth in his strained voice.

Alexey had the decency to only giggle and not outright laugh. That or he knew Vic would leap across the bed at him. She shook her head at Simon, lifting his hand again to kiss it. "Ass," she told him with her lips still on his fingers.

"I still think...you're beautiful," he said, blinking heavily. Vic winced. A part of her wished he didn't. A part of her wished he'd be angry at her, instead of happy to see her. Maybe he was angry. But maybe his happiness at seeing her again was clouding it.

A groan escaped Alexey's lips and he threw his hands up in the air overdramatically. Both Simon and Vic turned to look at him, Vic annoyed and Simon just trying to keep up with it all. "Oh god," Alexey drawled, playing up his disgust for the sake of lightening the mood and keeping his brother from worrying too much over his own wounds. "I would say get a room but I think I'm in it."

Vic sighed and Simon just smiled and closed his eyes. He seemed to take comfort in the familiar and long missed banter. She felt his hand going slack in hers and she laid it down gently onto the bed, her fingers tracing his. Alexey turned to pull a chair over for her and then grab another for himself on the other side. She sat down and watched Simon's face, watched the rise and fall of his chest. He seemed to realize he was falling asleep though and his eye opened again, turning to try and look at both of them.

"Dude, just sleep," Alexey said, voicing Vic's thoughts before she could. "Your sweet, beautiful, and amazing guardian angel is here to protect you now. Oh, and Vic's here too."

Vic rolled her eyes as Simon gave a soft, painful laugh, not opening his eyes. She leaned forward and said quietly, "He's right, though. Get some rest. We'll take care of Lyle for you." Her words didn't get the reaction she'd thought out of him. His face furrowed into a frown and he forced his eye open. He looked at her then, studying her for a moment, like he didn't understand what she'd just said. She frowned at him, glancing to Alexey who looked equally confused at his reaction. "Simon, what is it?" she asked.

11221221111.content:
Simon and Alexey were shooting hoops on a cracking and rotting basketball court. They'd just gotten off a job the previous day and this was their down time. Vic hated basketball. She hated anything that didn't involve her punching something or making something bleed. But the boys loved it and she'd go and watch just to make them happy.

She was sitting on a bench under the sun, bored. Lyle came up to stand behind her.

"Stop sneaking up on people," she said to him.

"It's not sneaking if you hear me coming."

"One day I won't. And I'll rip your face off."

He laughed and patted her shoulder and she wanted to break his hand but restrained herself because then there would be a trip to the hospital and she knew Simon and Alexey would be angry.

Lyle leaned in closer and she turned to look him in the eye. He had snake eyes. Even in human form. He was grinning at her. "He loves you," he said, voice quiet, calculating. She frowned, eyes darting a moment to Simon, who had just scored a three point shot and was ribbing Alexey about it. The younger man seemed to rage and it turned into a scuffle. She looked back to Lyle. Boys would be boys.

"No he doesn't," she told him. "He thinks he does."

Lyle shook his head. "No, he does. And he's lucky, because you love him back."

The Viper Shifter stood up and walked away at that. Vic watched the spot he'd been standing in for a moment before turning back. She'd swallowed thickly.

Four weeks later, when she realized Lyle was right, she left.


***



"It wasn't Lyle."

Simon's broken voice echoed in the silence that followed the statement. Vic seemed surprsied at that and she looked to Alexey for an explanation, since he'd been the one to tell her the information. But one look at the younger man and she realized he was more shocked than she was. He shook his head, leaning forward to look Simon in the eye.

"No, bro, it was him," he said, trying to keep his tone light. Vic knew him too well, though. She knew when Alexey got serious because he could never quite keep that look out of his eyes or the quake out of his voice. He was one of the worse poker players she knew, because he wore his emotions on his sleeve at times. He couldn't hide joy and he couldn't mask anger. It was what she loved about him. And she loved that he tried to hide it, even though he knew he was terrible at it. "There were witnesses. They identified Lyle's scale markings. You know those can't be replicated, even if they used the same snake's DNA. Those markings are unique to each Shifter. They're better than fingerprints, man, remember? Lyle hated that."

Simon shook his head again, his sudden burst of energy fading quickly. "It wasn't him," he rasped. He had to lick his lips afterwards.

Vic leaned forward. She clasped Simon's chin in her hand, gently so as to not hurt the obvious bruising there. She guided his head so he was looking at her instead of trying to argue with his brother. She knew how the two of them could get and even in his drugged, concussed and injured state, she could see Simon's argumentative side flaring to life. She wouldnt' allow it. She needed answers. "How do you know?" she asked. "How do you know it wasn't Lyle?"

He swallowed thickly, his glassy eye distant a moment. "The eyes, Vic," he choked out. She frowned at him but he continued without needing to be prompted. "They weren't his eyes."

As Simon finally lost his battle with consciousness, Vic looked over at Alexey, who had a perplexed look on his face, but she could tell he was thinking the same thing she was. Lyle had unmistakeable eyes. They were piercing and yellow and so unique in the fact that they didn't change between his snake and his human form. It was a flaw, the scientists had told him. Well, for a flaw, he'd always been proud of them. Because they scared people and fascinated people and seduced people all at the same time. Hell, he'd almost won Vic over once. If she hadn't known what a pompous ass he could be, she may have even wound up fucking him instead of Simon.

The contemplative silence was broken as Jez came into the room, carrying a tray with three coffees fit snuggly into their holders. She was grinning as they looked over at her. "I brought gifts!" she said happily, but the smile faded from her face as she looked at them, taking in their stares and worried looks. "What's wrong?" she asked.

Alexey voice their predicament. Because even if Simon was lying in a hospital bed and he was drugged, concussed and loopy as hell - they knew he was right. Vic knew what it was like to be attacked. She knew that one of the first things you looked at while it was happening was the eyes. Because eyes were something people remembered but seldom looked at. Look into them and you can see the future. You can see whether this person beating the crap out of you is just going to leave you broken and bleeding or if they're going to leave you dead on the street. She knew Simon and she knew he'd look at the eyes.

And because she knew, and because Alexey knew too, they knew they had a problem.

"It wasn't Lyle."

114.content:
Her teeth sunk into his shoulder and he gasped at the pain of it before slamming her harder against the wall. A small moan escaped her lips and her nails dug into his back. They were both covered in sweat and panting now, the last of their clothes lying in a trail leading from the door to the bedroom.

“Victoria…” he said. His eyes fluttered and he was breathing hard, but he slowed the pace down.

“Shut up,” she snarled at him. Her teeth sunk into his skin again and she pushed off the wall so that they both tumbled to the floor. She didn’t want him to be nice or slow or gentle, she just wanted to feel every inch of him tonight with a feverish desperation that she couldn’t put into words.

She straddled his hips and he groaned underneath her. His fingers dug into her hips and he sat up, stubble rough against her breasts as his teeth scraped her skin.

He didn’t know this was her way of saying goodbye.

***


She ripped the last of the meat off her fish and tossed the bones to the plate. One nail scraped a scale out from between her teeth and then she spit that out as well. When she glanced up, Sung was staring at her from across the table, shaking his head in mild disgust. “I’m from here and I don’t even know how you can eat that.”

She grinned. “I pretend it’s still alive.”

He laughed. “I’d like to pretend you’re kidding.”

She shrugged and glanced around the diner again, lacing her fingers behind her head as she leaned back. She used to wonder what her opponents were doing right now, if they were kissing their husbands or wives goodbye, or tucking their kids into bed for the last time. She used to wonder who would be at their funeral or what they would be leaving behind. After a while, she’d stopped caring, because she’d figured out that the people she fought were like her.

They had nothing to lose.

No one entered Death Matches because they wanted to die, but most of them had come to terms with the idea. The ones that didn’t died in the lower tiers because they weren’t willing to sacrifice everything for the fight. Most people didn’t understand the idea that not being afraid of death wasn’t the same as wanting to die.

She was sure there were things and people she would miss if she died tomorrow, but it wasn’t enough to stop her. Once she would have felt bad for killing someone, or felt afraid that tomorrow would end with her in a black bag. She’d been a different girl once, the kind that worried about the world and people and her soul. Things had changed before she’d gotten the wolf in her genes, and they’d changed even more after that.

There was no point in worrying about the weak. In the end, only the strong survived.

She had fought long and hard to try and be the strongest, and that didn’t leave room for regret. It didn’t leave room for pity or fear, and it especially didn’t leave room for love. She couldn’t afford those things, because if she was weak she would die, inside and out. It was the way of the world and she had learned that lesson the hard way.

“That guy’s staring at you,” Sung said, nodding behind Victoria.

She shoved her thoughts away and turned halfway in her seat to look at the doorway. A small groan escaped her lips and she almost stormed out then and there, but the man had seen her and now he was headed her way and there wasn’t much she could do about it. “Sung, maybe you should take a walk,” she grumbled.

“I don’t think so,” he laughed. “That’s kind of against the point of a Keeper.”

Then the man was at their table. “Hello Victoria,” he said, taking off his glasses.

She rolled her eyes and a sigh escaped her lips. She wanted to tell him to fuck off, but if he was here than it was either about the old team or her old contract and either way she couldn’t make him leave. Unfortunately for her, she owed them, whether she liked it or not, and she should have known the expiration of a contract didn’t mean they wouldn’t come back with another one in hand. “Hello Elias. Something I can help you with?”

Elias was one of the liaisons for the big bosses and he was her favorite, not that it counted for much because she still hated the prick. He smiled and slid into the seat next to her. “Funny you should ask that.” Then he looked up at Sung. “Hey kid, why don’t you take a hike?”

Sung snorted again, half a dumpling in his mouth. “Do either of you understand what they pay me for?”

“Sung,” Victoria said sweetly. “If you stay at this table, this man is probably going to put a bullet in your head. Watching me from across the room probably isn’t against policy and it’ll save your boss a lot of paperwork.”

He glared at her before tossing his dumpling down on the table. “You’ve got five minutes,” he snapped, and then wiped off his hands to go to the bathroom.

She sighed and rubbed at her temples. “What do you want Elias?”

He started laughing. “It’s good to see you haven’t lost your touch.” He patted her on the back once before swinging around side of the booth so that he could face her. The grin never left his face the whole time and she hated that about him. He was like one of those stupid actors who always smiled because he thought it would look better for the press and make people like him more and it just made him look like a jackass. “We’ve got a job offer for you.”

She snorted. “Not interested.”

That stupid damn smile never left his face. “Now you haven’t even heard the offer yet.”

“I really don’t need to,” she said. “I’ve got a fight here in the morning and I’m really not interested in renewing with you folks. No offense, I’m sure your Christmas bonus has really improved, but I’m afraid the company and I will have to stay our separate ways. Thanks for thinking of me, maybe next time.”

He tipped his head back and laughed. “Well, that’s nicer than Alexey’s response, anyway.”

She raised an eyebrow. “You asked Alexey?”

She wanted to wipe that fucking grin off on the concrete. “Yup, and he still signed on.”

Damn it. He had her attention now, as much as she didn’t want to admit it. She played with the bones on her plate and sighed. “Alright,” she finally said, kicking at the bench. She really didn’t want anything to do with them anymore, but she wanted to know what was so interesting that Alexey had agreed to sign up for it. Last she’d checked, he was off fighting evil and Russia and didn’t want anything to do with their initial employers anymore. “What’s your offer?”

“We were hoping you and your associates could help us track down an old friend. Lyle has ah, gone missing, and he’s done so with some very sensitive property of ours. Now, if he were the only one involved it would be no problem for us to find him, but it seems the associates he was dealing with decided to kidnap him.”

“So now you want us to find him?”

Elias nodded. “And the property he stole, of course.”

Her eye narrowed. “What did he take?”

“I’m afraid that’s classified. We would of course, tell you once you agree to help us and sign a confidentiality agreement.” He chuckled, putting the sunglasses back on his face. She wondered why he was wearing them because it was dark out, and she figured it was probably because the asshole thought he was a goddamn special agent. Stupid fuck. “Here’s my number. Call me if you change your mind.”

He stood up to go and a hand on his arm stopped him. “Who else is signed up for this?”

He smiled, and this one was almost cruel. “Alexey and Jezibel are all already on board, as well as Tony and Delia. You were the hardest to track down, so you’re the last one we’re waiting on.”

“Simon?” she asked, and she knew as soon as she said it he’d tricked her into it.

“Right, did I forget him?” He grinned wickedly and then pulled his arm away. “Hope to hear from you soon, dear.”

1141.content:
She stared at the business card in her hand and thought about flushing it down the toilet.

Her teeth worried at her bottom lip and her fingers drummed on the side of the tub that was still filling up with water. Her whole body ached, and the claw marks on her side were still fresh and oozing blood every time she moved. She hadn’t skipped out on her fight, but it had been over faster than even she’d expected. They guy had been huge, like Sung said, but he’d been slow and stupid and most of all new. He didn’t understand that Victoria wasn’t going to hold back.

He also hadn’t understood that a girl half his height could be faster, tougher, and stronger, and now he never would.

She sighed and slid into the tub, letting the water soak away her aches and pains. She kept staring at the goddamn card, studying the numbers over and over again and wondering if she should call. What could Lyle have possibly taken that would piss of the Big Bosses so much and who was involved that could keep him hidden from them?

She wondered if it was really a kidnapping, or if he’d cut some kind of protection deal. She wondered if he was dead and a feral grin crossed her face because she had really never liked him. It was hard to work with someone who might be thinking about stabbing her in the back every time she turned around. She had wanted to trust him, wanted to like him even, but he was a snake through and through and had never let anyone close enough to understand what made him tick.

This day had probably been coming for a long time.

She let the number slip from her hand to the bathroom floor and tipped her head back.

She hadn’t thought about the old crew much in the last two years, partly because it wasn’t convenient, and mostly because it hurt too much. Even if Lyle Liddle was a prick, he and the others had still been like family to her. He was just the little fuck-up brother that she knew she was going to have to bail out of prison one day, and this felt like the time.

Jezibel had been her little sister, the kind that showed up in chick flicks and was into those dressing room fashion montages. She laughed a little thinking about it because she’d tried to drag her out to that kind of thing more than once and Victoria had sat on the bench with a bemused expression on her face the whole time. She’d been the only one she’d actually told she was leaving, and Jezibel had only one thing to say about it.

“Have you told Simon yet?” she’d asked.

“I’m telling him tonight.” Only that had been a lie. All she’d said was goodbye, and then she’d been gone. The only evidence she’d left behind was the picture he kept in his living room and she was pretty sure she’d left a change of clothes in his bottom drawer. She’d been so busy trying to sneak out without waking him that she’d forgotten about grabbing them.

Fuck, she didn’t want to be thinking about Simon right now.

What was he going to say when he saw her again? It was too much to hope that he wouldn’t say anything, and she didn’t have an explanation for him. She tried to turn her attention to the last member of their group that had really mattered, but it was still too close to home because now she was thinking about Alexey and he was like Simon in a lot of ways. Alexey was always getting into trouble and half the time it was Simon and Vic had to bail him out of it.

He was a good kid though, and she missed him too. She groaned and hugged her knees to her chest. She missed all of them really, more than she wanted to admit. She couldn’t pretend that the thought of working together again didn’t appeal to her because it was one of two things she’d tried not to think about in two years.

She sighed and finished up her bath, wrapping a towel around her frame and grabbing the card off the floor.

She’d known it would come to this in the end. She’d just been putting it off.

Elias picked up on the second ring, and she could even hear that fucking stupid smile on his face over the phone. “Victoria,” he said, drawing out her name. “I’ve already booked you a flight to Cairo for ten o’clock tomorrow.”

“You didn’t know what I was going to say,” she grumbled into the phone.

He laughed at her and she really wished he were here so that she could punch him in the face for it. “Of course I did. You wouldn’t be calling if you weren’t taking the job. You can sign all the paperwork at our offices in the morning, and you’ll be filled in on the rest of the details once you land in Egypt.”

“You’re a fucking prick,” she told him.

“Yup. Have a nice flight.”
