11411.content:
She reread the contents of the manila folder four times before the plane touched down in Cairo.

The first thing in there was a copy of the contract she’d signed that morning. She was tired because she hadn’t slept much the night before but she’d made herself read it through twice before she’d signed anything. It promised standard rates for a one time mission, but the part that worried her was the terms of the contracts dissolution. It basically said that if they didn’t find Lyle or what he’d stolen, they were locked back in.

She had missed it and she was cursing herself for it now.

The second thing in there was a detailed, scientific description of what exactly he’d stolen, and it was more than she’d expected. “Jesus,” she breathed after the second time she read it, because she still couldn’t believe that Tex had the balls to pull off a heist like that and that it had even been made in the first place.

Apparently Shifters weren’t the end of the line when it came to human gene manipulation. She didn’t know why she ever thought it would be, but she was kicking herself for it now. It looked to her like they’d been developing some kind of super race, a Shifter with all kinds of strength and speed capabilities and a last bit that looked like it was straight out of a science fiction novel because it gave the human part psionic capabilities.

A mind-reading fucking killing machine and a copy of the gene had been stolen by Lyle Liddle.

They were fucked.

She let her head fall back to the seat and she laughed because it was just too damn funny. Maybe he’d thought they could work it into his own system, because then he’d never have to worry about the Big Bosses or anyone ever again. He could go where he wanted, when he wanted, and no one would be able to stop him. She wondered if he had really been kidnapped or if this was just Tex’s way of setting them up, because it sure felt like the second.

The plane jolted when it hit the runway and she was still in shock when she grabbed her carry-on and started walking off the plane. She was so distracted by what she’d learned that she almost forgot about the second part of all this, that she’d be working with the old team again.

That lasted until she got to the terminal.

“Vic!” A familiar voice called, and her head twisted to her right.

There they were, three of them in a group by the sleek blue benches. Jezibel was talking to him, Simon Welsh, and of course he would be here, she’d known he was part of this. She’d just thought she’d had more time. Alexey was the one that had called her and he was trotting in her direction with a grin on his face. She gasped in surprise when he picked her up in a bear hug and then he was slapping her on the back. “How you been, bitchzilla?”

“Fuck you,” she said, slapping him lightly across the back of the head, and he laughed at her.

“Good! Glad to hear it.” He left his arm slung lightly around her shoulders as he guided her over to their small group.

“Victoria,” Jezibel smiled, the same glittering and perfect smile she’d always had that rubbed in just a little bit how rough Victoria herself was. She gave her a light hug before stepping back to study her. She shook her head, staring at the black eye patch. “Oh no dear, this will never do.”

“Nice to see you too,” she said, brushing the hand from her face.

“Hey Vic,” came a quiet rumble.

She’d prepared for this moment a thousand times over the last few hours, it was part of the reason she couldn’t sleep the night before and part of the reason she’d wanted to tell Elias to go to hell. She had imagined how it would go a thousand times, told herself she would be cool and calm and wouldn’t give him an inch. She had told him goodbye, said the words, said it in ways that didn’t involve words, and she should have been over it by now.

She kept her voice from shaking, but she couldn’t meet his eyes. “Hey Simon,” she said, and she stared at a scar on his chin so she wouldn’t have to see his expression. He looked the same, tattoos curling up under his shirt and was it really so long ago she’d been able to trace them all the way across his skin?

She realized he was staring at her, and she made the mistake of glancing at his eyes.

They made her forget why she’d ever left.

“Well, our chariot awaits, and so do Tony and Delia,” Alexey said, breaking the awkward silence. He started off towards the doors, arm still around Victoria’s shoulder and she went with him easily. She didn’t want to face him with everyone around and she didn’t want to face him alone and she wanted to go back to Bejiing where it was easier to forget.

She tried not to listen in, but she heard Jezibel’s quiet voice behind her.

“You okay?” she was asking Simon.

“Yeah, fine,” he told her. “Don’t worry about me Little Bird.”

“You’re a terrible liar, Simon,” she said softly.
11411.title: Victoria lands in Cairo without problems...

114112.content:
As soon as they stepped outside she felt the sweat break out on her forehead and she realized she was still wearing a long-sleeve shirt and jeans. She was stupid, she hadn’t even thought about the climate change. Between Elias and his stupid contract, the lingering soreness from the fight before, and the thought of seeing Simon again, she’d had more than enough on her mind. She dropped her bag on the sidewalk and proceeded to strip down to her tank top.

Alexey whistled at her and she tossed the shirt in his face. “Fuck off,” she told him with a sneer.

“You’re so violent today,” he said with a grin. “I think you’re sexually frustrated.”

“Keep it up and I think you’re going to be,” Jezibel said sweetly from behind her and Alexey’s face paled a little. At first Victoria didn’t understand what had happened. Then it hit her and her head whipped around to look at Jezibel. Apparently the shock was evident on her face because Jez blushed, looking down very intently at her shoes.

“You two?” she blurted.

Alexey laughed and shrugged, not embarrassed in the least. “What can I say? She couldn’t resist my charms.”

Simon didn’t seem phased by it, so she imagined his little brother had already told him. She wondered what else she’d missed in two years. He chuckled and ran a hand affectionately through Alexey’s hair, making him look like he’d just rolled out of bed. “Lex, you’re about as charming as a drunken hobo and smell just about the same.”

“Still makes me more charming than you,” he grinned. It turned into a yelp when his brother put him in a headlock and Victoria couldn’t help but laugh. It was almost like old times again.

The sound of tires squealing around a corner drew her attention to the road.

For a moment she just stared at the car as it whipped through the parking lot. There was something strange about it and for the life of her she couldn’t place what it was, but a bad feeling hit her gut and she started to turn back towards Jezibel when she saw the machine guns appear in the windows.

Jezibel just managed to shout “Get down!” before the gun fire started and people started screaming.

Victoria dropped to the ground seconds before the car next to her rattled as bits of metal tore through it. A tire popped and hissed and then she felt a fiery pain rip through her shoulder. She clasped her hand over the wound as blood started to spill out and she pressed her face closer to the ground while she waited for the maelstrom to stop.

Jezibel lay next to her, her white dress smudged and dirty. “Get down!” she shouted again at the small family cowering behind a van ten yards away. She didn’t understand why they hadn’t already hit the dirt but at Jez’s cry they crouched down on the asphalt, the father leaning over his children to protect them.

This was a fucking major airport. This shouldn’t be happening here.

A couple had just been walking out of the doors when the attack started and they hadn’t had time to duck. She could only watch as red flowered out from their bodies and they tumbled to the ground in a morbid pile of blood and flesh. The whole thing felt weirdly familiar and for a second her eyes shut and she could see a stone building erupting into smoke and metal as the enemy assaulted their makeshift base. She remembered screaming as a bullet punctured her lungs.

She remembered Simon holding onto her arms.

“It’s gonna be okay Vic,” he’d told her. “Just stay awake.”

She looked over at him now, and she could see Simon lying half on top of his brother but there was no sign of blood or wounds on either of them. His gaze met hers across the sidewalk and his expression was unreadable. She swallowed down the lump in her throat and pressed her cheek back into the ground while bullets rained down around her.

Then the gunfire stopped and she heard feet pounding across the ground towards them.
114112.title: They get attacked...

choices: Alexey recognizes one of the dead gunmen...
1141121.content:
Vic tensed at the sound of approaching footsteps. She felt Jez's hand lay gently on her arm and the girl whispered quieted, "God, you're bleeding."

She growled out, "It's fine," before she even knew the validity of that statement. She assessed herself quickly, finding it to be true as the pain from her shoulder could only be from a graze at most. She tried not to let the fact that she knew the difference between a bullet graze and a bullet wound upset her. Right now, someone was coming and she threw her gaze to the side to see who it was.

There were men with guns and they were aiming at her. She growled, shifting already, because she still felt Jez's hand on her arm and she knew if they shot at her, they'd no doubt his the Owl Shifter too. And there was no fucking way she would let that happen. Not to Jez. The girl, though bitchy and moody at times, was like a little sister. And she'd die before she let the smaller woman die so violently.

Turns out, she didn't have to worry. Alexey and Simon must have felt the same way.

The brothers were up and charging the gunmen before Vic could even gain her feet. Alexey flipped and whirled around like a fucking gymnast on crack, because his fox genes accepted nothing less than flexibility and show. Simon was less artsy in his fighting style, but he still had grace and speed and he pounced on the gunman without hesitation. The guns went off several times as the two knocked them away and Vic heard someone cry out in pain, but it wasn't one of hers, so she threw herself into the fray.

It wasn't like old times, like she thought it would be. Because back in the day, she would have gone to Simon's side and helped him take out his attacker. She would have teamed up with the Panther Shifter and they would have taken out bad guys like they took out the fucking trash. They had been a team. They had been partners. They'd been lovers admist battle. But not now. Because now, she helped Alexey over Simon. And she wasn't sure if it was a conscious decision or not. But she noticed it and that was enough.

There were a dozen men, all with guns. Alexey was flipping and whirling and twisting about them with agility and speed that blurred even Vic's wolf senses. She'd always liked that about the Fox Shifter. He was quick and he was flexbile, but he wasn't strong. His claws weren't as sharp as Vic's or Simons and his teeth weren't as lethal. He often didn't slash or bite, but hit or distract. It was a much different fighting style than anyone else on the team. He wasn't a killer. He was just a quick sonofabitch.

Vic took out the guys for him as he whirled and cracked the guns out of their hands and knocked heads together. She'd finish them off, following behind him ripping out throats or slashing guts. They tore threw them and it was like some kind of sick dance they'd coreographed beforehand. She found she liked it. It was beautiful.

When they reached the end of the line, Alexey crouched low to the ground, breathing heavily, his eyes darting around. He grinned wickedly at Vic, adrenaline coursing through him and she grinned back before turning around, eyes seeking out Simon. Because even though she'd followed after Alexey, even though she was pretty sure she'd done it on purpose, she would never, ever leave the Panther Shifter to fend for himself for long.

Lucky for her, Simon was handling his own. He'd taken out a few guys, who lay on the ground. One was crying out with a broken scream. The others would never scream again. Simon was still locked in combat with what seemed to be the leader of the attackers. It was a Shifter. A big Shifter. It took Vic a moment to realize she didn't know what the animal inside the Shifter was. Brown fur, massive claws, muscles that stood out starkly even against the hair covering him. He crouched and stood with knees that went backwards and she could tell that's the part that was giving Simon difficulty. This was a creature, with a weird anatomy and Simon was having trouble adapting. Plus, it was damn good at blocking every hit Simon threw at him and finding openings where he could throw his own punches back unblocked.

Simon took a punch to the face that ellicited a strangled grunt and broke something in Vic. She howled and leapt and the strange Shifter must not have been expecting it because her claws dug into his spinal cord and paralyzed him at the same time Simon threw a fist the his face and his neck snapped beneath the force of it all. He was dead before he hit the ground.

Vic's eyes came up to meet Simon's as they both shifted back to their human forms. She eyed the forming bruise on his cheekbone and he eyed the bullet graze on her shoulder.

"Are you okay?"

The both asked it at the same time. A smile crept onto Simon's face and Vic had to look away. Because she didn't like it. She didn't want to like him anymore. He would only get hurt.

Alexey's voice broke the awkwardness of the mellowing moment.

"Oh...shit."

11413.content:
His head was resting in his hands but he looked up at her when he heard her enter the room.

“I thought I was going to die,” he said. He shivered once and then looked down at his hands. He flexed them, watching the skin stretch over the muscle. His hands were calloused and covered in little scars that he’d acquired over years of fighting. “I had cancer you know.” His voice had fallen to a whisper.

“I know,” she said softly, and she did. She knew, but they never talked about it.

“I thought I was going to die,” he repeated. “I was supposed to. I had only weeks to live, until they put the cat inside me. It was all they could think of to save me.” He grew quiet and let his hands fall to the bedside. Then he looked up at her and smiled. “It worked. I just wonder sometimes…” he laughed and ran a hand through his hair. “I just wonder if sometimes this isn’t all a dream I’m having because of the cancer in my brain, you know?”

She walked over to him then, running her fingers through his hair. He pressed his face to her stomach, his hands resting on her hips as he breathed her in. “This isn’t a dream,” she told him softly, fingers sliding down his neck to where his shirt began. She started to pull it off and he leaned back to let her. “And you’re not dead.”

He looked up at her, fingers still on her hips, and normally he would be smiling, but he just looked sad. “Prove it to me,” he whispered. “Prove to me I’m still alive.”

The sound of something banging against her door woke her up.

She fell out of the bed onto the floor just as the door slammed open and someone charged in. The coffee table crashed as they slammed a boot into it and some of the splinters flew into her room. She started shifting almost immediately, but the guy was fast and he was already in her doorway by the time the claws had come out.

She leapt at him from the ground, slashing at his stomach with one hand and staying low, thinking that maybe that would help her. He howled as her claws drew bloody furrows across his chest but it didn’t slow him down any and he charged straight towards the bed. She dodged sideways and she heard a rush of air as the fist just barely missed her face. Jesus his fists were the size of fucking hams. She got hit with one of those, she was going down.

Then a hand closed around her throat and picked her up off the floor.

Her hand snapped out and claws slashed across her attacker’s face, drawing bloody lines in their skin and summoning a bestial roar from his throat. He tossed her to the side like a ragdoll, but she hit the ground rolling. She hadn’t spent the last year in a Death Match arena just to go down easy. She kicked high at his chest but it barely even budged him and then he was charging her again, hands going back towards her throat. She rolled out of the way, lashing out another kick towards his gut.

Nothing hurt this guy. She felt a sliver of fear go down her spine, and then there was nowhere else to dodge in the tiny bedroom and he was slamming her against the wall.

He held her there with an arm across the throat and caught the arm heading towards his face with his other hand. She clawed weakly at the arm holding her up and wondered who the fuck this was. “What do you want?” she gasped, claws digging into the skin of his forearm. If anything he just pressed on her throat harder and then she couldn’t form words at all.

“What did Elias want?” he asked. His voice was a low growl, barely even human anymore.

“I don’t know,” she gasped. She was seeing stars now.

He growled again, tossing her to the floor. A heavy boot landed in her gut, forcing all the air out of her lungs. She was already bruised and battered from the fight and she would be lucky if she was only limping tomorrow. Then the boot smashed into her jaw and she heard something crack.

“Try again,” he said, and the hand closed around her throat again. “What did he want? Who was he looking for?”

Her head lolled to the side. She couldn’t form words, her lips moving weakly. One of them was split and she felt blood trickling down her face. She couldn’t tell where it was coming from anymore and her head was throbbing, fiery pain lancing through her skull. He leaned down and she mouthed the words for him again.

“Fuck you,” she said, and then spit blood in his face.

He howled at her, throwing her through the door and back into the living room where she landed on the broken pile that used to be her coffee table. A sharp cry escaped her lips as she felt something pierce her side. She struggled weakly to her knees, grabbing the broken chunk of wood and pulling it from her skin. The beast was stalking across her apartment towards her and she lashed out weakly with the make shift weapon.

He snarled and batted it away before he was on her again, pressing her face into the ground. “Tell me you fucking bitch,” he said. “Tell me or you die right now. What did Elias want? Which one of you was he looking for?”

She managed a snarl and then it turned into a laugh. “Why don’t you just go ask him yourself?”

She saw a dark glint in the dim light from his eyes, and they looked like fucking snake eyes. She thought briefly of Lyle and the laughter bubbled over bloody and dark onto the floor as she realized that’s probably who he was looking for. Well, maybe the little shit hadn’t gotten himself kidnapped after all.

Then she saw him raise his fist over his head and she managed one last desperate lunge towards his neck. She felt teeth sink into flesh and blood burst in her mouth and then he was howling again and tossing her across the room. There was a crash as she slammed into the television and she felt splintered shards puncture her skin. Through increasingly blurry vision she saw the attacker stand up, hand clutched over his neck, and then she couldn’t see anything anymore.
11413.title: Someone breaks into Victoria's apartment...

114131.content:
She woke up to the sound of something dripping to the carpet.

Her first thought was that the goddamn kitchen sink was broken again, and she was pissed because she’d already had that thing replaced twice in the last year and it didn’t seem to be helping any. The plumber said something about high acid content in the water and that was going to wear away at any system she put in. She didn’t know shit about pipes and home repair so she had to take his word for it but she honestly thought he was scamming her.

She started to roll over because if it was the sink again then she was going to have a fucking mess to mop up and she might as well get started now before it got much worse. Then she felt splinters digging into her skin and she gasped at the pain because she hadn’t expected it.

Her good eye slid open and she realized the dripping sound was the blood falling from her fingertips onto the ground.

Then a gasp escaped her lips as she saw the body lying next to her.

“Fuck,” she groaned, trying to push herself up.

Pain lanced through her as she put pressure on her already wounded hand and a hiss escaped her lips. She was still lying in the remains of her broken television and she thought distantly how much it was going to be to replace it. That and the coffee table because there was no way wood glue was going to be able to fix that thing. It was massacred, the pieces strewn about her apartment and she would be lucky if she wasn’t pulling splinters out of her ass for a month.

She crawled her way out of the wreckage, trying not to look at the corpse she’d left. His eyes were empty and lifeless but she was still afraid to get close to it in case her attention would wake him up. She knew better, she knew he was dead, but the fear sat in her gut anyway and she wasn’t sure what had put it there.

Her phone was still on her nightstand, and right now it seemed really fucking far away.

She pulled herself across the remains of her apartment, hands digging into the carpet for purchase. She wondered what time it was, if she’d already missed her flight to Cairo. She wondered who had sent the bastard, if he was from the arena, the Big Bosses, or whoever had kidnapped Lyle. She would check for an I.D. in a second because she wasn’t afraid of a corpse no matter how big it was or how much it had hurt her when it was still a living, breathing person.

She knocked the nightstand over when she grabbed at her phone and the lamp fell to the floor with a deafening crash. She winced at the sound, ducking her head like she expected it to hit her. The phone bounced onto the ground next to her and she was so tired she didn’t have the energy to pick it up at first.

When she did, she just hit the redial button.

It rang three times before a groggy voice answered “Hello?” and she’d never heard Elias sound groggy before. Never mind that it was past three o’clock in the morning and he’d probably been asleep, she still expected him to sound awake and alert and like his usual prick self. This was the asshole that never went anywhere without a smile plastered on his face, couldn’t he summon a little more enthusiasm for her?

“Elias,” she said, and her voice sounded like it had been put through a blender.

His voice evened out and she heard him moving in the background. “Victoria? Everything okay?”

“No,” she told him. She shook her head and then stopped when he realized he couldn’t see that through the phone anyway. Her arm was shaking with effort of holding her up. She twisted so that she could lean back against the bed and that helped a little. “Someone’s here. I think he’s dead now, but I don’t know…”

“I’ll be there in twenty minutes,” he snapped. “Stay where you are.”

She laughed. “Don’t worry, I’m not going anywhere.”

She heard something crunch and her breath froze in her chest. “Elias,” she said softly. “Someone else is here. Be careful.” She snapped the phone shut because she didn’t know who was here and if they could hear her or already had. She’d called Elias. He knew where she was. That would have to be enough.

She heard the sound of a gun cocking and she hoped she had enough strength left in her for one last fight.
114131.title: She wakes up with a dead body in her apartment...

1141311.content:
Her hand moved quietly towards her mattress, trying to get to the small gun she kept hidden there.

A boot nudged the door open and her heart began to race. She felt some small relief when her hand closed around the handle of her gun and she raised it towards the door. It was heavier than it should have been in her hand, and she was tired, oh so tired. There was blood trickling down into her one good eye and it was making everything blurry.

She wondered if Elias would get here soon. She hoped this wasn’t someone else coming to finish the job, but there was no reason for anyone else to be here.

She almost pulled the trigger.

She would have if he hadn’t said anything.

“Victoria?” he said. The word was more of a gasp, but she would’ve known his voice anywhere. Her arm wavered, still sighting along the gun and then it fell to her side because it really was him standing in the doorway. There were circles under his eyes and his black hair was a ruffled mess. He had a gun in his hand, but he holstered it when he saw her, hurrying across the room to her side. She was surprised he even had one. Jumbo must still be a mess out there.

“Vic, fuck… are you okay?”

She almost laughed at him, but it might have hurt his feelings, and he’d only just gotten here, so instead she plastered a shaky smile on her face as she looked up at him. “Sure babe, never better.”

He smiled at her, but it didn’t quite turn into a laugh. His hand came out to grasp her chin, lifting her head so the light from the window hit her face. “Jesus,” he whispered, his eye scanning her features in quick glances. She didn’t like the way his gaze focused on her missing eye or the way it scoured the cut on her temple. His gaze was full of concern and she hated it.

She pulled her head from his grasp and looked away.

“What are you doing here?” she asked.

He sat back on his heels, and there it was, that hurt puppy dog look on his face. It was only there for a second before he smoothed it away, but she had seen it and that was enough. “I came here with Elias, he didn’t tell you?”

She shook her head. She didn’t mention that Elias had never said his name at all.

He smiled a little, but it was strained. He didn’t give the awkward silence time to settle in between them, instead sliding an arm around her back and then under her knees. She barely had time to protest before he stood, her cradled in his arms. “Jesus,” she said, trying to pretend that every little movement didn’t hurt her. “I don’t need you to fucking carry me like some damsel in distress, Welsh.”

“Shut the fuck up, Wolfe,” he told her cheerfully as he carried her into the bathroom.

She should have argued with him more, should have told him to fuck off after he set her gently down on the edge of the tub. She didn’t, so he kept going, calloused hands gentle as he peeled the bloodstained tank top off her skin. His face was like stone and she wanted to ask him what he was thinking, but he wasn’t giving anything away. He started the bath running and she felt warm water running over her feet. It came away red and she wondered if there was anything left in her veins.

“He just broke in?” he asked, and she knew he was just trying to distract her. He had a washcloth now and was cleaning the wounds on her face. She felt her forehead sting as he brushed over it and she couldn’t stop the wince. His motions paused, his gaze focusing on hers. “Vic?” he prodded gently.

“Yeah, probably an hour ago?” she shivered and looked down at the bathwater. “Is he really dead?”

“Yeah,” Simon said. “I checked the body myself.”

He turned her slowly so that he could get to the mess Jumbo had made of her back. A gasp escaped her throat as he wiped down the hole her coffee table had left in her lower back. She was lucky it hadn’t punctured a kidney or something, and then he put pressure on it and she didn’t feel lucky anymore. “Fuck,” she growled, her fingers turning white around the side of the tub. She bit her lip to keep from saying anything else because the last person she wanted to look weak around was Simon.

“Simon, how did you know to come here?” she asked suddenly.

“Elias,” he said. She winced as he pressed down on the wound again and she wondered just how much fucking blood was back there. Then she glanced over her shoulder at him and saw the look on his face. His hand was shaking and he looked exhausted. How was that fair that she was the one running on no sleep with the crap beaten out of her and he was the one that looked so tired? “He told me to stop by and check on you every few hours.”

“How considerate of him,” she growled, her eyes narrowing.

Simon shrugged. “Turns out it was.”

He turned and started rummaging through her medicine cabinet. He passed over the pain killers, pretending not to notice how empty most of the bottles were, and pulled out the first aid kit she kept on the top shelf. She looked down before he opened it, knowing it was going to be even emptier than the painkillers.

Maybe she was still alive, but she got hurt a lot in Death Matches. She didn’t want to know what he would say about that, assuming he would even say anything.

He kneeled back down next to her, the gauze in his still shaking hand.

“Simon,” she whispered. Her hand came out to rest on his forearm and he glanced up at her.

She couldn’t remember what she was going to say. Two years of silence stretched on and on between them. She could see the gap that she’d opened up, see it in the way he kept studying her face, like he was afraid if he didn’t memorize every inch of it now then he would just forget when she was gone again. “Why are you here?” she asked softly. “Why did you come here with Elias?”

“I missed you,” he told her, and then he looked at her back, pressing the gauze pad against the wound. She felt warm blood trickling down her spine and then she felt him wipe it away again.

“You don’t have to take care of me,” she told him. It came out harsher than she meant.

“If you want me to go, I will,” he said. “but not until you’re patched up and Elias gets here. I’m not leaving you here to bleed to death now that you’re not being beaten to death anymore.”
1141311.title: Simon's in her apartment

11413112.content:
“No,” she said, more quickly than she liked. “I don’t want you to go.”

“See?” He smiled, but it was a cold thing. “That’s all you had to say. You want me to stay, I’ll stay.”

“You mean like I didn’t?” she snapped. Guilt twisted into a knot around her heart and she tried hard to choke down the sensation. She looked away from him and down at the tub where water still swirled over her toes and back down the drain. “Thanks, but I don’t need shit from you, Welsh.”

She regretted the words as soon as she said them.

“Fuck you Victoria,” he snapped, and she couldn’t remember the last time she’d heard so much venom in his voice. Her head snapped up to look over her shoulder and she wanted to pretend she was feeling tears of rage stinging at her eyes and not the tears of hurt that she knew where threatening to fall.

“That’s nice, asshole,” she spat. “Why don’t you kick me while I’m down too?”

The anger was misplaced and she knew it. She was pissed that she’d been taken down by anyone, and more pissed that he of all people was the one that found her. She was pissed that he was being nice to her, and really fucking pissed that she needed his help at all. She wanted to tell him to fucking go, but it wasn’t the truth and she was a bad liar even when she was mad.

He was staring back at her, one hand still holding white gauze to the wound in her flesh, but he just looked mad and hurt.

“What did you expect Vic? You left me, not the other way around.”

“Go fuck yourself Simon.” Her hands were shaking now and she wanted to hit him. “I told you not to get attached.”

“Gee, I’m so fucking sorry that I gave a shit about you Vic. Sorry that was so fucking inconvenient for you.” His voice was rising and she had never seen so much anger in his eyes before. “If you just wanted a fuck buddy you should have been talking to Lyle. Because me? I actually cared about what happened to you.”

Her bottom lip was trembling and she felt the tears slip and fall from her eye. She turned her head quickly to stare at the wall as she swept them off her face.

“Well you can go fuck yourself,” she said.

He sighed and she felt him slap medical tape on her spine, less gently than a minute again. “You can be such a bitch sometimes,” he told her quietly.

He didn’t say anything else to her and she crossed her arms self-consciously over her bare breasts. She glanced backwards at his face and it was cold and tired. His eyes just looked distant and sad and he was barely looking at her anymore, patching up the last of her wounds with quick deft movements.

He’d had enough practice patching wounds over the years, both hers and his, and probably Alexey’s for most of his life.

She swallowed the lump in her throat and tried to ignore the sickening sensation of guilt settling in her stomach and making her sick. Her arms tightened around her chest and she knew this is the part where she should apologize. She wanted to, felt the words on her tongue, but she couldn’t force them out.

“Fuck you Vic,” he said after a moment. She heard him stand and turn to go.

She almost let him.

She glanced over her shoulder at him and he looked so tense and strained as he reached for the doorknob. She would have let him walk out, except a terrible feeling settled in her gut that if she let him go now, she would never see him again. Maybe that’s what she thought she wanted two years ago, but then she was leaving him, and she knew she could always go back.

Now he was leaving her, and she was scared it would be forever. The truth was that she had missed him, more than she would admit to herself, and now that he was here again she was terrified of losing him again. Even if it had been her fault the first time, even if it would be her fault next time, even if he hated her right now, she didn’t want him to leave. Even if he didn’t love her anymore, she still just wanted him to stay.

She didn’t know how to tell him any of it.

She forced her pride down to fester with her guilt and stood on shaky feet. “Wait,” she whispered. She licked her lips because they felt dry and chapped and they didn’t want to say the words she felt hovering on the edge of her tongue. Her steps were unsteady as she stumbled across the bathroom carpet and she felt her head pounding as the room spun around her. Then her hands met his arms and she was pressing her face into the hard plane of his back and the world fell back into place.

She breathed in the smell of him, as comforting as she remembered, closed her only eye and whispered. “I’m sorry.”

He was a stone statue. His hand still rested on the doorknob but he didn’t move to leave.

“You only say that when you want something,” he said. She could hear the quiet smile in his voice, but it sounded just as tired as the rest of him looked. His shoulders sagged as he glanced back at her, his eyes tracing her face. One of his hands came up to cover hers as she held onto his arm.

“I do,” she whispered. “I want you.”

He laughed. “You say that now,” he said to her. He turned slowly, hand still holding hers so that she didn’t fall. She wavered as the steadying force of his back left her and then he was pressing her hand over his heart, letting her head come to rest on his chest. “What happens to me when you change your mind, Vic?” His chin came to rest on the top of her head and a heavy sigh escaped his lips. “I can’t go through that again, babe. I just can’t.”

She shivered as the cold settled on her bare skin. She pressed her face harder into his chest, holding onto his shirt to keep from tipping over. The pounding in her head was increasing and she closed her eyes against it, leaning into Simon. She had missed this, the solid warmth of him, the hand on hers, and the fingers in her hair. She had missed him.

“I’m sorry,” she said again. “I missed you. I was stupid. I’m still stupid, I just… I want you.”

He tensed under her skin, and she kept waiting for him to tell her to go to hell. It’s what she would have done, if he’d just up and left her for two years without a word. She tipped her head back so she could see his face and he didn’t look sad anymore. She couldn’t tell what the look on his face was, but his breathing was quickening and he was staring at her. “Vic,” he whispered. “You’re cheating.”

Her face wrinkled in confusion. “How am I cheating?”

He laughed, and his hand left her hair to settle on her hip. “Here you are, telling me the things I want to hear most, that you honestly missed me, that you’re sorry, that you still want me and you’re telling me these things in your goddamn panties. I call that cheating.”

She laughed and pressed a kiss to the hollow of his throat. “Sorry,” she whispered again.

“You’re a cheating bitch,” he growled, and then he was kissing her. His lips claimed hers with an animal ferocity and she felt her own body rising to meet his. His tongue snaked into her mouth and his hand tightened on her hip with a groan as her teeth snagged his bottom lip. She had missed this so fucking much.
11413112.title: Vic tells him to stay

114131121.content:
She growled against his lips and her teeth were catching against his. She didn’t care about the pain, as his fingers dug into her hips and his hand brushed already bruised ribs. She wanted him to be rough. She wanted him to take her and hurt her and make her his all over again. Suddenly two years wasn’t long enough to forget how much she wanted to be possessed by him. His tongue slid against hers and he was setting her on fire with his lips.

Her hands were just sliding under his shirt when she heard the door slam open. She growled at the intrusion and at the sound of Elias’s voice as he called out, “Victoria?”

“Tell him to go away,” she said against Simon’s mouth.

He laughed and for a moment she thought he might because his fingers were playing with the band of her panties. She pressed herself tightly against him, fingers digging into his back and breath hot against his throat. His hands were sliding over her skin and making her crazy with need.

“Simon,” she breathed.

“I can’t,” he said abruptly. His hands left her hips and slid up to her arms where they rested for a moment. She tried to stretch up on her toes to kiss him again but he looked away at the last second and her lips slid over his cheek. Then he was pushing her away with a gentle, frustrating force. “Victoria…”

“Vic you here?” Elias called again. She heard the moment he found the body because he started cursing and Elias almost never cursed. He was too fucking professional and too much of a stuck up prick.

“Simon…” she said again.

He shook his head. “Not right now, Vic. We’ll talk, but not right now.”

Another growl escaped her throat and her teeth nipped possessively at his throat. “I don’t want to talk, I want to fuck,” she said.

“I know,” he said, and his voice had dropped in temperature. She scanned his face and realized she had said the wrong thing again. What did he want from her, professions of undying love? He had everything of her that she had left to give, and she didn’t know if love could ever be a part of that. She could give him her loyalty, her compassion, her body, but she didn’t know if there was anything in her that knew how to love.

“That’s why we have to talk,” he said. He pushed her gently away and steered her back towards the edge of the tub. He crouched down next to her, cupping her face in his hand and the look he was giving her caused that knife of guilt to twist itself into her stomach again. “I need to go talk to Elias. Stay here, I’ll get you some clothes.”

“Simon,” she said as he stood to go. “I really am sorry.”

“I know, Vic,” he said, closing the door behind him. He didn’t look back.

***


Elias was bent over the body, but he looked up when Simon came out of the bathroom. He barely got his mouth open to speak before the man was punching him in the mouth. He felt the hit connect with his jaw and his head snapped back. He barely had time to think of what kind of a shiner that was going to leave before he felt a fist close around his shirt collar and yank him to his feet. Simon’s eyes were narrowed and dangerous.

“Did you know this would happen?” he demanded.

Elias smirked, because he just couldn’t fucking help himself. He thought about lying, but either way he was going to get himself in trouble. He might as well get all this unpleasantness out of the way as soon as possible, and hope that Simon wouldn’t get any more physical or he’d be in trouble. “I suspected,” he said.

He saw the Shifter’s teeth grind together and he couldn’t wipe the damn smile off his face. Christ, he was about to start laughing because Simon just looked so damned mad.

“Why? What did you expect?”

“When Jez and I went to fetch Alexey from Russia, he was attacked in his apartment. Luckily both of them were there at the time, and… well they weren’t asleep, so they dealt with the attacker fairly quickly.” He smiled, straightening his tie as Simon released him, though his hands clenched at his sides like he really wanted to hit Elias again.

“Why didn’t you warn Victoria?”

Elias snorted. “Warn her of what? I didn’t know for certain until tonight that the attacker was trailing me and not your dear brother. Besides, we both know it’s Victoria we’re talking about, and she wouldn’t take a warning from me anymore seriously than she would anyone else. That’s why you were supposed to be keeping an eye open.”

“She could have died,” Simon said.

Elias grinned again. “And wouldn’t you have felt like an asshole then?”

He wasn’t surprised at the fist that connected with his stomach, but it was harder than he’d thought and he doubled over with the impact. Simon shoved him roughly away and he felt his knee hit the carpet. He was grinning as he looked up at the Shifter, but it had become a feral thing. “And that,” he said coldly, his expression never wavering. “Is the last time you get to hit me.”

***


She held her head in her hands and shook.

Her body was exhausted and it felt like it was shutting down on her. She slipped down next to the tub and rested her back against the cool porcelain. Now that Simon was out of the room and away from her, she could feel all the pain coming back to her. She didn’t even have the energy to climb up her bathroom sink and take a painkiller because she was afraid if she moved then she would start bleeding again.

Her fingers touched her lips and she could feel his kiss still lingering there. A shiver went down her spine and she let her fingers travel her face until they were running over the scars on her face. She was sure she had scars all over her body and her soul, going all the way back from when she was six years old and her father had started abusing her.

She pulled her knees up to her chest and closed her eye.

Her vision was getting blurry. She hoped it was from exhaustion and not blood loss.

The door creaked open again and she glanced up as Simon opened the door. He looked tired and irritated but he offered her a small smile, even if it was a lie. He tossed her a change of clothes, but didn’t come any farther into the room. She bit her lip hard and grabbed the old tee-shirt out of the pile. “What did Elias say?” she asked.

His gaze narrowed again. “That the attack was not entirely unexpected.”

She snorted, attempting to wriggle into a pair of jeans without standing up. It was more work than it should have been and she felt the cuts on her back split open. God, would she ever stop bleeding again? “That’s nice. A head’s up would have been good. What else?”

“You need to rest,” he said quietly.

She shook her head. “Fuck that. I want to know what’s going on.”

“Victoria,” he whispered. He sighed as she struggled to her feet but when she stumbled he reached out to catch her. He was holding her at arm’s length and she couldn’t pretend it didn’t hurt. Should she start assuming that kiss was an accident? The look on his face said no, but the way he held her away from him, like she was fucking diseased or something, felt like a yes.

“You need sleep,” he said. “You’re hurt, you’re exhausted, and we probably need to travel tomorrow. Go to bed.”

She smirked, but it didn’t reach her eyes. “Only if you come with me.”

There was that cold expression on his face again. “I won’t fuck you, Victoria.” He at least had the decency to look like he regretted saying it. It didn’t make the words hurt any less and it didn’t help that knife of guilt from twisting itself all the way up through her ribcage to her heart, but at least he looked like he felt bad about it.

“I know,” she said quietly, and now she was looking at the floor. “I just don’t want to be alone.”
114131121.title: Elias arrives at her apartment

1141311211.content:
Simon slid an arm under her shoulders and helped guide her out of the bathroom. At least he wasn’t carrying her this time, though she wasn’t sure that was a good thing now. She felt the distance between them like an open wound, but she was too tired to fight him. Her head was fuzzy and she didn’t know what she wanted from him except that she didn’t want to be just friends and she didn’t want him to leave her right now. She had missed him, despite everything.

Elias was on his phone when they limped into the living room.

“I want your best investigators and a clean up crew here by ten o’clock,” he was saying. “Find out who this guy is and how he’s been following me. This is the second massive asshole that’s tried to go after one of my contacts and I want to know who sent him and where he came from.”

There was a moment of silence and he glanced up at the two of them. “Go to bed,” he said. “I’ll take care of this.”

Victoria nodded, but her gaze lingered on the corpse in her living room.

She had competed in dozens of death matches, but somehow this had felt different. He had come onto her turf and he had almost won. She knew she shouldn’t have been standing at all. It had been a lucky hit that had taken him out and he easily could have ended her before he’d gone down. A split second either way could have her just as cold a corpse right now, and Simon would have been the one to find it. Probably not the reunion he was hoping for.

He pushed the door to her bedroom open and she was almost embarrassed by it. It wasn’t messy, because she liked to keep things neat and utilitarian. It was just so bare. She had her bed, with plain green sheets on it, a dresser that had the usual jeans and tank tops, and a night stand that was on the floor.

It was a hotel room. It wasn’t a home; it was just a place she slept.

She missed his place, because it was messy and the bed smelled like Simon and she was at home there. She had bitched about having to pick up his jeans off the floor every morning and how he always left his dishes in the sink instead of washing them, but right now she missed all that because it was normal and comforting and she’d been happy.

He set her on the edge of the bed and bent down to straighten the mess she’d made.

“Do you hate me?” she asked quietly.

He stilled for a moment but didn’t look up at her. Then his hands started moving again, sweeping the remains of her lamp into his palm so that he could dump them in the trashcan. “No,” he said. “I don’t hate you.” Then he turned to face her and he looked as tired as she felt. His eyes didn’t meet hers as he helped her pull the jeans back off and it was almost funny that she’d gone through all that work just to walk from her bathroom to her bedroom.

She crawled under the sheets first and she was ready to fall asleep before her head hit the pillow.

She felt the bed move as he lay down next to her, but he didn’t make any move to touch her. She rolled over, fingers brushing his arm and she could see his eyes in the predawn light just coming through her window. “Simon?” she whispered and he grunted in response, trying to pretend that he wasn’t still wide awake.

“Will you just hold me?” she asked, and it was the closest she would ever come to admitting how afraid she’d been that she was going to die alone in her apartment two hours ago.

He understood. She knew he did because he wrapped his arms around her and held her against his chest.

“Go to sleep, Victoria,” he said, and for once she did what he told her.

***


She dreamed about gunfire.

She dreamed about pressing her back to the wall and holding her gun between her legs as the world around her was riddled with holes. Clay and dust fell on her in chunks and she fought against the cough rising in her throat because when the gunfire was over she was going to kill the bastards who were shooting at her.

Next to her were the two brothers and Alexey was laughing maniacally. She could see Jez in the corner and she was rolling her eyes at him. Victoria could understand what Lex was feeling though, because she felt it too. The adrenaline pumped through her veins and she knew that the second the gunfire stopped they would be over the wall and ripping some assholes a new one.

Simon smiled at her. “You ready?” he asked.

She gave him an animal grin in return. “Always.”

Opposite her she could see Lyle trying to get a good shot out of his sniper rifle. He was crouched behind the remains of the wall and he had his goggles pulled down over his eyes so she couldn’t see the snake eyes looking out at her. The sun glinted off his scope and she watched as he swung the barrel of the gun until it was pointed at her head.

Then he grinned, and whispered “Bang.”

***


At first she couldn’t remember where she was.

It felt so familiar, the sensation of waking up in Simon’s arms. She made a noise in her throat that couldn’t pass for any word she knew and rolled over into him. She felt sore and for a minute she couldn’t remember why, but it wasn’t a new sensation so she wasn’t worried about it. Her lips brushed his skin and she felt him grumble something in his sleep.

His arms tightened around her as she bit gently on the skin at his throat. She trailed kisses up his neck and then his ear and she was tugging on it with her teeth.

Then his hand closed around her arm and his eyes slid open.

“Victoria,” he whispered, and the expression was so unlike what she’d expected that it brought her back to painful reality. The playful smile fell off her face and she pulled her lips away from his skin, swallowing hard. She had forgotten that he didn’t want her anymore, because she had fucked up.

Her head fell back to her pillow and she pulled her fingers back from his skin.

“Sorry,” she told him.

He sighed, his hand coming out to catch hers again. “Victoria,” he said. His voice was a harsh whisper. His hand squeezed hers, and then brought it back to his chest. “I guess we should talk.”
1141311211.title: They go to bed

11413112111.content:
His hand curled around hers on his chest and she felt him take a deep breath. She was suddenly afraid of what he was going to say next, because this felt like more than just him being afraid to get hurt again. She wondered if he was about to tell her he’d found someone else, and she felt her heart slam against her ribcage. Jealousy was a bitter taste in her mouth and she tried to swallow it down. She had left him. He had every right to move on; he should move on, she was bad for him. She was the girl he couldn’t bring home to mom, the one that had broken his heart once and would do it over and over again.

She was a fucking liar who couldn’t tell him the truth when it mattered most. She was the bitch who kept her secrets locked in the back of her mind so that they could fester and rot in the darkness where no one would have to face them, not even herself. She was dead inside and Simon was the only one who’d made her feel alive, so he was the one she hurt the most.

“I know,” he said quietly. He wasn’t looking at her face, and she was confused.

“You know what?” she asked him.

His eyes met her and he looked so fucking miserable that she almost wished she hadn’t asked. He took a heavy breath, and the hand around her hand tightened, squeezing so hard it almost hurt. Then his other hand came out and rested on her abdomen. “I know,” he whispered again, and now her heart was thundering so heart in her chest she thought it was going to claw its way through her skin and die a slow death on the bed. He swallowed hard, his eyes begging her to say something back.

She shook her head, and suddenly she was on the verge of tears again. She hated that fucking pitying look she saw staring back at her, that defeated, sad look, and she felt herself punching him in the chest. “Fuck you,” she snarled, pushing his hand away from her abdomen and away from the thin white scars that his fingers had brushed over.

“Fuck you Simon, you don’t know a fucking thing.”

She was punching wildly now and she couldn’t stop the tears or the sobs that ripped their way out of her chest because she had tried to forget that, tried to bury it in dark corners and pretend it had never happened. It was most of why she left, because she was scared and confused and didn’t know what to do. She had fucked up, and he wasn’t supposed to ever find out about it and she hated him and she hated herself more. Her fist hit his chest again and then she felt his hands around her wrists, pinning them to the bed just to stop her from hurting him. “Victoria,” he said, and she thrashed her head from side to side.

“Fuck you,” she snarled.

Then she just couldn’t fight anymore and her head fell to the side, tears streaming off onto the pillow.

He rested his forehead against hers, his hands still pinning her wrists down, and she could feel his breath heavy and strained across her face. “I’m sorry Vic. I’m so fucking sorry,” he whispered, and it just made the tears fall harder. She couldn’t look at him, couldn’t breathe, because he was never supposed to know and it must have been fucking Jezibel that told him because the girl was the only one who knew what had happened.

“I lost it a few months after I left you. It was the fight I lost my eye in,” she whispered, still not looking at him. She stared out into the dark room and tried to pretend that everything didn’t hurt right now. She was going to yell at Jez when she talked to her again, if she ever spoke to her again, because right now all she wanted was to run across the world again and disappear into corners so dark that no one could find her again. She swallowed the lump in her throat and her lips kept moving, even though she wasn’t sure she wanted to say the words aloud.

“I was scared,” she said. “I didn’t know what to do, so I kept fighting.”

She looked him in the face now, feeling the tears drying on her face. He still hadn’t said anything, but he released her wrists slowly, now that he was sure she wasn’t going to try and hit him anymore. She rested them over her stomach, fingers tracing the scars where the Shifter’s claws had pierced her skin. It was an unsanctioned move, just like the hit that took her eye, and it never should have happened that way.

“How’d you find out?” she asked, glancing at his face.

“Jezibel called me from the hospital after the fight,” he said. He didn’t look mad, just depressed and tired. He scrubbed a hand through his hair and shook his head at her. “She told me the truth, told me what had happened. Why couldn’t you just tell me, Vic? We would have figured it out.”

“I didn’t want to figure it out,” she said. “I just wanted to pretend nothing had changed.”

His hand cupped her face. “Vic… it doesn’t work that way.”

She laughed at that, and then she cried. “I know. I know it doesn’t, but I wanted to pretend it does. You know the worst part? Some part of me was relieved. Some part of me was relieved when I lost it because I was so fucking scared,” she told him. “I hate myself for that. I understand if you hate me too.”

“I already told you I don’t hate you, Vic.”

His voice was gentle, and his hands covered hers on her stomach. She couldn’t look at him anymore and she looked away.

It didn’t matter if he was telling the truth or not, she still couldn’t stop hating herself for it. She took a breath, trying to keep from crying again. She hadn’t been ready for the responsibility. She had found out the day her contract ran out from a home pregnancy test. She had promised Jez that she would tell Simon before she decided once and for all if she was leaving or not, but then she’d gone over that night and she just couldn’t do it. She’d panicked. She’d a total break down and she had run like there was no tomorrow, from him, from everything.

She hadn’t really understood what it meant until she’d lost it, and by then it was too late. She’d already been a few months into it and they’d had to cut the corpse of her baby out of her womb. They said it was a boy. She wondered if he would’ve looked like his daddy, and she felt the tears come again.

“I’m sorry,” she told him.

He pulled her up to his chest and she let him hold her there while she cried out the last two years into his chest. “Me too,” he said quietly. “I’m sorry too.”
11413112111.title: They have their conversation...

114132.content:
Simon was on top, his hands running through her hair.

“I love you,” he said, and it startled her because he’d never actually said those words before. She started to sit up, but his weight held her down and then he moved and a small gasp escaped her throat. “I love you,” he said again, his lips brushing her neck. She knew this was a dream, knew this had never happened before because maybe if he’d said the words she never would have left, or maybe she would have left that much sooner but it was a really good dream.

He moved inside her and she clutched at his arms, gasping at the sensation. This wasn’t like them, because they never went slow. She never let him. Fucking was always like fighting with them, all rough hands, teeth and nails and most of the time it left them with bruises. She tipped her head back to kiss him and he tasted just like she remembered.

“I love you,” he said a third time, and then he smiled. “That’s why I’m sorry.”

His hands moved from beside her head to around her neck and at first she didn’t understand. “Simon, what…?” Then his fingers were digging into her throat and she couldn’t breathe. She clawed at his arms but they were like steel around her skin and she felt them crushing her windpipe. She hit desperately at his chest and his face and he didn’t flinch, didn’t move, and his eyes glittered like snake eyes in the dark bedroom.

Stars were bursting in her vision and she felt her lungs start shutting down.

He leaned down, his lips brushing her ear. “What did Elias want?”

Then she woke up.

At first she just lay there, taking stock of what hurt and where. It felt like there was still blood trickling down her forehead and she could taste it on her lips. Her tongue probed at the gash, tasting the familiar metallic tang flood her mouth. Her arms were throbbing and she remembered distantly the sensation of smashing into her television, the tiny shards embedding themselves into her skin. She was fighting for every breath and she wondered if one of her lungs had collapsed.

Also, her throat was really fucking sore.

She couldn’t see anything at first and fear lanced through her. Maybe she’d lost her other eye now too. Maybe she was going to be blind for the rest of her life. She didn’t know if she could handle that and she felt panic blossoming in her chest. If she lost both eyes then she was done professionally. She would end up in a lab with all the other Shifters that had lost their contracts or gone rogue because she wouldn’t be able to fight or hunt or do any of the things that kept her free.

She took a breath and reached up towards her face. Her fingers brushed over the empty space where her left eye used to be and then it traveled over to the right one. She realized she wasn’t breathing and then her fingers brushed over the gauze on her face. A sigh of relief swept through her and she peeled it back.

Well, at least she was still only half blind.

She was lying in a bed, but it was hard to tell in the dim light if the sheets were gray or blue. She was heavily bandaged and she felt her chest constrict when she took a breath. She wondered if any of her ribs were broken and she prodded at them, wincing at the pain she felt on her right side. It was hard to tell anymore what injuries were from what. The last two days, if it had been only two, felt like a haze of blood and pain.

She couldn’t tell if she was in a hospital, because if she was it was the quietest one she’d ever been in, and the darkest. She could barely see across the room, but that was partially due to the gauze still covering half her face and the blood in her eye. She tried to blink it away.

She was still trying to figure out where she was when she heard an all too familiar voice from the corner of the room. “Hey Vic,” he said. “About damn time you woke up.”
114132.title: Vic wakes up somewhere else entirely...

choices: Vic doesn't trust Lyle at all
1141322.content:
She remembered the day she’d met Lyle “Tex” Liddle.

He’d been hitting on Jezibel, because everyone hit on Jezibel, but he had this look on his face that seemed like he didn’t even want to be talking to her. She got a bad vibe off him, and no matter how much she wanted to like him, she found that she just couldn’t. If she were really a wolf her hackles would be raised and she would be growling every time he walked in the room. He hadn’t given any of them a reason not to, but everyone knew instinctively that this was a man not to turn their back on.

He looked like he was trying to be the goddamn Marlboro man, his blonde hair hidden under a brown Stetson and a cigarette hanging from between his lips. He looked like he hadn’t shaved in a couple days and he completed the look with dirt smudges on his jeans and on his brown snakeskin boots.

“You know what they say about Texans…” he said, winking at her as he leaned against the wall.

“That they’re compensating for something?” Victoria said, stopping next to Jez.

He glanced at her and the look sent shivers down her spine. It wasn’t mean or irritated, it was just appraising. She remembered hearing about some girl a few years ago who’d let her boa constrictor sleep in her bed with her. After a while the snake started sleeping stretched all the way out next to her, and then it had stopped eating. She took it to the vet, and it turned out the snake was sizing her up to see if he could swallow her whole.

That’s what she saw when Lyle Liddle looked at her. He was a snake, trying to see if he could swallow her whole.

“Lyle,” she said. She forced herself into a sitting position.

He looked almost exactly as he had that first day she’d met him, though there were a lot more scuffs on the snakeskin boots, and the Marlboro man was short a cigarette or three. He leaned forward into the dim light when she said his name and she saw a wicked scar running from the corner of his lip up towards his eye. “How you been?” he asked, and the deadness of his eyes made her wonder if he really even cared if she answered.

“I’ve had better days,” she said.

He chuckled dryly. “I’ll bet.”

“So,” she began. “Are you the one I have to thank for Jumbo’s visit?”

He laughed again, reaching into his pocket for a cigarette. “You’re a quick one, aren’t you?” She couldn’t tell if it was sarcasm or not, so she didn’t say anything, waiting for him to answer. He ignored her for the moment, sticking the cigarette in his mouth and flicking his zippo open. A tiny flame shot to life and it gave her a better view of the room for a split second. There was no carpeting or windows, and she was getting the impression from the giant vent in the ceiling that this was no apartment.

Then he snapped the lighter closed, studying her through the haze of smoke. “What did Elias want with you?” he asked.

She laughed. She couldn’t help herself, and even when it turned into a cough she kept laughing. “Right, so you admit you send that fucking monstrosity to beat the shit out of me, and then you expect I’ll start talking as soon as you drag me back to your bachelor pad? What the fuck, Lyle?”

He grinned and shrugged. “Can’t blame a guy for trying, but alright. How about quid pro quo then?”

“That works more in your favor than mine, doesn’t it?”

He laughed, shaking cigarette ash out on the floor. “So he didn’t even tell you why he’s looking for me, did he?” He shook his head, clucking his tongue in mock disappointment. “Elias is looking for me because he wants what I have, and he doesn’t want the Big Bosses to get it first.”

“Bullshit,” she said. “Elias isn’t stupid enough to try and cross them.”

He raised an eyebrow at her. “You think so?”

There was the problem. She didn’t think Elias would try and double cross the organization, but she didn’t know for sure. She also couldn’t tell if Lyle was lying to her because if he was a master of anything, it was that. He was considered a snake for a lot of reasons, not just because of his Shifter form, and not just because of those stupid fucking boots. “Alright,” she said. “What do I have to tell you so that I can get out of here?”

He smiled, and he tried to make it pitying but it just came out mocking. “Can’t let you go right now, Vic. Sorry. My other associates would probably be pretty pissed if they even knew you were alive after seeing me here.”

“I see,” she said coldly. “Then they can go ahead and just fucking try to kill me.”

He laughed again, spinning the butt of his cigarette off onto the floor. “I’m sure you’d win. Most of them are just goddamn suits.”

“How nice for them,” she snapped.

He sighed, leaning forward. “Listen Victoria, I always liked you the best, so I don’t want this to go badly. I just really, really need you to tell me what Elias wanted from you. Was he trying to hire you back? Does he have the old team looking for me? Does he have the backing of the Big Bosses… never mind, scratch that last one, you wouldn’t know if he didn’t. But seriously here Vic, if you want me to try and help you out, you’re going to have to throw me a bone.”

The speech almost worked on her. If she didn’t know him any better she might have believed him. He looked so desperate and scared. She wondered again what he’d taken that was so important, and if maybe he was telling the truth about Elias. If he was, he might honestly be her best shot at getting out of here.

Then again, if he was lying, the Big Bosses would bring hell down on him, and her for trusting him.

Vic took a good long look at Lyle. She wasn't sure if she trusted him. She wasn't sure if she ever had. But he'd been like family once and that had to count for something. She wasn't sure if he'd ever felt the same, but back in the days, he'd give people looks that she just couldn't figure out. He'd given Alexey many of the strange looks, usually when the Fox Shifter had been making fun of Texas or cowboys or something to try and rile Lyle up. He'd given the look to Jez a few times when she seemed oblivious to his charm. He'd give it to Simon just once, when he'd beat the fuck out of some guy for almost killing Lyle. He'd given Vic the look many times and she couldn't remember what she'd done to garner it. But he was looking at her with that look right now. And she thought she finally understood what it meant. It was admiration. And it wasn't something he gave out often.

And looking into those god damn yellow snake eyes right now, she could see it. She could see it clearly. He admired her for taking a beating and still ticking. She wondered if she was going to disappoint her when she agreed to help him. She hoped not.

"If you're fucking lying to me, or if you fucking betray me, I'll kill you, so help me god," she dug out, staring at him with her one eye to make sure he knew she wasn't kidding around. His brow rose in feigned surprise, but she watched his face for signs of disappointment or other emotions. He didn't seem phased. He seemed happy. And they both knew what she meant, even if Lyle wasn't 100% sure on what Elias had told her, he already knew the answer. He just needed verbal confirmation.

If he hurt the team or got any one of them killed with whatever stunt he was trying to pull off, she'd fucking kill him.

Lyle snorted and pulled out another cigarette. He lit it and then made a half hearted crossing motion over his heart. "I swear, Vic," he grinned and the words sounded slimy, and she tried to convince herself that he was telling the truth. She had doubts. But she didn't have a choice. "Tell me what Elias told you and I'll help you out of here and that'll be the last you see of me."

She highly doubted that, but she narrowed her eye and whispered to him anyway. "He signed me up to retrieve you and whatever the fuck you stole from the Big Bosses."

"Who else did he get?" he demanded, apparently done joking around. Damn, he must really be needing answers.

"The team," she answered simply, trying not to feel like she was betraying them. She didn't want to say their names outloud.

Lyle raised an eyebrow. "All of them?"

"The ones that fucking count."

He snorted and the grin was back on his face. He leaned back in his chair, pulling the cigarette from his lips to tap the ash on the ground. He seemed to be thinking and Vic gave him some time. She had questions of her own, but she knew Lyle was the dominant one in this situation. She didn't want to push. She didn't want to make him mad.

Lyle's voice was quiet when he spoke. "He's going to get them killed." The drawl was thick in his voice and Vic had to pause a moment because the words and the way he said them were so...unnatural on his tongue that she wondered if there was a speaker in the room and someone else had said them. There were truth to these words, and it made her wonder if she'd ever heard actual emotion come from him before. Lyle's eyes came up to meet hers for a moment before he leaned forward, face falling a bit. "The people I work for now, they won't hold back, Vic. They'll kill the team, all of them. And they'll make it bloody, just to prove a point to Elias."

"Who do you work for?" she asked.

He had the decency to laugh. "Sorry, Wolfe, that's a secret."

"I want to talk to them."

Lyle snorted. "Not gonna happen."

"I have information about the team," she found herself saying before she had a chance to think her plan through. "I can tell them how they work, how they operate. I want in."

Lyle sighed, seeming to catch on to what she was trying to do. "Vic, I have all the same information."

She shook her head. "Not like me. I know how Elias works. I was his second in command for a year, I know how he operates, I know how'll he command the team. Let me talk to them."

"This isn't going to work," and he almost sounded sorry that he even had to tell her that.

"I want in, let me talk to them."

Lyle ran a hand over his face and Vic watched him think. She hoped she knew what she was doing. She hoped she could talk to his new employers, get the scoop on what he stole, infiltrate from the inside and protect the team. How, she'd figure out later. Right now, she just needed Lyle to get her to the employers. He shook his head. "If they've already signed on, they're already dead, Vic," Lyle let out slowly. She bit her lip. "No matter what you think you can do, they won't let the team walk away. If they signed the paper, they're done. They're the walking dead."

"We'll see."

He eyed her for a few more moments before he turned and left without another word. She could only lean back and hope she knew what she was doing.

She sat up as far as she could, hands resting limply on her knees. She was in a terrible bargaining position right now and she knew it, but at least she had that tiny scrap of information that he wanted and maybe it would keep her alive. She felt the bandages shift around her midsection and the terrible warm, wet sensation of blood beginning to trickle down her side. If he decided to come after her now she might not win.

“Sorry Tex,” she told him. “But I trust you about as far as I can throw you right now.”

He laughed and shook his head. “That’s too bad. It really is.” He sighed and leaned back in his chair and he was digging for another cigarette. “I thought maybe we could help each other here. I thought maybe you of all people would understand…” He sighed, lighting up and blowing smoke at her face. “There’s a revolution coming Vic, and it’s coming faster than you know. People are a thing of the past, we are the future.”

She raised her eyebrow at him. “Right and you’re going to usher in the new era? That’s all bullshit Lyle. You don’t care about the world or the people in it. Why don’t you tell me what’s really in it for you? Is it money? Jesus, who the fuck trusted you enough to steal from the Big Bosses?”

He grinned. “Tell me what Elias said, and I’ll tell you. Who’s he got looking for me and where are they?”

She shook her head at him. “Not going to happen, Tex.”

He laughed, standing up from the chair and heading towards the door. His snakeskin boots clicked loudly on the cement and the sound felt so final in the stillness. He paused with his hand on the latch and glanced over his shoulder at her. “I’m sorry it came to this, you know? If you’d just told us what you knew in your apartment we could have left you there instead. Maybe you could have gotten out of this in one piece.” Then he yanked the door open, waving a hand at her from over his shoulder. “I’ll tell them not to mess up what’s left of your face too much.”

“Hey Lyle,” she called. He paused in the doorway and his snake eyes slid over his shoulder to meet her one good one. “Do you think you can trust your associates? Do you honestly think they won’t betray you too?”

He smiled at her. “I’ll worry about me, Wolfe. You just worry about you.”

Then he was gone, the door snapping shut behind him.

She took a hurried breath and then started to roll out of the bed. Her movement stopped abruptly when she felt something tug on her ankle. She jerked her foot again and heard metal banging against metal. “Fuck,” she growled, ripping the sheets of the bed to reveal a chain running from her leg to the end of the bed. The thing was freaking huge, each link about as big as her thumb, and she would have smiled if she weren’t so annoyed. At least they weren’t underestimating her, for all the good it was doing her.

She sighed and dropped the sheets back down. Her arms were stinging now, all the little cuts and scraps whimpering in silent protest with every movement. Her head was starting to hurt and a tentative touch to her skull came away bloody. They’d bandaged her up at least, though it sounded like that wasn’t going to last long.

“Fuck you Lyle,” she growled darkly, yanking on the chain. Fuck him and fuck Elias.

She shouldn’t have taken the contract. Maybe if she’d just told him to go to Hell like she wanted then she wouldn’t be here now. Then again, maybe she would still be here with an even smaller idea of what was happening. She pressed her heels to her eyes, trying to focus enough to untangle the mess. There were at least two major parties involved, plus Elias and Lyle and she couldn’t figure out which one of them was really on her side.

She would have to get out of here and find the Big Bosses.

She wished Simon or Alexey were here. They would figure out a way to get out of this mess.

If Jezibel was here she’d be able to tell what was going on. Jez was good at seeing through all the bullshit to the person underneath. That was part of the reason she and Vic had been friends when anyone else probably would have been scared off early on. The girl had a knack for understanding what made people tick, and she had never hated Lyle, even if she never trusted him. She would have been able to tell Vic whether or not he was telling her the truth.

It didn’t matter because none of them were here. She was on her own.

She heard the door open and she pulled herself off the bed, trying to keep it between her and whoever was in the doorway. “Get the Hell away from me,” she said, and she almost hoped it was Lyle again because at least he’d just talked to her and she had a bad feeling about whoever was here now.

The man came into the room. He never turned the lights on, but the dim glow from the hallway illuminated a briefcase in his hand. For a second she thought it was a fucking suit and then she realized that it probably didn’t contain paperwork. “Please sit down, Miss Victoria,” and his voice was cold and smooth. She watched him set the case down on a metal table and undo the snaps and her heart thundered rapidly in her chest when she saw the collection of tools and needles inside. He was a goddamn torturer. Lyle had sicced a fucking torturer on her.

“Fuck you,” she said, her voice stronger than she felt. He laughed, and snapped his fingers.

A second form appeared in the doorway, and a groan escaped her throat. “Didn’t I already kill you?” she asked Jumbo, and the torturer laughed quietly. He stepped out of the shadows and she could see his face now. She didn’t recognize him, but then she hadn’t expected to. There was a needle held up in one hand and his eyes were cold shards of glass in his face.

“Back on the bed, if you please,” he said.

She stumbled back, crouching into the best fighting position she could manage with that goddamn chain around her ankle. She felt the blood began to ooze down her side and she felt all her cuts stretch and burn. She couldn’t let them see it, or that the pain in her head was starting to make her dizzy. Weakness was what got people killed. Strength was the only thing that mattered. “What part of ‘fuck you’ did you not understand?” she growled.

“The part where you don’t have a choice,” he said. Then Jumbo or Jumbo’s fucking clone was in the room and the kick she threw at his chest mattered just as much as it had in her apartment. He knocked it aside, grabbed her by the throat and forced her back onto the bed. She heard the quiet click as handcuffs closed around her wrists and then she felt something piercing her neck.

She tried not to cry out. She bit the sound off of her tongue and tasted blood in her mouth.

Jumbo’s hand covered her mouth and she heard the torturer again.

“Just hold still,” he said. He was smiling. “This will only take a second.
