She was dreaming.

At least, she hoped she was dreaming because the alternative was that the bone of her index finger really was snapping like a twig under the pressure of a pair of pliers. If she wasn’t dreaming than it meant it was her voice she heard screaming into the darkened room and her throat that was raw and sore.

She was dreaming, and in her dream Simon was brushing the hair from her face. “I miss you,” he said, and she believed him. She was sorry she had left. Even if she didn’t say it out loud, even if she didn’t dare to think it most days, she was sorry she had walked away from all of them. She was just sorry about him most of all. She was sorry she had let herself fall in love with him and sorry that it still hurt after all this time.

She was sorry she couldn’t let him go.

She was talking, and she didn’t know what she was saying.

Her head was swimming and she wondered what they had injected her with because it was making her see things and she couldn’t tell the difference between awake and asleep. She blinked hard and there was a man in a suit sitting next to her and his vision blurred. “Elias?” she tried to say, and she wasn’t sure if the words actually came out of her lips or if they just floated there in the back of her head like the dreams.

He grinned at her and that looked like Elias. “Victoria,” he said. “What was I saying to you?”

She rolled over the side of the bed and threw up on his shoes and it made her giggle like a little girl. What did Elias want? She couldn’t remember but she thought it was important. Her head was swimming with the pain and the drugs and she felt something piercing her arm and she screamed again. She let the screams come out because the alternative was crying and she didn’t cry.

Only Simon could make her cry. When he looked at her with those puppy eyes of his and whispered in the back of her mind “Why did you leave me?” it made her cry. When he was half asleep and his arm draped over her stomach and his lips pressed tightly against her neck as he whispered “I love you,” in a mumble that promised he wouldn’t remember he’d said it in the morning, it made her cry.

“Elias?” she asked again, shaking her head as she tried to clear it. “Did you bring the contract?”

He leaned forward in his chair, and he smelled like smoke. “What contract?”

She shook her head again and this time the world spun around her. She didn’t understand the question, didn’t understand why she hurt so bad and she couldn’t remember where she was. Was she still dreaming? She couldn’t tell anymore. “Don’t be stupid Elias, you’re the one that came to me,” she mumbled. She felt numb and her skin was crawling over her bones. With a slow certainty she realized she was high and she didn’t remember taking anything.

It had been years since she’d even tried drugs. She’d still been a teenager and then her teeth chattered as she wondered if maybe she was still a teenager or maybe she’d been in a coma for the last ten years and if maybe the whole thing had been a dream. She wondered if Simon was a dream and remembered him asking her that same question.

She had proved to him they were both alive, why was she so confused?

“Remind me again,” he said.

“You wanted me to look for Lyle,” she told him. “You were sending me to Cairo… but he’s not there, he’s here…” her eyes narrowed and she tried to shake the fog from her brain but it just made it worse. Something pricked her fingers and she winced because it hurt more than it should. Her head fell to the side and her left hand lay next to her head. All her fingers were crooked and thick bruises had made the skin swell.

Blood trickled down her hand to her arm and she followed the trail of red to her midsection. It had bloomed all over her body and she couldn’t remember where half the cuts had come from. She remembered hitting her television, was that it? Because she didn’t remember breaking her fingers but they looked broken now.

She smelled smoke again and her eyes rose to Elias.

“Where’s Simon?” she asked. She thought he was supposed to be here and she missed him. She missed him so much that it made her chest hurt and she tried to breath but her lungs were constricted and she felt like crying. Was he okay? Had he been okay after she left or had she just broken him even more? She knew he loved her and that had driven her halfway around the world because she was so afraid to be loved.

She was afraid that maybe he would see past all the bullshit and realize who she really was inside.

She was nothing. She was a ghost. She was just a dead shell of a girl.

She had died once. Someone she had loved had killed her and she was terrified that if she cared about anyone again then she would realize that she had either never come back to life or that all that waited for her was a second death. She wasn’t afraid of dying, but she was afraid of letting someone kill her, inside and out.

“Why do you ask?” Elias asked her, but she couldn’t remember what they were talking about.

She looked at him and realized she didn’t recognize him. He didn’t look like Elias anymore, he looked like a slender man with graying hair and he had gloves on. The white gloves were splattered with blood and she wondered whose it was. “Are you a doctor?” she asked quietly.

He chuckled and pulled a syringe out of a suitcase. “Something like that,” he told her, flicking the air bubbles out of it and then he was pressing the needle into her neck. It pinched, but she still felt numb and foggy so she barely winced at the pain.

Then he leaned down by her ear. “Who else is looking for Lyle?”

She laughed and it hurt and turned into a cough. She choked on the blood in her throat and then she was throwing up again and her stomach hurt and her legs and arms and side and her everything hurt. Her head was pounding and there was a red fog over everything. Her right hand came up and played over the scars where her eye used to be and she felt like a broken thing. She was used up and hollowed out and she missed Simon because he made her feel like a person again.

“Everyone,” she said. “Everyone’s looking for him. The Big Bosses, Elias, the old crew…he took something… something important…” she trailed off and stared at the ceiling trying to remember, but Elias had never told her what he’d taken. Lyle himself hadn’t told her and she tried to remember where she’d seen him.

Her head fell to the side and she looked at the nice doctor. “What did Lyle take?”

He smiled. “I’ll tell you later. Was there anything else?”

She shook her head. “No, nothing, why…? Why don’t you know all this? Wasn’t Elias here? Did you tell him about Jumbo because I was half asleep and he was fucking huge.” She started coughing and her fingers dug into the mattress and as soon as they did pain splintered through her arm and her mind. A sharp cry escaped her lips and it helped to sober her up a little. “Where am I?” she asked, because she couldn’t remember how she’d gotten here.

Where had she seen Lyle? Wasn’t he just…

Oh. Fuck.

A shock ran through her body and she felt her back arch off the table.

Her eyes slid open and she could see needles sticking out of her skin, running down her arms and her chest in lines. The shock hit her system again and her muscles jerked violently. Something was on her mouth, running down her throat and she started to choke on it. She tried to cough or swallow and it just hurt. She tried to pull it out with her hand but they wouldn’t move because of the white straps holding her down.

“Fuck, why is she waking up?” she heard the voice from across the room, but she didn’t recognize it. The sound of footsteps echoed across the tile and she tried to shake her head and tell them no but she was going into panic mode because she couldn’t move and she was choking.

Something pierced her skin. She felt numbness flood her and then the blackness came again.

***


Her eyes slid open. There was a bright light over her head, and she could hear the quiet beeping of a heart monitor next to her. She blinked again, her movements sluggish and slow as she tried to look around the room. White gauze was wrapped around her neck and her abdomen but she couldn’t remember why it was there. Her eyes slipped shut for a moment and she had a sudden flash as she remembered thick fingers digging into her neck.

Her hands started shaking. Oh God, was he here?

Her head fell to the side and she could see a man sleeping in the chair next to her bed.

Please no, she thought quietly. She bit her lip so that she wouldn’t cry because he liked it when she cried. It just excited him more, and then he would hurt her more. She took a shaky breath and swallowed down the fear because he liked that too. Sometimes she thought he could smell the fear on her, or maybe he just knew that it was on her all the time. She hated him with all her might and she was afraid to even say the word now because he might wake up.

She thought about closing her eyes and going back to sleep, but then she might just dream about him again. They slid shut anyway and she tried to slow her breathing. Next to her she could hear her own heart rate rising in steady blips. Please, let it not be him. Please don’t let him wake up.

“Victoria?” a voice said, but her eyes opened when she realized it wasn’t him. “Victoria Boston?”

The man sat up in his chair and he must have been sleeping because his hair looked ruffled and his suit had wrinkles and creases in it. He adjusted the glasses on his face and licked his lips, trying to put himself back together. “You are awake,” he said, and he forced a small smile.

“Yes,” she whispered. “Who are you?”

His face fell into a serious mask and he straightened his plain black tie. “I’m your arresting officer.”

“Arresting…?” she tilted her head to the side and went to raise one of her hands but she realized it was handcuffed to the bed. “What am I being arrested for?”

He blinked in surprise. “You don’t remember?”

She closed her eyes and tried to think. She remembered the hands on her throat, remembered her father forcing his way between her legs. She remembered screaming at him but that just made him hit her harder. Her hands scrambled desperately on the countertop for something, anything that could make it stop because she just wanted it to stop. She had just turned eighteen and she had just come back to get the last of her things and then she would never have to see him again.

Then she remembered her fingers curling around the knife. She remembered the look on his face when it sunk into his chest, remembered the surprise and fear, and it felt good. For the first time he was the one that was fucking afraid, and even when he hit her across the face and knocked her to the ground she didn’t care, because she had made him afraid.

She remembered stabbing him in the chest again. She must have stabbed him a hundred fucking times.

She didn’t feel guilty at all.

***


Something punctured her spine and she arched back off the table again, her eyes fluttering open.

The ceiling over her head was white, fluorescent lights staring down at her. Her head fell weakly to the side and to her right was a pane of glass. She could see her own reflection on it and there were so many things wrong on what was looking back at her that she couldn’t breathe. Then again, maybe that was because of the tube still coming out of her throat. Needles lined every inch of her and when electricity arced between them, she saw her hands shift into claws and back again.

What was happening to her? Where was she?

Electrodes had been fastened to her temples. She wondered what happened to her when electricity was shot through them. Maybe that was how they got her whole body to shift. She wondered why she felt a throbbing pain the back of her neck. She wondered how long she’d been here and what they were doing to her and she wondered when she had gotten her left eye back.

She wondered who she was.

She was starting to choke on the tube again as her lungs tried to breathe by themselves. She gagged and coughed and this time when she tried to raise her and to pull it out her body actually listened to her. The tube scraped against her throat as she yanked it out and gasped for air. No one was running across the room to stop her and drug her, but she heard the door opening and closing and she wondered how she could hear that from all the way the hell over here, behind two panes of glass.

Snakeskin boots clicked on the tile and she felt like that sound was familiar anyway, even if this place wasn’t. Bits and pieces of memory swam at the edge of her mind but she couldn’t pin any of them down. Her hand came up to brush over her left eye and she felt scars leading into a lid and she blinked when her fingers almost touched the iris.

Something was wrong here.

She spun and sat on the edge of the table, watching the man enter the room in the glass reflection. She knew him, even if she couldn’t remember his name or where she had seen him before. Recently, she thought, and her eyes narrowed as she tried to place him. He was wrong too, his eyes strange and golden snake eyes. He smelled wrong, smelled like an animal instead of a person and there was something about the way he moved that wasn’t human.

He was a shifter, she remembered. Like her.

“Victoria,” he said. “You’re awake.”

“Yes,” she responded, because she didn’t know what else to say.

“Are you going to the bar tonight to celebrate?”

Simon looked up at her and smiled. He was sitting in a chair, lacing his boots up as he got ready to leave for the last time. They all were, gathering their things together and saying goodbyes to all the other folks they’d worked with for the last few years. It felt weird to be saying goodbye after everything they’d been through. They had become a team, a family, and now that the contract was over they would start drifting apart.

“I figure Alexey will make me, whether I want to or not.”

She smiled, and then she reached for her hand, catching his fingers in hers. His smile softened a little and she hated it, because it made her chest hurt. It reminded her of the things she hadn’t told him yet, that she was leaving and not coming back. It reminded her that she loved him, no matter how much she said otherwise.

She couldn’t afford love. She couldn’t afford weakness.

“I want to come over later,” she told him quietly, and his smile widened. He brought her fingers to his lips and brushed them lightly over her skin, eyes never leaving hers.

She felt a hand slap her on the back. She didn’t manage to even turn around before Alexey was draping himself over her shoulder, a stupid grin on his face. “Hey, if you two are all done eye-fucking each other, there’s a lot of drinking to be done and I’m afraid we’re the only ones for the job.”

“You’re a little shit, you know that?” she said, her arm wrapping around his neck as she grabbed him in a headlock.

She tried not to scream as the blade twisted into her skin.

He was being careful not to permanently damage anything, but everything except vital organs was apparently fair game. Two of her fingers were already broken and they throbbed and screamed up her arm and into her brain. Most of her wounds had reopened and she was covered in sweat and blood and pain. Her hands were shaking and she pulled futilely at the handcuffs holding her down. Her wrists were numb from the metal digging into the flesh.

“What did Elias want with you?” he asked, twisting again.

Clouds of white and red burst in front of her eye as she stared at the ceiling. She tried to imagine they were clouds or stars or anything but her brain overloading on pain. She tried to tell herself she’d been through worse, remembering the sensation of claws ripping out her left eye.

The clamps closed down over her middle finger. “What did Elias want?”

She shook her head from side to side and bit her lip as she prepared for the crunch that came with snapping bone.

Her back arched when it came but the scream never left her throat. She thought maybe Simon would be proud of her. She wondered if Elias had realized she was missing yet and if he would bother to send anyone after her. No one else had known she was in China. Her match had ended yesterday and no one from the arena would bother to look for her for at least a week, if then. No one knew where she was. She didn’t even know where she was.

She couldn’t depend on anyone but herself.

He pulled out another needle and there was a pinch as it entered her neck. Her vision was beginning to swim and she was seeing all kinds of things around the room that she had to remind herself weren’t really there. For a moment she thought Simon was holding her broken fingers in his and then the sensation was shattered as her index finger cracked. This time the scream pulled its way from her throat and she could hear it echoing back to her across the room.

She swam in and out of consciousness, and after a while she couldn’t even feel the pain anymore.

“Victoria.” Someone was lightly slapping her face.

She rolled her head over and found herself staring into a pair of wicked gold eyes. They were the fucking snake eyes of Lyle Liddle and she growled and snapped at the hand. He laughed, pulling it back and stepping back away from her. He was digging into his coat pocket for something.

For a moment she blacked out again and then she heard him speaking.

“I’m sorry, I lied to you Vic.” Lyle was sitting in the chair in the corner of the room again, smoking his Marlboros with his feet propped up on the end of her bed. “You’re not my favorite. In fact, some times I really fucking hated you. Between you and Welsh, you were always making things worse. You know why?” He laughed and shook his head. “Because you two never know when to throw a fight. You never know when to just fucking walk away.”

“Alexey and Jezibel understood, though not as well as I do. Sometimes you just can’t fucking win. Sometimes you just have to throw in the towel and let it go.” He kicked the edge of her bed and the move reminded her of just how sore her body was. “You were never satisfied until something was dead, and you didn’t fucking care who it was.”

“I could’ve told you that would get you in trouble one day.”

“I’m going to rip your throat out,” she told him.

He just smiled. “Throw this fight,” he told her. “Tell me what I want to know and this will all stop. He couldn’t have told you anything that important. He didn’t even tell you what I took.” He sighed and leaned forward. “Victoria, this is the last time I’m going to come here to ask nicely, because honestly you’re starting to piss me off. Tell me what he said and I’ll help you out of this.”

She grinned and there was blood on her teeth. “Go fuck yourself,” she told him, spitting blood across the room.

He sighed again, shaking his head as he stood up. He walked across the room before hauling his fist back and punching her in the face. She heard a crack as his knuckles met her jaw and the pain seared through her nerves again. Then black flooded back into her good eye and she was gone.

She woke up again just before she hit the ground.

Her jaw cracked off the floor because she didn’t have the strength to even put her hands out. Blood bubbled from between her lips and she watched it puddle on the floor in front of her eyes. There was light in this room at least and she could see the mangled remains of her hand hit the cement next to her. A quiet whimper slipped from her lips and it was the only sound her raw and bleeding throat could manage.

She felt someone land a kick in her gut and a quiet laugh over her head and then the door slammed shut and left her wherever the hell she was. It was a struggle to breath and she felt the world tilting around her, spinning in a slow rotation over her head. She couldn’t remember how long it was since she’d last been conscious.

She couldn’t remember how long it had been since she hadn’t been in pain.

A small, strangled groan escaped her lips as she struggled to her knees. A cough wracked her form and she splattered blood across the concrete. Her elbow gave out from under her and she felt it slam against the floor. Another whimper dragged its way from her throat as she crawled her way to the wall. She fell back against it and tried to take stock of her surroundings.

She wasn’t sure how far they’d gone from the last place they’d held her, whether it was out of the country or just a floor down, but this room wasn’t half as nice as the other. There was a hole dug in the corner, presumably the bathroom and other than that it was concrete floors and thick mason walls. There was no window in this room either and the only airflow came from under the thick metal door and the giant vent in the middle of the room.

Also, it was really fucking cold.

She hadn’t been aware of it at first because she was still only half conscious, but now that she was aware of it, her teeth began to chatter in her head, goosebumps spreading across her skin. She pulled her mangled hand to her chest and whimpered as the broken fingers brushed her skin. Air hissed out of her lips and it came out in a white plume in front of her face.

She was so fucked. For the first time in her life she didn’t honestly know how she was going to get out of this.

She leaned her head back against the wall and sighed.

She wondered if she should call Lyle back in. She wondered if she should just tell him what Elias had asked her, because it honestly wasn’t that fucking much that it would compromise everyone. What if just mentioning their names was enough to get them a visit from Jumbo 2.0?

11413222211.content:
She dragged herself across the floor with her one good arm, nails digging into the cement. Every motion jostled her broken fingers and she had to bite her tongue to keep from crying. She didn’t cry over fucking pain, she was Victoria Wolfe and she was the baddest bitch this side of the planet. She told herself that over and over again, trying not to choke on the blood in her mouth.

She had to stop twice to let the room stop spinning and she hated herself for it because the goddamn door was only five feet away. She hated being weak, hated that she felt absolutely helpless in this situation and she didn’t know how to get out of it.

She hated that she kept wishing Simon was here.

Her breathing was heavy and ragged by the time she got to the door, pouring out from between her lips in thick white plumes. She closed her eyes and rested her forehead against the metal, trying to ignore the chill that shot down her spine and made her teeth chatter. It was so fucking cold here. Where the hell had they taken her, Siberia? She laughed a little because it was better than screaming and then she dragged herself up to her feet.

She wavered for a moment and she thought she was going to crash back down to the ground. Her fingers dug into the mason wall, trying to hold herself upright long enough for the spinning to stop and the pain to recede back down to a manageable agony instead of this fiery horror that was racing through her now.

Then she raised her fist and slammed it against the door.

It sent shooting pain up her arm so she did it again and again until she was numb with the shock of it and all she could hear was the rhythmic pounding, over and over again in her brain. “Lyle!” she shouted. Her voice was ragged and harsh. She didn’t recognize it as her voice anymore.

“Lyle you dirty fucker, where are you?” She bit down hard on the inside of her cheek because the tears were building in her eyes and she didn’t fucking cry over pain.

Oh, but this was bad.

It hurt so fucking bad.

Her teeth pierced the skin and she felt blood gushing into her mouth in a metallic flood. A harsh cry ripped itself from her throat and she slammed her fist against the door with more force as she howled into the room. “Lyle fucking Liddle!” and she didn’t know what else to say because she hated him right now with every piece of her she could spare because the rest of her was made of knives and needles stabbing into her over and over again until she was screaming.

She crumpled to the ground when the door opened because it had been the only thing holding her up. She was hauling deep, shaking breaths into her lungs, her whole body shivering now. She wondered if this is what going into shock felt like. She wondered if she was dying. The whole room was tumbling around her now, and in the center of it were a pair of snakeskin cowboy boots.

She focused on those and followed them up to the ceiling, where a pair of golden eyes stared down at her.

“I want to make a deal,” she said.

***

He handed her a cup of coffee from across the desk and she took it more gratefully than she wanted to. Her body welcomed the warmth, though her stomach probably would welcome the acidic liquid she was pouring into it. They had splinted the fingers, stitched up a couple of the knife wounds, and given her some painkillers. Amazing how quick things turned around when they thought she was giving them what they wanted. Suddenly Lyle was her best friend again, instead of the asshole punching her in the face.

She glanced at him now, and while he looked like he hadn’t slept in a couple of days he was already doing better than her. He was kicked back in the plush leather chair; his boots thrown up on the desk which she doubted was his. If it was, he probably wouldn’t be getting mud all over the paperwork.

“So,” he said from across the desk. “What kind of deal?”

She nodded slowly, wincing at the throbbing it started in her head. Most of her was numb thanks to the drugs they’d given her, and it was a sign of how bad off she was that she hadn’t even questioned it. If they wanted to kill her, they would just do it. If they wanted to seriously drug her, they’d just stick more needles in her. Either way she couldn’t stop them.

“I’ve got three pieces of information for you,” she said. Her eye narrowed. “So I want three things in return.”

He smirked. “Alright, what do you want?”

She set the coffee cup down on the edge of the desk so that she could lean forward and look him in the eyes. “The first thing,” she said. “I want to know what you stole. If I’m in the middle of this clusterfuck I at least want to know what the fight is over.”

He laughed. “Alright. Maybe I’ll tell you.”

She licked her lips and nodded, because that was one of the things she was willing to give up. She didn’t honestly expect him to keep his end of anything but if she could get something out of this it would be better than where she was at before. “The second thing,” she said, and her voice lowered in case anyone was listening. “I want the fuck out of here. Don’t tell me it can’t be done, just tell your associates you fucking shot me and left me in a ditch and let me out the back door.”

He tipped his head back and laughed, cigarette still between his lips. She hoped he died of lung cancer, except shifters couldn’t get cancer anymore. They had too much going on in their bodies as it was. “We’ll see about that. It’s not them I’m worried about, though I don’t want to piss them off. But if the Big Bosses find out I’m alive and the general area I’m at… well that could get messy for me.”

“Right,” she said, rolling her eye back in her head. “We wouldn’t want to inconvenience you.”

He grinned, his eyes narrowed slits. “Not right now you wouldn’t. What’s the last thing?”

She bit her lip, wondering if she should tell him now. She wanted his fucking word on this, and it was the one thing she couldn’t compromise on because it was the most important. Even if he betrayed her, even if he didn’t let her go, she had to know that the others would still be safe. The problem was, even asking it of him let him know that they were involved and she couldn’t afford for that to backfire on her.

“This doesn’t come back on the old crew,” she said finally.

He looked confused. “What do you mean? Why would…” and she saw the moment it dawned on him. He burst out laughing, running his hand through his blonde hair and shaking his head in disbelief. “Oh, I’m fucking stupid, I should have caught that to begin with. If he was dragging you into it, I should have assumed the others would be involved somehow too. So they’re the ones he’s got hunting me, huh? Is that one of the things you were going to tell me?”

She bared her teeth at him because she couldn’t quite make it a smile. “Yes. And I fucking mean it Lyle, you don’t hurt any of them or I swear to Christ I’ll…”

He laughed. “You’ll what? Bleed some more?”

“I’ll kill you,” she said, more calmly than she felt. “If I have to fucking crawl back out of a grave to do it, I will find you and I will rip your fucking head from your shoulders and no one will find the pieces that are left when I’m done with you.” She was breathing heavy because she was getting mad and her fingers were digging into the arms of the chair.

He was still laughing. “Yeah, you probably would. Fair enough, what else did you have for me?”

"You gonna give me what I asked for?"

He shrugged. "I suppose there's no reason not to."

She took a breath and then she told him. “Elias came to me to get me to sign a new contract, just to hunt you down. He told me that Alexey, Jezibel, Simon, Tony, and Delia had already signed up, and when I called him the night you sent Jumbo to visit me he was setting up a flight to Cairo. He said I’d get more information there, but that’s where he planned on looking for you first.”

She sighed, grabbing the coffee cup off the desk. “The thing I think you’ll be most interested in is that if he really is a traitor, it doesn’t seem like the Big Bosses know about it yet. So you’ve got leverage on him.”

He grinned. “All good things for me.”

“So, are you going to keep your end?” she asked, and she watched his eyes over the cup of coffee. “Or is this the part where you fucking shoot me in the back because if it is at least make it quick.”

***



Sung fucked like a train.

He was rough and hard and fast and she liked it. She liked that he didn't expect anything from her. She liked that it was just fucking, and not anything more. It had never been anything more with any of the guys she'd been with since him. It probably never would be.

She didn't sleep with all of her Keepers, because some of them weren't worth it to her, even if it was possible she only had one more day to live when they spent the night at her apartment. She'd have to take her chances. Not like she was a virgin or anything. But with Sung, she was just feeding a primal need that had popped up. And she tried to convince herself of that. She tried to forget what day tomorrow was. Because she'd always fucked Simon on his birthday. And it had always been the best she'd ever had. Because it was more than just fucking. It was love.

She hated love.

Sung rolled over in his sleep and she turned to look at him. His back was facing her and there were new scratches that ran criss cross over his shoulders. Damn, he liked it rough. So did she, though. Tomorrow, she'd go fight. Then she'd probably never see Sung again because he'd be assigned someone else to go play babysitter for. She didn't think he fucked everyone he watched, and not just because some of them were guys, but because he didn't seem the tpe.

Looking to the clock, she sighed when she realized how late it was. She should be asleep, she should snuggle Sung and just be content there was someone with her on what could possibly be her last night on earth and she should go to sleep. But she couldn't. She couldn't because of what day tomorrow was. It hurt. Because she wondered what he was doing and whether he was thinking of her and whether he was happy. Would anyone call him? Did anyone even talk to him anymore from their old crew? She hoped to god Alexey still did. Because if everyone had abandoned him, then she'd feel ten times worse. And that was saying something.

The phone rang and she reached out to snatch it quickly, glancing back over her shoulder at Sung. The Tiger Shifter stirred a little, but settled almost immediately. She pulled the phone to her ear and said quietly, "Yeah?" Who the fuck was calling her this late?

The voice on the other end was not one she expected. "Bitchzilla!" He was loud and obnoxious and the nickname spiked her heart with anxiety because she hadn't talked to him either since she left. But there was a hint of something else in his voice and she wondered what he'd been up to the past two years. She'd heard he'd been in Russia, playing super hero. Sounded about right.

"Alexey."

He lowered his voice, trying to be playful, but she could hear the strain and the exhaustion seep through anyway. "Why are we whispering?"

"What do you want?" She ignored his attempts at light heartedness.

Alexey sighed and she pulled herself from under the covers and went into the bathroom, shutting the door with a final glance to Sung, who was still peacefully asleep. She sat on the edge of the tub and put her head in her hands. If Alexey gave in that easily, something was wrong.

"Vic, how fast can you get to the States?" he asked.

She frowned. "Why would I want to go to the states?"

He scoffed. "Because I'm here, duh."

"Lex," she said softly, not in the mood.

The pause he gave her was enough to know that she should probably already be packing. Fight be damned.

12.content:
He really fucking hated interviews.

There was just something about reporters that grated on Simon's nerves. The way they smiled at you and pretended to be interested in the bullshit spewing from your mouth when really all they wanted was for some tidbit of juicy gossip to slip out so they could exploit it all over tv or in the papers on or the internet. So and so was sleeping with so and so, this person had this addiction, this person was in this rehab, bullshit, bullshit, etc, etc. It's how it went. They'd slide in next to you, be your best friend. You'd open up your heart and the next day everyone and their mothers knew your deepest, darkest secrets. And Simon Welsh didn't like it one fucking bit. Fucking reporters.

But the American Cage Fighting Association loved interviews. They loved selling off their stars to the tabloids and coming up with some grand schemes and stories to blow out of proportion. Because it put butts in the seats and money in their pockets. The ACFA was good for that. So if they told you to go out there and tell everyone you wore tutu's on Sundays because it made you feel so fucking alive - then you'd better do it. If you didn't, hey, you might find your contract with the association slipping. Maybe your name would stop appearing on the rosters. Or worse of all, maybe they'd ban you from organized fighting rings around the world. So the only action you'd ever see again in your life would be unsanctioned and much less pretty.

So Simon did his interviews. He gave the public what they wanted and his face was plastered on posters in pre-teen's rooms across the nation. He was allowed to fight in the cage fights. He was given sponsors and had a fan base and people adored him. It was the life of a star, of an athlete, it's what some kids dreamed of becoming when they were younger. Only Simon wished he could throw it all away and be done with. But this sort of contract, you didn't just walk away from. You walk away, you give up your Shifter rights, and they use you as a test subject in some lab - dead or alive, they didn't have a preference.

Simon had been dying. When the research had advanced far enough to allow humans to change their genome and shift between a human state and an animal state and somewhere in between the both, that's why Simon had been dying. Cancer. Spread through his body. No hope of survival. Weeks to live. Dying. The only cure science had found for the damn disease was Shifter genes. Replace the bad ones with the animal ones. He wasn't sure the science behind it all. But he was sure of one thing.

He'd be dead without the animal inside him.

So he did what he was told. At first, he'd been enlisted into a contract enforced by the government. Going to boot camp to learn his new skills and abilities, he excelled. He'd been one of the best. They'd agreed and had thrown him onto a mercenary team. The best fucking team around. He didn't regret a day of that contract. Because as terrible as the work was, the team had been family. Literally, in the case of his half brother, who'd been on the team. But the others, he'd die for them. Any of them. But especially her. Especially Vic.

He missed her. God, he missed her.

The team had split, a couple years ago and they'd all gone their separate ways. Some had gone off the radar, because their contracts weren't up. They refused to go on to other contracts. Refused to play puppet to some fighting association or side show company. Simon had stayed. The rest had left. And besides a few Christmas cards here and there, he didn't hear from any of them. Not Alexey. Not even Vic.

"Simon, tell me what you think about this upcoming fight," the reporter broke his thoughts and he looked up, forcing the cocky grin to his face that had become his signature among all the teenage girls who swooned over him. "Do you think you can beat the Rider brothers?"

The other reporters at the press conference waited patiently for Simon to answer, their individual taped to the table in front of him. A few other fighters who were on his "team" sat on either side of him, letting their "star" handle the questions aimed at him. Simon had no doubt he could beat the Rider brothers in a fight. He'd done it before. But, he stuck to the script he'd been given.

"Let me tell you something," he said, leaning closer to the mics. "There is no way that the Rider brothers are walking away from this fight. Because the Big Cat's coming out tomorrow. And he's bringing the pain!" Simon's teammates on either side let out a war-whoop and he forced his cocky grin to stay on his face. The few fans that had been let into the room who sat behind the reporters started screaming and yelling. A couple security guards had to come over and quiet them. Simon sat back in his chair, letting his teammates answer more questions as he maintained his character. Cool, calm, collected, ready to rumble.

He really fucking hated interviews.

123.content:
The night before his fights, Simon had a ritual.

It started back when Vic and Alexey and the others were around and they were a family. The night before a mission, they'd get together and watch Kung-Fu movies and drink beer and eat cheesy burritos and listen to each other scold themselves on how unhealthy and ridiculous their pre-mission rituals were. And you'd think they'd wake up the next day and be worse for wear. But they never were. There were never hangovers or re-appearing burritos. There were just focused Shifters and much too much adrenaline for one room.

So every night before his fights, Simon would rent a Kung-Fu movie. He'd pop a disgusting frozen burrito into the microwave. He'd crack open a Bud Light. And he'd sit on his couch alone, half watching a movie he'd seen a million times while trying not to choke on the food or the beer or the emptiness of the room. Sometimes he'd picture Vic and Alexey going at it. Fighting about some mundane topic like health care or muscle cars. Because whatever Vic said she liked or agreed with, Alexey would disagree and dislike. Simon knew his brother did it just to rile Vic up. Hell, he'd do it too if he wasn't certain she'd knock him unconscious to just shut him up. Vic always had a soft spot for Alexey. But she never seemed to hold back with him. He always thought it was because she was afraid of breaking Alexey's scrawny ass.

The memory, or the dream, whichever it was, made Simon laugh as he sat alone on his couch with a half-eaten burrito in one hand and a beer in the other. Some guy was getting his ass handed to him on the television and all Simon could think about was how empty the goddamn room was. He never thought they'd leave, like they did. He never thought that one night they'd say goodbye and disappear, just like that, without looking back. He understood why they did it. They'd said a long, long time ago that when their contracts with the government were up there was no way they'd be sold to some ridiculous other contract. Not like Simon and his showmanship association. They did real work. They did real fighting. They left like they said they would.

Turning his head to eye the picture on the coffee table, Simon rolled his eyes. He kept the team picture there. Him, Vic, Alexey, Jez, even fucking Lyle. There were others too. Bull, whose real name was Tony, and some rookies they'd conned into standing with them to make them look big and tough. Everyone was smiling. Even Vic.

God he was lame. He chuckled soberly at himself as he leaned forward and set his food and drink down. Who would of thought this is where he'd be. He hated how he came to these dark places before a fight. How he lived in the past and couldn't seem to get a grip on the future. Maybe it's because he didn't like the here and now. He didn't like what he'd become and that he couldn't escape it. He couldn't go fight bad guys in Russia with Alexey. He couldn't go do whatever the hell Vic was doing wherever the hell she was. He'd tried to keep track of her when she left, but she'd always been good and covering her trail.

A knock at the door had Simon running a hand over his eyes to clear them of whatever it was that was stinging at them and threatening to spill over - because it wasn't crying, he didn't fucking cry - and glancing at the clock. It was late, pass 1:00 in the morning. Whoever was interrupting his pre-fight ritual had better have a damn good reason to do so.

Standing, he walked to the door and yanked it open, not bothering to look through the peephole.

He knew it was a mistake the moment he saw the person on the other side.

The baseball bat hit the side of his head with a force that sent him into the wall and onto the floor before he could catch himself. He'd seen it coming and only quick reflexes kept him from getting the full brunt the attack had meant to hold. It was a glancing blow off his cheek, but still sent him to the ground, dazed and seeing stars. He tried to push himself up, even before the cobwebs cleared. Years of fighting and taking hits like this, maybe not as hard but similar nontheless, conditioning him to keep going. He'd gain his bearings while the ref held the other guy off. Oh wait...there was no ref.

The second blow caught him square in the back just as he was raising himself off the ground. It sent him back to the hardwood floor with a grunt that stole away his breath. He felt as though his chest had turned to stone, refusing to draw in air while a firey agony exploded between his shoulders. He coughed, expelling air, painful and slow and ripping out of his throat. He sucked in a gasp, equally as tricky and painful.

Out of the corner of his eyes, he saw his attacker drop the baseball bat. Simon thought about grabbing for it, but his new concussion and shock to his lungs slowed his reaction time. A pair of black boots came into sight and he tried to roll his head so he could see who was standing over him. A boot greeted him in the face instead.

"Fuck..." Simon growled, breath still struggling. His face and chest were on fire. The left side of his face felt broken and he wasn't sure but he thought maybe his left eye was swollen shut. When he moved his arm, his back flared with pain. Another boot to the face split his lips and shattered his nose. He cried out, only to have someone grab his hair and roughly jerk his head back, hand covering his mouth. He tasted blood, draining back from his nose and coming in from his lips. Tears came unbidden to his eyes.

Funny, the only thing he could think of at the moment was how much shit he'd get from Vic if she ever found out he'd let him get his ass handed to him. Excuses ran through his head. Like maybe he hadn't expected to be attacked at 1:00 in the morning. Maybe the beer had slowed him down. Maybe the burrito had clogged his arteries and not enough blood was getting to his brain. She'd probably laugh at that one. Then smack him upside the head.

He wished she was here. He wished she had never left. He wished he could tell her how much he loved her.

Simon's head was slammed into the floor once, then twice, and on the third time, his world went dark and he swore he could hear Vic somewhere out there in the world.

And man, she sounded pissed.

Sometimes Lyle wished he was a cobra instead of a viper, because how cool would it be to sport that hood around whenever he shifted? He'd confessed that to Alexey once, when they were both drunk, and the fucker had the nerve to make some stupid G.I. Joe comment and Lyle had decided that from then on, he'd keep his own personal wants and desires to himself. Fucking Romanova, he should have kicked his ass.

Lyle hadn't thought about that cobra comment for a long time, but in Egypt, he was reminded of it constantly. There were snake charmers bascially on every corner of the fucking street. Anywhere he went, someone was playing a pipe or kissing a cobra or doing something else with the most deadliest snake in the world that no one in their right mind would do. Lyle thought about showing them what a real snake looked like and shifting in front of them. He wondered how many Egyptians he could get to crap their stupid robes. The thought made him laugh. He shut up though, because then he realized that was something that Alexey would come up with, and there was no way he was going to laugh at something that little prick would laugh at.

Two years. It seemed like longer. Two years since Victoria Wolfe's contract was up and she'd walked out on the team. Lyle always thought that was the beginning of the end for them. Simon still had a few months left on his contract. Alexey's ended the same day Victoria's had, and Lyle and Jezibel still had a year left each. Lyle hadn't stuck around, though. Simon had turned into an emo bitch, while the others said every day how they couldn't believe she'd just leave. Lyle got sick of it and a month later he'd left. Simon and Jez finished up their contracts and had taken on some ridiculous ones after that. Jez maybe just renenewd hers, Lyle couldn't be sure. She seemed like the type to stick around with the Big Bosses watching over her.

They'd came after him at first. The Big Bosses didn't like contract breakers and they'd sent bounty hunters after him to either bring him back or take him out. They'd almost succeeded in both, several times. But an "almost" was still a failure. Because Lyle wouldn't go back to them, ever. He'd slit his own fucking wrists before he went back to those bastards. And now, he'd found something ten times better to look forward too.

Treasure.

It sounded ridiculous every time he said it. He knew the others would laugh at him if they got the chance, but in all honesty, once they say the type of money he brought in with his so called treasure, they'd shut their fucking mouths, that was for sure. He'd come to Cairo with a few other Shifters who had ended their contracts early. They were a rough sort and Lyle seemed to fit right in with them. He wouldn't exactly call himself a bad guy, because he'd never done anything like kill a guy who didn't deserve it. But he wasn't exactly an upstanding citizen, either. He was greedy and he was slimy and he lied every other word out of his mouth. Maybe that's why Diego and Vanya liked him. They were just like him and neither of the three trusted each other and it was a mutual and respectful relationship - with the chance of being backstabbed made very clear from the beginning.

Diego was a Dingo Shifter, and that made Lyle laugh on a daily basis. Vanya had eagle in him. Lyle had always liked the avian shifters. They were a different class of style altogether. Jezibel had been avian, an owl. She'd been graceful and seductive and altogether deadly. Vanya wasn't graceful or seductive, but Lyle had seen him kill a man and he had to admit, talons were way fucking cooler than claws.

"Lie-del," Diego's Mexican accent rang out and Lyle sighed, not bothering to look up from the drink he had in front of him. They said it was homemade whiskey, but he thought it tasted a lot like Jim Beam.

"It's pronounced Little," he drawled out in his Texan accent.

The man snorted and took a seat next to Lyle, who gave him a half grin before ordering a round of drinks for both of them, an extra one for Vanya when he showed up, because Lyle didn't want to hear the fucking Russian bitch and moan about not having a drink.

"Tex," Diego said, drawing Lyle's gaze towards him. "I think I found what we've been looking for."

Lyle scoffed. "That's bullshit."

Diego raised an eyebrow, confused. "What?"

"That's bullshit," Lyle repeated. "If you found it, you wouldn't be here. You'd be out trying to get it for yourself."

The Mexican laughed and Lyle couldn't help but smile. "That'd be true, if I didn't think it's going to take all three of us to pull this off."

Lyle snorted. "Are you going to shoot us in the backs when we get it?"

"Probably."

"Oh, good, I'll bring my glock. We can have a shoot out. It'll be fun."

The two laughed and clinked glasses before downing their shots like it was some funny joke and light banter that passed between them. But they were both aware that if at any time one of them deemed the other two unnecessary for this job, or future jobs, they wouldn't hesitate to kill the others. Luckily, so far, the "future jobs" part was what kept the blood from spilling. They hadn't scored anything big enough to retire happily yet. But once they did, it was a mutual agreement that their partnerships would be over and that meant there would be two bodies and only one rich sonofabitch in the end.

Lyle only hoped he would be the rich sonofabitch and not a body.

15.content:
Alexey hated the snow.

Why the hell he ever moved to Russia was beyond him. It seemed to snow every day, no matter what time of year it was. He wasn't sure if that's how this country was suppose to be, but it's how it was. Maybe the weather had just been bad because he was in town and the world was entirely working against him. He didn't know. He didn't care. He just knew he hated the fucking snow. And he was getting damn tired of this stupid country.

But he didn't have a choice. He couldn't exactly turn around and tell his contractors that he wanted to walk away because he hated the weather. They'd probably laugh at him and then put a bullet in him. That's why he liked them. Well, liked was a loose term. That's why he was entertained by them. They kept things interesting. The only contract was less entertaining. A bunch of suits with sticks up their asses. Kill this person, steal this stuff, retrieve this information, blah blah blah. At least with bounty hunting things staying interesting. Mercenary work was...predictable.

He did miss his old team, though. His new team was a bunch of amateurs and he was the only Shifter. The only one held to a contract so the no one stuck around long. They got their feet wet in Russian bounty hunting and then moved on, because they weren't required to stick around and they definitely weren't required to enjoy it. Not like Alexey was. Not like he had ingrained himself to be. So he considered himself a solo artist, with some back up singers every once in a while. He couldn't count on them because one day he may have someone with years of experience at his back and the next day he's got a rookie fresh out of basic.

Sometimes he missed having people he could trust. People he could count on. People he could call friends.

Simon, Victoria, Jezibel, Lyle. Well, maybe not so much Lyle, he'd always been a prick. But the others, for sure. Simon because he was his half brother. Victoria because she was just a badass. And Jezibel because she was fucking hot as hell. And they were a family. But, using the term loosely, because he didn't really want to call Jez family, just in case, you know?

"About time you showed up." The voice caught him off guard and he turned quickly to look behind him. His employer was walking towards him, through the few inches of snow accumulated on the ground. He had his hands stuffed into his coat pockets and there was a furry god awful looking hat on his head. Alexey snorted. Russian fashion, he'd never understand it. Although, it was probably warmer than his own wimpy hat. He frowned. Dammit, now he wanted a stupid furry hat.

He grinned and threw his cigarette to the side. Simon had always told him smoking was bad for him. Ever since they were teenagers and Alexey had gotten into the "dark side" of beer and cigarettes. Simon had always been the healthy one. But with an unusual obsession with tattoos. He'd still eaten healthy, worked out and stayed in shape. Alexey had gone the opposite route, although still maintained he had a nice body, even if he was a little skinny in some places.

Funny how it had been Simon who'd wound up with a fucking brain tumor, even with his obsession with being healthy.

Wait, there was nothing funny about that.

"I've been here for twenty minutes," Alexey complained half heartedly.

His Employer grinned and came to stand next to him. "Fucking cold," he said and pulled an envelope from his coat, handing it to Alexey.

The Fox Shifter looked at it for a moment, keeping it closed. "You know, I was thinking about suggesting moving this little operation of ours to warmer climates. I hear Costa Rica is a nice place for criminals and heathens."

"Good luck with that," the man grit out, shivering a little. He'd probably made a half dozen other stops to bounty hunters before he'd gotten to Alexey. He didn't envy the man.

Opening the envelope, Alexey reached inside and pulled out the picture of the person he was supposed to hunt. He quirked a brow and looked to his Employer, grin on his face, though it was timid and unnatural. "You're joking, right?"

The man gave him a pointed look. "I don't fucking joke when it's this damn cold out."

The grin faded quickly from Alexey's face and he turned back to the picture. "Shit."

inspired by "Metamorphosis"   by ΚΙΣVΣ (71)

When the world discovered gene splicing it was a gift to some and a curse for others. The world now had the technology to cure cancer, escape disease, and create a new kind of human altogether. Though some had trouble admitting they were human at all.

It started simply, merging pig genes with that of a human. The human body seemed to accept pig tissue more than any other creature. But technology grew and experiments grew more complex. It changed from just replacing human hearts with pig hearts and went to replacing entire chromosomes, changing the human genome.

The earliest experiments had no choice but to take on a half human half animal form after their genes were spliced. Many were scrutinzed and even unaccepted by the public eye. So scientists began to develop a way of switching between human and animal form. Thus began a new sub-race of humans known as the Shifters.

Shifters began finding a new role in society. From entertainers to soldiers to criminals. It is the Shifters now who will mold our future. It is the Shifters now who will save us from ourselves.


~***~



Characters:

Victoria Wolfe - Wolf shifter. Brown hair, golden eyes. She has a patch over one eye when she lost it in an arena fighting match. She's cold and distant but a born leader. She doesn't take bullshit and she hardly laughs. She's always down to business but only if it's something worth her time. She's constantly appraising people and only surrounds herself with people she feels deserve to be there. But even though she is distant from most, she is extremely dedicated to the people she cares about and will do anything to protect them.
         Location: Beijing, China
         Occupation: Death Match Cage Fighter



Simon Welsh - Black Panther Shifter. Short black hair, green eyes. He has tattoos that span the length of both arms and wrap around his back, also on his calves. He's light hearted and good humored. Though he tends to stay on the quiet, reserved side, he can really let loose when around friends. He's muscled and good in a fight. He tends to hide it when he's hurt or upset, instead playing it off with a smile or a joke. He's good at what he does, but seems to attract trouble and violence.
         Location: New York, New York
         Occupation: American League Show Fighter



Lyle "Tex" Liddle - Viper Shifter. Sandy blonde hair, yellow eyes. His most famous quote: "It's pronounced Little." He is uppity, self-centered, sneaky and like his animal counterpart suggests, slimy. You never know if he's on your side or not, and that constant doubt and questioning usually keeps people at arms length, never getting close. He talks slowly, calculating his words. On his good days, he can have the humor of a clown. On his bad, he'll shoot his best friend in the head.
         Location: Cairo, Egypt
         Occupation: Tomb-raider, thief



Jezibel Givessi - Snowy White Owl Shifter. Bleach blonde hair, sky blue eyes. She is soft spoken and gentle. White is her favorite color and chastity comes without question. She is quick to befriend and slow to anger or doubt. But she is smart and wise and knows who to trust. Her delicacy can sometimes work in her favor, making people underestimate her ferocity in protecting those she cares about. She's a girly girl, very beautiful, and silently deadly when she needs to be.
         Location: Paris, France
         Occupation: Dancer



Alexey Romanova - Fox Shifter. Long black hair, piercing green eyes. He is Simon's younger half brother, they share a mother. He's cocky and arrogant. His favorite person in the world is himself, but that doesn't keep him from easily making friends and keeping them. Even with his odd humor and "I'm a badass" attitude, he's very protective and caring with his friends. He's a womanizer and a flirt. He share's his brother's penchance for getting into trouble.
         Location: Moscow, Russia
         Occupation: Bounty Hunter


~***~



Background Story: (Suggested) The backstory to this Interactive is that each of these characters were at one time mercenaries. They were hired or coerced into splicing their genes and in return for the free treatment, they would work on a mercenary contract for the government. These characters have either fled, fulfilled or still maintain their contract. At one time they all worked together - so feel free to have them meet up.

The fun thing about interactive stories are the many possibilities, so please use the above backstory only as a suggestion. Feel free to make up your own backstory/plot/other characters.
